(b)  Opening. Bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notices. 
(c)  Tabulation. A tabulation of all bids received shall be available for public inspection, and all original bids, together with all documents pertaining to the award of the contract, shall be retained and made a part of a permanent file or records in the office of the agent, and shall be open to public inspection. 
(Code 1956, § 2-108) 
Sec. 2-173. - Rejection of bids. 
    The agent shall have the authority to reject any bid if the price is deemed excessive or the quality of the product inferior. 
(Code 1956, § 2-108) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-57. 
Sec. 2-174. - Authority of agent to award contract. 
    The agent shall have the authority to award contracts within the purview of this article not exceeding ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in amount, provided such is approved in writing by the mayor or other duly designated person by the council. Contracts in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be awarded by the council. 
(Code 1956, § 2-108) 
Sec. 2-175. - Lowest responsible bidder. 
    Contracts shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder, and in determining such lowest responsible bidder, there shall be taken into consideration in addition to price, the following: 
(1)  The qualities of the commodities proposed to be supplied; 
(2)  Their conformity with specifications; 
(3)  The purposes for which required; 
(4)  The terms of delivery; 
(5)  Transportation charges; and 
(6)  The dates of delivery. 
The agent in the purchase of or contract for personal property or contractual services shall give preference, provided there is no sacrifice or loss in price or quality, to commodities produced in Alabama or by Alabama persons. If a bid is received from a person deemed to be a responsible bidder having a place of business within the city, which such bid is not more than three (3) percent greater than the bid of the lowest responsible bidder who does not have a place of business within the city, in such case the purchasing agent may award the contract to such resident responsible bidder. 
(Code 1956, § 2-108) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 41-16-50, 41-16-57. 
Sec. 2-176. - Award to other than low bidder. 
    When the award is not given to the lowest bidder, a full and complete statement of the reasons for placing the order elsewhere shall be prepared by the agent and filed with the other papers relating to the transaction. 
(Code 1956, § 2-108) 
State Law reference- Reasons for award to other than low bidder open to public inspection, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-57. 
Sec. 2-177. - Tie bids. 
(a)  Local vendors. If all bids received are for the same total amount or unit price, quality and service being equal, the contract shall be awarded to a local bidder. 
(b)  Outside vendors. Where subsection (a) above is not applicable, the agent shall award the contract to one of the tie bidders. 
(Code 1956, § 2-108) 
Sec. 2-178. - Performance bond. 
    The agent shall have the authority to require a performance bond before entering a contract in such amount as he shall find reasonably necessary to protect the best interest of the city when required by invitation for bids or proposals or otherwise required by law. 
(Code 1956, § 2-108) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-58. 
Sec. 2-179. - Partial contracts. 
    No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1956, § 2-108) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-54. 
Sec. 2-180. - Emergency purchases. 
    In case of emergency affecting public health, safety or convenience, so declared in writing by the agent, setting forth the nature of the danger to public health, safety or convenience because of delay, contracts may be let to the extent necessary to meet the emergency without public advertisement. Such action and the reasons therefor shall immediately be made public by the agent's reporting the same in writing to the council, where the same shall be spread upon the minutes of the council. 
(Code 1956, § 2-109) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-53. 
Sec. 2-181. - Inspection and testing. 
    The agent shall inspect or supervise the inspection of all deliveries of supplies or contractual services to determine their conformance with the specifications set forth in the order or contract, unless such inspection and supervision is vested in some other officer or authority by the council or by the provisions of applicable law. 
(1)  Inspection by using agency. The agent shall have the authority to authorize using agencies having the staff and facilities for adequate inspection to inspect all deliveries made to such using agencies, under rules and regulations which the agent shall prescribe. 
(2)  Test. The agent shall have the authority to require chemical and physical tests of samples submitted with bids and samples of deliveries which are necessary to determine their quality and conformance with the specifications, and in the performance of such test shall have the authority to make use of any laboratory facilities of the city or of any outside laboratory. 
(Code 1956, § 2-110) 
Sec. 2-182. - Surplus stock. 
    All using agencies shall submit to the agent, at such time and in such form as he shall prescribe, reports showing stocks of all supplies which are no longer used, or which have become obsolete, worn out or scrapped. 
(1)  Transfer. The agent shall have the authority to transfer surplus stock to other using agencies. 
(2)  Sale. The agent shall have the authority to sell all supplies which have become unsuitable for public use, or to exchange the same for or trade in the same on new supplies. 
(Code 1956, § 2-111) 
Sec. 2-183. - Procedure on rejection of bids. 
    In case the agent rejects all bids for the furnishing of any supplies he may invite new bids, or in the event only one bidder responds to the invitation to bid the agent may reject the bid and, with the specific approval of the council or its duly designated administrative official, may negotiate the purchase or contract, provided the negotiated price is lower than the bid price. 
(Code 1956, § 2-112) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-50. 
Sec. 2-184. - Exemptions from requirement for bids. 
    Anything in this article to the contrary notwithstanding, competitive bids shall not be required for: 
(1)  Purchases of utility services where no competition exists or rates are fixed by law. 
(2)  Purchases of insurance. 
(3)  Purchases of election supplies. 
(4)  Contracts for services of attorneys, physicians, architects, teachers, superintendents of construction, artists, appraisers, engineers, consultants, certified public accountants, public accountants or other individuals possessing a high degree of professional skill, where the personality of the individual plays a decisive part. 
(5)  Contracts of employment in the regular civil service. 
(6)  Purchases of products made or manufactured by the blind or visually handicapped under the direction or supervision of the Alabama Institute for Deaf and Blind. 
(7)  Purchases of maps or photographs purchased from a federal agency. 
(8)  Purchases of manuscripts, books, maps, pamphlets or periodicals. 
(9)  The selection of paying agents and trustees for any security issued by a public body. 
(10)  Contractual services and purchases of commodities for which there is only one vendor or supplier. 
(11)  Contractual services or purchases of personal property which by their very nature are impossible of award by competitive bidding. 
(12)  Purchases of products where the price of such products is already regulated and established by state law. 
(13)  All contracts and purchase orders for labor, services or work, or for the purchase or lease of materials, equipment, supplies or other personal property, involving less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
(14)  Purchases and contracts for which competitive bids are not required by the provisions of state law. 
(Code 1956, § 2-113) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-51. 
Secs. 2-185-2-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PARK AND RECREATION BOARD[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Supervision of cemetery, § 8-3. 
State Law reference- Park and recreation board, Acts 1973, No. 506; recreation boards, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-86-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-201. - Creation; composition; qualifications of members. 
    There is hereby created "The Park and Recreation Board of the City of Decatur, Alabama," referred to in this article as the "board." The board shall consist of seven (7) citizens of the city, who shall be chosen by the governing body because of their civic interests and who shall be persons particularly interested in the development of city parks, city playgrounds and community beautification. 
(Code 1956, § 2-55) 
Sec. 2-202. - Term of office; selection by council; vacancies. 
    Members of the board shall be appointed to serve for five-year staggered terms. Vacancies in unexpired terms shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments are made. 
(Code 1956, § 2-56) 
Sec. 2-203. - Authority; powers; duties; contract limitation; funds; officers; program. 
    The park and recreation board shall be authorized and empowered to counsel and advise with city government on maintenance, preservation, operation and use of all the lands and grounds within the city which have heretofore been or may hereafter be acquired by the city for use as parks, playgrounds or places of recreation, including Point Mallard Park. It shall be the duty of the board to recommend to the governing body the rates and fees schedule relating to the overall operation of the Point Mallard Park Complex. The board shall not have the right to bind or obligate the city in any way beyond the appropriations from time to time made by the city to the board, but shall receive and disburse the funds under such rules and regulations as it may adopt. It shall elect its own officers and plan its own program. 
(Code 1956, § 2-57; Ord. No. 2071, § 2, 4-4-77; Ord. No. 06-3889, § 2, 12-4-06) 
Sec. 2-204. - Reports; statements; accounts. 
    The board shall render such reports, statements and accounts of its affairs and transactions as shall be required from time to time by the mayor or by the city council. 
(Code 1956, § 2-58) 
Secs. 2-205-2-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - OLD BANK BOARD 

Sec. 2-221. - Created; duties and responsibilities; audit of records; report. 
    Under and pursuant to the terms and provisions of section 11-47-16, Code of Ala. 1975, as amended, and that deed dated July 24, 1974, of record in the office of the judge of probate of the county in deed book 913 at page 198, there is hereby created the old bank board, referred to in this article as the "board." The board shall be authorized and empowered to counsel and advise the city government on the restoration, preservation and use of the properties conveyed to the city by the aforementioned deed, hereinafter referred to as the "facility," and to administer said facility. The board is charged with the responsibility of seeing that the maintenance and operation of the facility is handled by qualified personnel, and to fulfill the terms and provisions and conditions of the aforesaid deed and enabling legislation. All agreements made by the board with others shall be subject to review and approval by the city council. The board shall not have the right to obligate the city at any time. The board shall have the right to collect and receive all income from the operation of the facility and to expend the same in the maintenance, operation and development thereof. The books, records and accounts of the board shall be submitted to and audited by the city at their regular intervals. The board shall make full report to the city council of its acts and doings at least once each year and at such other times as may be requested by the mayor or city council. 
(Code 1956, § 2-67) 
Sec. 2-222. - Composition; qualifications; terms of office. 
    The board shall be composed of eleven (11) members appointed by the city council. So long as Morgan County Post No. 15 of the American Legion remains an active and viable organization, at least four (4) of the members shall be appointed or elected by the city council from the members in good standing of such Post No. 15, upon recommendation from the board of trustees of said Post No. 15. All members of the board shall be residents of the city and shall serve for five-year terms, except that with respect to the initial appointment of the sixth through eleventh board members, such appointments shall be staggered from one (1) to five (5) years as shall be designated by the city council in its resolution or action of appointment or election, with the understanding that two (2) members shall be appointed for five-year terms. Board members may be removed at any time, with or without cause, by action of the city council. All terms shall run on a calendar year basis, terms expiring on December 31, except as otherwise provided in this section. All initial appointments shall be made for the specified term. Thereafter, appointments shall be made as the terms of office expire. Members shall continue to serve after the expiration of their terms until their successors are appointed. 
(Code 1956, § 2-68; Ord. No. 99-3534, § 1, 6-7-99) 
Sec. 2-223. - Election of officers; meetings; quorum; compensation. 
    The board shall elect one (1) of its members as chairman, one (1) as vice chairman and one (1) as secretary-treasurer. It shall hold such meetings as in the opinion of its members are necessary for the transaction of the business of the board and may adopt such rules and regulations for its operation and the operation of the facility as are reasonable and proper. Special meetings may be held at any time upon the call of the chairman or of any two (2) members of the board. Any business transacted at a meeting of the board at which a quorum is present and have had notice prior to the meeting shall be valid and binding. Six (6) members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of the business of the board. The members of the board shall receive no compensation for the services upon the board but shall be reimbursed from funds of the board for their actual expenses incurred in performing their duties as members of the board. 
(Code 1956, § 2-69; Ord. No. 99-3534, § 2, 6-7-99) 
Secs. 2-224-2-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - PLANNING COMMISSION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Pursuant to an agreement originally entered into by the City of Decatur on July 12, 1971, with Cullman County, Morgan County, Lawrence County, the City of Cullman, the City of Hartselle and the Town of Moulton, a regional planning and development commission was created pursuant to the provisions of Title 11, Chapter 85, Article 4 (sections 11-85-50 to 11-85-59, inclusive), Code of Alabama 1975, known as North Central Alabama Regional Council of Governments. This agency succeeded to the assets and functions of that regional planning commission known as North Central Alabama Regional Planning and Development Commission. See Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-85-50 et seq. 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Ch. 18; zoning, Ch. 25. 
State Law reference- Municipal planning commission, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-241. - Creation; composition; appointment; term of office. 
    Pursuant to Title 11, Chapter 52, Code of Ala. 1975, there is hereby created a planning commission for the city, to consist of nine (9) members, to be appointed for the terms and in the manner set forth in the above mentioned Title 11, Chapter 52, Code of Ala. 1975. 
(Code 1956, § 2-52) 
Sec. 2-242. - Master plan for city development; zoning plan; subdivision of certain unimproved property. 
(a)  The planning commission is authorized and empowered to make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the city, including any areas outside its boundaries which, in the commission's judgment, bear relation to the planning of such municipality. 
(b)  Such plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts and descriptive matter shall show the commission's recommendations for the development of such territory, including, among other things, the general location, character and extent of streets, viaducts, subways, bridges, waterways, waterfronts, boulevards, parkways, playgrounds, squares, parks, aviation fields and other public ways, grounds and open spaces, the general location and extent of public utilities and terminals, whether publicly or privately owned or operated, for water, light, sanitation, transportation, communication, power and other purposes, the removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, vacating, abandonment, change of use or extension of any of the foregoing ways, grounds, open spaces, buildings and premises; and, as the work of making the whole master plan progresses, the commission may from time to time adopt and publish a part or parts thereof, any such part to cover one or more major sections or divisions of the city, or one or more of the aforesaid or other functional matters to be included in the plan. 
(c)  The commission is authorized and empowered to adopt for transmittal to the city council a zoning plan for the control of the height, area, bulk, location and use of buildings and premises in the area. 
(d)  The commission is hereby authorized and empowered to exercise all powers and to do all things authorized to such commission by Title 11, Chapter 52, Articles 1 and 2, Code of Alabama 1975, and to exercise such control as is authorized under such Act with reference to subdivision of unimproved property within three (3) miles of the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1956, § 2-53) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-8; territorial jurisdiction of municipal planning commission as to subdivisions, § 11-52-30. 
Sec. 2-243. - Authority of mayor and city council. 
    The mayor and city council are hereby authorized and empowered to make all appointments and exercise all authority authorized by Code of Ala. 1975, section 11-52-1 et seq. 
(Code 1956, § 2-54) 
State Law reference- Planning, zoning and subdivisions, Code of Ala. 1975, Title 11, Ch. 52. 
Secs. 2-244-2-255. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - PLANNING DEPARTMENT[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Ch. 18; duties as to building numbers, § 20-22; zoning, Ch. 25. 

Sec. 2-256. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a department to be called the "planning department," and the person in charge thereof shall be known as the "planning director." The planning department shall: 
(1)  Gather and evaluate social, economic, financial and related data for use in the area of municipal planning and community development and shall prepare plans, charts, maps, sketches and designs pertinent to the formulation and maintenance of comprehensive plans, including the master plan. 
(2)  Prepare applications together with required data for submission for various governmental grants available to the city and its agencies, and where practical, provide administration for such grants. 
(3)  Prepare studies and plans for urban rehabilitation, relocation, transportation, zoning and other related development activities. 
(4)  Compile economic, social, engineering, financial and related data to be used in the analysis of community planning and development. 
(5)  Provide in-house support and consultant services to the planning commission in the performance of its duties and responsibilities. 
(6)  Perform such other functions of a related nature as shall be assigned to it by lawful authority from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 1-5-81) 
Sec. 2-257. - Qualifications and duties of director. 
    The planning director shall possess training and experience reflecting specialized knowledge and skill in the performance of planning and development services and in the direction of a planning department and planning program. He shall hold a master's degree in urban planning from a college or university accredited by the American Institute of Certified Planners. He shall be the department head and shall have authority over all personnel assigned to the planning department, subject however, to the personnel rules and regulations as such relate to classified employees. He shall see to the performance of responsibilities assigned to the planning department. The position of planning director, pursuant to the recommendation of the personnel board, shall be a position in the exempt service of the city. In addition to the duties enumerated, the planning director shall perform such duties as shall be assigned him by the mayor or city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 2, 1-5-81) 
Sec. 2-258. - Salary of director. 
    The salary for the position of planning director shall be fixed and adjusted from time to time, by resolution of the city council or by its duly authorized designee. The planning director shall receive such nonsalary fringe benefits and shall have the right to participate in such plans and programs as are generally available to other city employees, and shall earn and have vacation and sick leave on the same basis as classified employees. 
(Ord. No. 2263, § 3, 1-5-81) 
Secs. 2-259-2-275. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XIV. - AIRPORT ZONING COMMISSION; HUNTSVILLE-MADISON COUNTY AIRPORT[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference- Aviation, Ch. 6. 

Sec. 2-291. - Created; powers. 
    There is hereby created an airport zoning commission to have and exercise the following powers: To hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of Article II of Chapter 6 upon which such airport zoning commission under such regulations may be required to pass and to hear and decide specific variances. 
(Code 1956, § 2-90) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to appoint airport zoning commission, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-5. 
Sec. 2-292. - Membership; term; removal. 
    The airport zoning commission shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the city council, who shall serve for a term of three (3) years and until their successors are duly appointed and qualified. Members shall be removable by the appointing authority for cause, upon written charges, after a public hearing. 
(Code 1956, § 2-90) 
State Law reference- Membership and term of airport zoning commission, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-5. 
Sec. 2-293. - Organization; meetings; record of proceedings. 
    The airport zoning commission shall adopt rules for its governance and procedure in harmony with the provisions of this article. Meetings of the airport zoning commission shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the airport zoning commission may determine. The chairman, or in his absence the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All hearings of the airport zoning commission shall be public. The airport zoning commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon each question, or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall immediately be filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be a public record. 
(Code 1956, § 2-90) 
Sec. 2-294. - Hearings; decisions. 
(a)  The airport zoning commission shall fix a reasonable time for hearing applications, give public notice and due notice to the parties in interest and decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. 
(b)  The airport zoning commission may, in conformity with the provisions of this article, make such order, requirement, decision or determination as may be appropriate under the circumstances. 
(Code 1956, § 2-91) 
Sec. 2-295. - Findings of fact; conclusions of law. 
    The airport zoning commission shall make written findings of fact and conclusions of law giving the facts upon which it acted and its legal conclusions from such facts in reversing, affirming or modifying any order, requirement, decision or determination which comes before it under the provision of this article. 
(Code 1956, § 2-90) 
Sec. 2-296. - Appeals from decisions. 
    Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected, by any decision of the airport zoning commission may appeal to the circuit court of the county, as provided in Code of Ala. 1975, section 4-6-11. 
(Code 1956, § 2-92) 
Secs. 2-297-2-310. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - FARMERS MARKET BOARD[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 14. 

Sec. 2-311. - Created; powers. 
    There is hereby created a board through the joint action of the governing bodies of Morgan County, Alabama and the City of Decatur, Alabama to be called the "Morgan County-Decatur Farmers Market Board," referred to in this article as the "board." The board shall be authorized and empowered to counsel and advise with the respective governing bodies regarding the use and operation of the property and facility to be known as the farmers market located adjacent to the intersection of First Avenue Southeast and Second Street Southeast in Decatur, and to administer and determine policies for the operation of the market as a public facility for the benefit, welfare, protection and convenience of the citizens of Morgan County in the sale and purchase of fresh produce and agricultural products grown in and around Morgan County, Alabama. The board is charged with the responsibility of seeing that the maintenance, operation and administration of the market is handled by qualified personnel in the manner prescribed by law, and as may be directed from time to time by the respective governing bodies. All agreements made by the board with others shall be subject to review and approval of the respective governing bodies or their designee, delegated such authority by resolution. The board shall not have the right to obligate the county or the city at any time, except by agreement reviewed and approved as above stated. The board shall have the right to collect and receive all income from the operation of the market and to expend the same in the administration, maintenance, operation, use and development of the market. The books, records and accounts of the board shall be submitted to and audited by the respective governing bodies at regular intervals. The board shall fully report to the respective governing bodies of its actions, policies, regulations, rules and determination at least once a year and at such other times as may be requested by the respective governing bodies. 
(Ord. No. 84-2381, § 1, 3-12-84) 
Sec. 2-312. - Composition; terms; residence; removal; expenses. 
    The board shall be composed of five (5) members. One (1) member (alternating member) shall be appointed initially by the governing body of Morgan County and thereafter alternately by the governing bodies of the City of Decatur and Morgan County. Two (2) members shall be appointed by the governing body of the City of Decatur and two (2) members shall be appointed by the governing body of Morgan County. The initial term of office of the alternating member shall begin immediately upon his appointment and shall end on the second January 1 following the date of his appointment. Thereafter, the term of office of the alternating member shall be two (2) years. The initial terms of office of one (1) member appointed by the governing body of Morgan County and one (1) member appointed by the City of Decatur shall begin immediately upon their respective appointments and shall end on the second January 1 following the date of their appointment. The initial terms of office of one member appointed by Morgan County and one member appointed by the City of Decatur shall begin immediately upon their respective appointments and shall end on the fourth January 1 following the date of their appointment. Thereafter, the term of office of each such member (excluding the alternating member) shall be four (4) years. The respective governing bodies shall specify for which term each member it appoints is appointed. If at the expiration of any term of office of any member, a successor thereto shall not have been appointed, then the member whose term of office shall have expired shall continue to hold office until his successor shall be so appointed. If at any time there should be a vacancy on the board, a successor member to serve for the unexpired term applicable to such vacancy shall be appointed by the governing body of that one of the governing bodies that appointed the predecessor member. Each member appointed by Morgan County must be at the time of his appointment a resident of Morgan County. Each member appointed by the City of Decatur must be at the time of his appointment a resident of the city. A member may be removed at any time, with or without cause, by action of the governing body appointing said member. Each member shall serve as such without compensation but shall be reimbursed for expenses actually incurred by him in and about the performance of his duties, if approved by the respective governing bodies or their designee. 
(Ord. No. 84-2381, § 2, 3-12-84) 
Sec. 2-313. - Organization; meetings; quorum. 
    The board shall elect one (1) of its members as chairman, one (1) as vice chairman and one (1) as secretary-treasurer. It shall hold such meetings as in the opinion of its members are necessary for the transaction of the business of the board and may adopt such rules and regulations for its operation and the operation of the market as are reasonable and proper and in accordance with the laws, ordinances and resolutions of the state, county and city. Special meetings may be held at any time upon the call of the chairman or of any two (2) members of the board. Three (3) members shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of business of the board. 
(Ord. No. 84-2381, § 3, 3-12-84) 
Secs. 2-314-2-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-331. - Generally. 
    The city council shall make provision for such retirement, insurance and employee benefit programs as it shall determine from time to time. 
Secs. 2-332-2-350. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SOCIAL SECURITY[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference- Administration of funds of pension and retirement plans of cities, Code of Ala. 1975, § 36-31-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-351. - Ineligible positions, employees and officials. 
(a)  There is hereby excluded from this division any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position or any employee or official now covered, or authorized to be covered, by any other ordinance or law creating any retirement system for any employee or official of the city. 
(b)  There is hereby excluded from this division any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, or any employee or official, compensation for which is on a fee basis, or any position or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1956, § 21-6) 
Sec. 2-352. - City officials and employees under federal social security. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law or by this division and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of old age and survivor's insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, including Public Law 734 of the Eighty-first Congress. In pursuance of such policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1956, § 21-1) 
State Law reference- Social security for municipal employees, Code of Ala. 1975, § 36-28-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-353. - Mayor to execute agreements. 
    The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the state agency authorized to act to secure coverage of employees and officials as provided in section 2-352 of this division. 
(Code 1956, § 21-2) 
Sec. 2-354. - Records and reports. 
    The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1956, § 21-5) 
Sec. 2-355. - Contributions by city. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer's contributions, which shall be paid over to the state agency designated by such laws or regulations to receive same. 
(Code 1956, § 21-4) 
Sec. 2-356. - Contributions by employees; withholdings from salaries, etc. 
    Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 2-352 of this division are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state or federal agency designated by such laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Code 1956, § 21-3) 
Secs. 2-357-2-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 89-2805, adopted Jan. 16, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-3 as Art. XVII, §§ 2-401-2-403, was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Ch. 18. 

Sec. 2-401. - Established; purpose. 
(a)  There is hereby established a department to be called the "community development department," and the person in charge thereof shall be known as the "director of community development". The community development department shall: 
(1)  Coordinate the planning, organization and execution of all community development projects. 
(2)  Be responsible for the preparation, handling, and supervision of all CDBG entitlement applications and all grant in aid applications for approval. 
(3)  Administer all approved applications including, but not limited to, bid preparation, bidding, awarding of contracts, coordinating and/or directing contract work, approving all expenditures of funds, and close-out upon completion. 
(4)  Maintain all record systems as required by the U.S. Government, state and/or city regarding matters within the jurisdiction of the department. 
(5)  Coordinate all projects with federal and state agencies, city departments, agencies and boards, and other local governments and their agencies and boards. 
(6)  Perform such other functions of a related nature as shall be assigned to it by lawful authority from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 89-2805, § 1, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 2-402. - Director-Qualifications. 
    The director of community development shall possess training and experience reflecting specialized knowledge and skill in the directing and coordinating of the total operations of the community development program for a municipality. The director shall hold a degree from an accredited four-year college or university, supplemented by the attainment of a master's degree in planning or a related field, including experience in grant writing with five (5) years of grant in aid administration and at least two (2) years experience in administering public works related to municipal government. The director shall be the department head and shall have authority over all personnel assigned to the community development department, subject however, to the personnel rules and regulations as such relates to classified employees. The director shall see to the performance of responsibilities assigned to the community development department. The position of director of community development, pursuant to the recommendation of the personnel board, shall be a position in the exempt service of the city. In addition to the duties enumerated, the director of community development shall perform such duties as shall be assigned to the director by the mayor or city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 89-2805, § 2, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 2-403. - Same-Salary range; fringe benefits. 
    The salary range for the position of director of community development is hereby established at salary range 36, and may be adjusted, from time to time, by city council action or by its duly authorized designee. The director of community development shall receive such nonsalary fringe benefits and shall have the right to participate in such plans and programs as are generally available to other city employees, and shall earn and have vacation and sick leave on the same basis as classified employees. 
(Ord. No. 89-2805, § 3, 1-16-89) 
Secs. 2-404-2-410. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XIX. - URBAN FORESTRY ORDINANCE[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, amended the Code by, in effect, repealing former art. XIX, §§ 2-421-2-441, and adding a new art. XIX. Former art. XIX pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 98-3436A, adopted June 1, 1998. 

Sec. 2-421. - Purpose. 
    The mayor and city council find that trees are recognized as a highly valued asset providing a more healthful and beautiful environment in which to live. Healthy trees reduce air pollution and some forms of noise pollution, provide energy-saving shade and cooling, furnish habitat for wildlife, enhance aesthetics and property values, and are an important contributor to community image, pride, and quality of life. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-422. - Goals. 
    This article establishes regulations and goals necessary to ensure that the city will continue to realize the benefits provided by its urban forest and to increase such benefits. The provisions of this article are enacted to: 
(1)  Increase and maintain an acceptable amount of tree cover on public lands in the city; 
(2)  Provide a stable and sustainable city forest through proper species and age distribution; 
(3)  To utilize expertise of ISA certified arborist and other qualified urban forestry professionals; 
(4)  Educate the general public in an effort to encourage the accomplishment of the above listed goals on private property. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-423. - Definitions. 
    The words and phrases listed below shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section. 
    City tree/shrub. Any tree/shrub on property owned by the city or located in dedicated city right-of-way. 
    Damage. Any injury to any part of trees/shrubs including but not limited to improper tree care methods such as topping, tipping, round-over, flush cutting, cavity cleaning, etc. 
    Forestry program. Those employees of the parks and recreation department and community development department designated by the mayor to enforce this article, or their designees. 
    Owner or owners of property. Title holder or person having right of possession of real property and includes legal title holder as shown of record in the tax assessor's office, or agent of legal title holder of said property. 
    Person. Any individual, owner, title holder, agent, firm, corporation, partnership, association, or organization of any kind. It shall include, but not be limited to, any tenant, lessee, manager, operator, occupant, executor, executrix, administrator, guardian, or other person in charge of, care of, possession of, or control of any real or personal property. 
    Prune. Includes the correct arboricultural method of removing tree limbs at proper locations, but does not include practices such as topping, tipping, round-over, or flush-cutting. 
    Shrub. A woody plant, living more than one (1) year, obtaining less than twelve (12) feet in height at maturity, and that is usually branched near the ground. 
    Tree. A woody plant, living more than one (1) year, obtaining twelve (12) feet or more in height at maturity, and that is unbranched near the ground. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-424. - Jurisdiction. 
    The city shall have control of all trees, shrubs, and other plantings now or hereafter in any street, park, public right-of-way or other public place owned by the city or located in dedicated city right-of-way, and shall have the power to plant, care for, maintain, remove, and replace such trees, shrubs and other plantings. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-425. - Liability disclaimer. 
    Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to impose any additional liability upon this city, its officers or employees, nor to create any additional liability for the owner of any private property with regard to the duty to keep any tree, shrub or plant on his property or under his control in such condition as to prevent it from constituting a hazard or an impediment to travel or vision upon any street, park, boulevard, alley or public place within the city. 
    Any city tree maintenance is subject to budgetary constraints and the city in nowise guarantees the safety of any tree. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-426. - Unlawful interference. 
    No person, firm or corporation other than duly appointed city officials, shall interfere with the forestry program or persons acting under its authority while engaged in planting, maintaining, or removing any tree, shrub or plant in any street, park, boulevard, alley, public place owned by the city or located in dedicated city right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-427. - Appeals. 
    Any action of the forestry program may be appealed to and heard by the city council. To be effective, an appeal must be filed within fourteen (14) days after the decision of the forestry program. The appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the forestry program. The appeal shall clearly specify the reasons for which a hearing is requested. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-428. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, partnership, firm, corporation, or other entity who violates any provision of this article is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment in the city jail for a period not exceeding six (6) months, or both such fine and imprisonment. All such violations which are of a continuing nature shall constitute a separate offense for each day of such continuance. Any violation of this article shall also constitute a public nuisance and may be enjoined and abated as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-429. - Enforcement. 
    The forestry program is hereby charged with the responsibility for the enforcement of this article and may serve notice on any person in violation thereof. Upon notice from the forestry program, or its designees, any cutting, pruning, removal, planting or other activities being done contrary to the provisions of this article or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing, and shall be given to the owner of the property, or to his agent, or to the person doing the work, and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. In the event the owner or person in charge fails to cease, correct or remove the cause of such violation, then such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to prosecution in the municipal court of the city. Where imminent danger exists, the forestry program shall not be required to give written notice to stop the work. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-430. - Protection of existing public trees. 
    Existing public trees shall be protected to the extent that it is possible and feasible. If removed they will be replaced where practical. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-431. - Planting, maintenance, and removal of public trees by city departments. 
    All planting, maintenance, and removal of public trees by city departments or authorized agents shall follow the standards adopted by the forestry program. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-432. - Planting, maintenance, and removal of public trees by someone other than the city or its authorized agent. 
    Any planting, maintenance, or removal of trees on public property by someone other than the city or authorized agent of the city, shall first require permission from the forestry program. Applications are available at the parks and recreation maintenance office and must be submitted to the forestry program thirty (30) days prior to planting. The forestry program will notify, in writing, the person filing application as to its decision. Approved applicants should not treat trees until after they have received approval in writing from the forestry program. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-433. - Licensing of private tree care firms for work on public trees. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of pruning, trimming, or removing city trees shall carry public liability and property damage insurance in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) unless otherwise stipulated by the city council and policies or certificates thereof shall be filed with the city clerk. Where deemed advisable, the forestry program may require the posting of a performance bond to guarantee the completion of any job in accordance with adopted city standards, rules and regulations. Applicants should also show proof of workman's compensation as provided by law and vehicular liability insurance. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of pruning, trimming, or removing city trees shall possess a valid business license. All tree work will be performed under the direct supervision of a qualified arborist and will comply with all city standards and ordinances. 
    The forestry program may recommend the suspension or revocation of a tree care firm's business license to the city council, when forestry program determines that the firm has not complied with city tree care standards. The city council will set a hearing to consider such recommendation at its next available council meeting. The decision of the city council may be appealed to circuit court within fourteen (14) days for nonjury trial determination. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-434. - Harming public trees forbidden. 
    It shall be a violation of the provisions of this article for any person to abuse, destroy or mutilate any city owned tree, plant or shrub. Examples of such damage may include but are not limited to: Attachment or placement of any rope, wire (other than one used to support a young or broken tree), sign, poster, handbill, or other things to or on any city tree; or to cause or permit any wire charged with electricity to be placed or attached to any such tree; or allow any gaseous, liquid or solid substance which is harmful to such trees to come in contact with their roots, trunks, or leaves. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-435. - Resolution of conflicts between trees and structures. 
    Where sidewalk or curb damage due to tree roots occurs, every effort shall be made to correct the problem without removing or damaging the tree. The public works department or other designated department shall be responsible for developing or approving corrective measures in consultation with the forestry program. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-436. - Situations which are declared to be public nuisances. 
    Any tree, shrub or ground cover, growing or standing on private property in such a manner that any portion thereof interferes with any public street, sidewalk, alley or restrict the flow of traffic or visibility of such street, traffic signs or visibility, sidewalk, alley or intersection thereof to any person or persons lawfully using such streets, sidewalks, alleys or intersections shall constitute a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Sec. 2-437. - Abatement of hazards and public nuisances. 
    The city may remove or trim such tree, may permit any public utility to do so, or may require the property owner to remove or trim such tree on private property. The failure of the property owner, or his duly authorized agent, to remove such tree after fifteen (15) days notice shall be deemed a violation of the provisions of this article, and the forestry program may then remove or trim such tree and assess the cost thereof against the property. 
(Ord. No. 10-4055, § 2, 1-3-11) 
Secs. 2-438-2-449. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XX. - ANIMAL SHELTER BOARD 

Sec. 2-450. - Created; authority and duties; relationship to city council. 
    There is hereby created a board of the city to be called the animal shelter board, referred to in this article as the "board." The board shall be authorized and empowered to counsel and advise with city government on maintenance, preservation, operation and use of all property which is a part of the animal shelter complex, hereinafter referred to as the "facilities." The board is charged with the responsibility of advising and assisting the city government in seeing that the mission and legal responsibilities of the shelter are accomplished as may be directed from time to time by the city council. The board shall take an active role in the decision-making relating to these matters and shall give a full report to the mayor and city council at least quarterly of its actions and recommendations. The board may be requested by the mayor and council to give reports at such other times as are deemed appropriate. The board shall serve as a link between the community and the city to establish goals for the proper treatment of animals. The board shall abide by the established policies and procedures of the city animal shelter. The board shall not have the right to obligate the city at any time, except by agreements approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2001-3663, § 1, 8-6-01) 
Sec. 2-451. - Composition of board; terms of office. 
    The board shall be composed of five (5) members, one (1) of whom shall be appointed by the mayor, and four (4) of whom shall be appointed by the city council. All members of the board shall be residents of the city or own a business within the corporate limits and shall serve five-year terms, except that with respect to the initial board, such appointments shall be staggered from one (1) to five (5) years, as shall be designated by the city council and mayor in the resolution or action of appointment, with the understanding that the mayor's initial appointment to the board shall be for the five-year term. Board members may be removed at any time, with or without cause by action of the city council with respect to its appointments and the mayor with respect to his appointment. All terms shall run from the last day of the month in which the initial appointments are made. Thereafter, appointments shall be made as the terms of office expire. Members shall continue to serve after the expiration of their terms until their successors are appointed. 
(Ord. No. 2001-3663, § 1, 8-6-01) 
Sec. 2-452. - Officers; meetings; quorum; compensation. 
    The board shall elect one (1) of its members as chairman, one (1) as vice-chairman and one (1) as secretary-treasurer. It shall hold such meetings as in the opinion of its members are necessary for the transaction of the business of the board and may adopt such rules and regulations for its operation as are reasonable and proper. Special meetings may be held at any time upon the call of the chairman or of any two (2) members of the board. Three (3) members of the board shall constitute a quorum for conducting the business of the board. The members of the board shall receive no compensation for the services upon the board, but shall be reimbursed from animal shelter funds for their actual expenses incurred in performing their duties as members of the board if authorized by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 2001-3663, § 1, 8-6-01) 
Chapter 2.5 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 14; taxation, Ch. 21; zoning, Ch. 25. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2.5-1. - Definitions. 
    Wherever used in this chapter, the definitions set forth in Chapters 3, 3A and 7A of Title 28 of the Code of Alabama, 1975, are hereby adopted by reference, and made a part hereof as if fully set forth herein. In addition thereto, the following terms shall have the meanings herein specifically ascribed to them: 
    Bartender/server: An employee of a retail alcoholic beverage licensee who is directly involved with the opening, mixing, dispensing, serving, or final sale of alcoholic beverages to a customer of the licensed establishment. 
    Committee: The alcohol license review committee. 
    Lounge: Any place or premises in which liquor or wine is offered for sale for consumption within the building in which the establishment is located, which is operated by a responsible person of good reputation, and which meets the following additional requirements: 
(1)  A space for at least one thousand (1,000) square feet on one floor in one room accommodating at least thirty (30) persons at one time. 
(2)  Such establishment shall meet the minimum requirements for an Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board on-premises lounge retail liquor license. 
    Manager: An employee of a retail alcoholic beverage licensee who is given the responsibility and authority by the licensee to direct the operation of the licensed establishment, either solely or in conjunction with other similarly designated employees, by directing the activities of other employees of the licensed establishment. Such direction could include, but not be limited to, such responsibilities as assignment of employee tasks, scheduling of employee hours, evaluation of employee performance, and employee hiring or discipline. 
    Person in charge (PIC): A person or persons, whether owner, partner, officer, or employee of the alcoholic beverage licensee, who is designated by the licensee as a responsible party for the licensee in ensuring compliance with the law and regulations of the Code of Alabama, Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, and the Code of Decatur as apply to the operation of a business having retail sales of alcoholic beverages. 
    Restaurant; definition for restaurant retail liquor licensing purposes: A reputable place duly licensed as a restaurant, operated by a responsible person of good reputation, in which a diversified selection of food, refreshments and alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption within the building in which the establishment is located, and which meets the following additional requirements: 
(1)  Dining space. The dining space may include the bar area if it is contained entirely within the dining space and is operated under the same management. If the dining space has more than one (1) room, the additional rooms shall be connected by passages or doors ordinarily used by patrons who are customarily served from the same stock of alcoholic beverages. A life safety plan shall be submitted to and approved by the building official regardless of the size of the building or dining space. The life safety plan provided by the applicant's architect shall also be subject to approval by the Fire Marshall and shall show the number of seats, tables, chairs, exits, emergency lighting, means of egress, and fire extinguishing devices. All State of Alabama requirements for the issuance of a restaurant retail liquor license must be met. 
(2)  A kitchen separate and apart from said dining space, but adjoining the same, in which food is prepared for consumption by the public and in which the food or meals served in said dining space are prepared. The kitchen may be accessible to the dining space through the use of hallways. 
(3)  At least one (1) meal per day shall be served at least five (5) days a week, with the exception of holidays, vacations and periods for redecorating. 
(4)  Such place shall meet the minimum requirements for an Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board on-premises license. 
(5)  The serving of food or meals shall constitute the principal business of such establishment, with the serving of liquor, malt or brewed beverages, wines or other alcoholic beverages being only an incidental part of the business. During any ninety-day period, the gross receipts from the serving of meals and food shall constitute at least sixty (60) percent of the total gross receipts of the business. The licensee for such establishment shall maintain a cash receipting system which provides a distinct separation of receipts for food items and for liquor, malt or brewed beverages, wines or other alcoholic beverages. In addition, the licensee for such establishment shall maintain all invoices for the purchases of food and all types of alcoholic beverages and shall preserve such records for not less than three (3) years. All such records shall be available for inspection and audit at the licensee's premises within the city during regular business hours as the revenue department, or duly authorized representative, may request. 
(Ord. No. 84-2412, § 1, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 90-2963, § 1, 12-10-90; Ord. No. 97-3399, § 1, 10-6-97; Ord. No. 98-3460, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-98; Ord. No. 16-4255 , § 1, 3-21-16) 
Sec. 2.5-1.1. - Exception. 
    The property under lease by the city to Riverwalk Marina, L.L.C., is currently not served by public sewer and due to the location and character of such property it is not presently economically feasible to design and construct and alternative sewage disposal system for such property which should accommodate a full-service restaurant capable of seating in excess of one hundred (100) persons. For purposes of this chapter, as to the property leased to Riverwalk Marina, L.L.C. by the city under lease dated June 23, 1995, as amended by the certain amendment to lease dated September 21, 1995, the following terms shall have the meanings herein specifically ascribed to them and shall be construed as exceptions to the definitions contained in section 2.5-1 of this Code: 
    Restaurant: A reputable place licensed as a restaurant, operated by a responsible person of good reputation, in which a diversified selection of food, refreshments and alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on a deck permanently affixed to the property where the establishment is located, and which meets the following additional requirements: 
(1)  A dining space on such deck of at least one thousand (1,000) square feet and said dining room to be equipped with tables and chairs accommodating at least fifty (50) persons at one time. 
(2)  A kitchen separate and apart from said dining area, but adjoining the same, in which food is prepared for consumption by the public and in which the food or meals served on said dining area are prepared. Such kitchen may be located in a mobile trailer type facility so long as such facility is licensed and approved by the State of Alabama Department of Public Health and such kitchen and deck facility is connected to a septic tank system approved by the State of Alabama Department of Public Health. 
(3)  Said restaurant must serve at least one meal per day when it is open for business. 
(4)  Such place shall meet the minimum requirements for an Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board on-premises license. 
(5)  The serving of food or meals shall constitute the principal business of such establishment, with the serving of liquor, malt or brewed beverages, wines, or other alcoholic beverages being only an incidental part of the business. During any ninety-day period, the gross receipts from the serving of meals and food shall constitute more than sixty (60) percent of the gross receipts of the business. The licensee for such establishment shall maintain all invoices for the purchases of food and all types of alcoholic beverages and shall preserve such records for not less than three (3) years. All such records shall be available for inspection and audit at the licensee's premises within the city during regular business hours as the revenue department, or its duly authorized representative, may request. 
(6)  A mobile trailer type facility may be utilized as the restroom facilities for the above restaurant facility so long as such restroom facility is connected to a septic tank system approved by the State of Alabama Department of Public Health. 
(7)  The exceptions granted herein shall cease to be effective eighteen (18) months after it is determined by the city council in a duly adopted resolution that the subject property under lease can be served by a public sewer system at a cost to the tenant of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or less. 
(Ord. No. 97-3369, § 1, 6-2-97; Ord. No. 98-3460, § 3, 7-6-98) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 97-3369, § 1, adopted June 2, 1997, amended the Code by adding a new section to be numbered § 2.5-1(A). In order to conform the new section numbering to Code style, the editor has redesignated said new section as § 2.5-1.1. 
Sec. 2.5-1.2. - Drinking, serving, dispensing of beer and wine within the Carnegie Visual Arts Center. 
    The other provisions of this Code notwithstanding, the drinking, serving, and dispensing of beer and table wine on a limited basis is hereby authorized within the confines of the Carnegie Visual Arts Center, subject to compliance with the following conditions: 
(1)  The required special events retail licenses are approved and maintained for such use from the city and the alcoholic beverage control board of the state. 
(2)  The duration of the licensed event is not more than two (2) days and the licensee is a nonprofit entity. The licensed event shall not be held or be in progress after 4 p.m. on any Wednesday. No licensed event will be held or be in progress on any Sunday. 
(3)  All drinking, serving and dispensing of alcoholic beverages will be without compensation to the licensee or any other entity using the premises in compliance with the rules, regulations, and policies of the alcoholic beverage control board of the state regarding their determination of any beverages being provided on a complimentary basis as opposed to constituting a sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(4)  Each licensee shall comply with all requirements, regulations, guidelines, ordinances, and laws of the state and the city which are not in conflict with the limited authorization of such use at the particular location. 
(Ord. No. 05-3841, § 1, 8-1-05) 
Sec. 2.5-2. - Construction. 
    This chapter shall be construed as an exercise by the city of the police power of the state delegated to the city, in the regulation of traffic in alcoholic beverages within the jurisdiction of the city, and also as an ordinance enacted for the purpose of raising revenue. Whenever the context requires, the words used herein in the masculine gender include the feminine and neuter, and words used in the neuter gender include the masculine and feminine. 
(Ord. No. 84-2412, § 25, 2-4-85) 
Sec. 2.5-3. - Location of premises near church or school. 
(a)  Subject to exceptions herein contained, no facility or property shall be authorized for on-premises sale or off-premises sale of alcoholic beverages where any part of the building in which the premises is located is less than five hundred (500) feet from any building in which there is a church, or a public or private elementary or secondary school. Provided, however, as regards: 
(1)  Off-premises sale of beer and table wine; and 
(2)  Except for premises located within a B5 (Central Business District) Zoning District, on-premises sale of alcoholic beverages by licensees other than class I lounges not operated in conjunction with a licensed restaurant, hotel or motel, and off-premises sale of alcoholic beverages other than beer and table wine, where no part of the building in which the licensed premises are located is closer than two hundred (200) feet from any building in which there is a church, or a public or private elementary or secondary school the aforesaid distance restrictions shall not apply in the following enumerated cases: 
a.  Where the licensed premises are separated from the church or school by a street or highway having four (4) or more traffic lanes; 
b.  Where the licensed premises and the church or school front on different streets and do not have common exits or driveways providing access; 
c.  Where the licensed premises and the church or school are separated by a permanent building, or topographical or man-made barrier, and the council or its duly delegated agent finds that the separation adequately screens and insulates the premises whereby the spirit of the separation requirement herein provided is substantially achieved; or 
(3)  For premises located in a B5 (Central Business District) Zoning District, on-premises sale of alcoholic beverages by licensees other than class I lounges not operated in conjunction with a licensed restaurant, hotel or motel, and off-premises sale of alcoholic beverages other than beer and table wine, where no part of the building in which the licensed premises are located is closer than twenty five (25) feet from any building in which there is a church, or a public or private elementary or secondary school the aforesaid distance restrictions shall not apply. However, no alcoholic beverages can be served or consumed in the exterior part of the building adjacent to a church or school. 
(b)  Where the church or school was established after the licensed premises began operation and said operation has not been abandoned or discontinued for a period of six (6) months the above distance restrictions do not apply. 
(c)  When measuring from a church or a school, the closest exterior wall of the closest building in the church or school complex wherein an essential function or activity of the church or school is carried on shall constitute the beginning point for measurement. When measuring from the licensed premises, the closest point on the exterior wall of the building occupied by the licensee shall be used for measurement purposes if the building is occupied solely by the licensee, otherwise, such measurement shall be made from the closest point of the licensee's occupancy within the building in question. 
(Ord. No. 84-2412, § 7, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 17-4310 , § 1, 12-5-17) 
Sec. 2.5-4. - Maintenance of order; report of violation. 
    It shall be the duty of each licensee engaged in the retail sales of alcoholic beverages, and of each employee of that licensee who is designated as a person-in-charge or manager as defined in this article, while the licensed premises are open to the public, to maintain order upon the premises and to exclude from the premises any person who is drunk and disorderly or who commits any breach of the peace, or who uses or engages in offensive, disorderly, threatening, abusive or insulting language, conduct or behavior with the intent to provoke a breach of the peace, or whereby a breach of the peace might be occasioned. It shall be the duty of each licensee, designated person-in-charge, or manager in charge of any premises licensed for the retail sales of alcoholic beverages, immediately to make an appropriate report to the police department of the city of each assault, assault and battery or affray, occurring on the licensed premises while said premises are open for business. It shall further be the duty of said person to make a written report of each of said incidents to the police department of the city and to the local field office of the alcoholic beverage control board within thirty-six (36) hours thereof. 
(Ord. No. 84-2412, § 9, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 98-3460, § 4, 7-6-98) 
Sec. 2.5-5. - Offenses in public. 
    Except as authorized in the Arts and Entertainment District by the provisions of article IX of chapter 25 of this Code it shall be unlawful for any person to drink, sell, serve, dispense or give away, or attempt to drink, sell, serve or give away, any liquor, wine or malt or brewed beverages, while upon any street, alley or in any public building or upon any public property, or while in any other public place in the city. As used in this section, the term "public place" shall mean and include any place or gathering which the public generally attends or is admitted to, either by invitation, common consent or right, or by the payment of an admission or other charge, and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, shall include public parks, city hall, library, school buildings, auditoriums, any store or place where merchandise of any kind is offered for sale, any theater or other place of amusement and any athletic contest; provided, that such term shall not mean or include premises which have been duly licensed by the city for sale thereon of such beverages. 
(Ord. No. 84-2413, § 2, 11-19-84; Ord. No. 84-2422, § 4, 12-17-84; Ord. No. 84-2412, § 10, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 85-2449, § 4, 3-4-85; Ord. No. 13-4142, § 1 , 4-1-13) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages in open containers, § 2.5-15. 
Sec. 2.5-6. - Minors; drunkards, insane persons-Offenses by seller or agent. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or for any employee, servant or agent of any person to sell, or offer for sale, any liquor, wine or beer to any person visibly intoxicated, or to any insane person, or to any minor, or to any habitual drunkard. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to serve to a minor or allow a minor to be served any liquor, beer or wine in any place where such beverages are sold. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person who operates any business of selling liquor, beer or wine to allow any liquor, beer or wine to be sold to any minor, or to be consumed by any minor, on the premises where such liquor, beer or wine is sold. 
(Ord. No. 84-2412, § 11, 2-4-85) 
Sec. 2.5-7. - Same-Offenses generally. 
    It shall be unlawful to do or perform any of the acts or things designated as follows: 
(1)  For any minor person, directly or indirectly, to purchase any malt or brewed beverages, any wine or liquor, or any alcoholic or intoxicating beverage, or to attempt to purchase any of said beverages. 
(2)  For any minor person to possess or to consume any malt or brewed beverages, any wine or liquor, or any alcoholic or intoxicating beverage, in any public place, or in any business establishment or club. 
(3)  For any person to sell, furnish, give to or purchase for any minor person any malt or brewed beverages, any wine or liquor, or any alcoholic or intoxicating beverage, or to attempt to sell, furnish, give to or purchase for any minor person any of said beverages. 
(4)  For any person to hire, employ or allow any person under twenty-one (21) years of age to serve or dispense alcoholic beverages of any kind. However, this prohibition does not apply when the only license held by the licensee is an off-premises beer license or an off-premises table wine license or a combination thereof, and provided there is an adult in attendance at all times. 
(5)  For any minor person, directly or indirectly, to falsely represent that such person is not a minor or is not under twenty-one (21) years of age, by means of which false representation such person buys, receives or otherwise obtains, or attempts to buy, receive or otherwise obtain any malt or brewed beverages, any wine or liquor or any alcoholic or intoxicating beverages. 
(6)  For any person, directly or indirectly, to falsely represent or attempt to falsely represent that a minor person is not a minor or is not twenty-one (21) years of age, by means of which false representation such person aids or abets, or attempts to aid or abet, such minor person to buy, receive or otherwise obtain any malt or brewed beverage, any wine or liquor or any alcoholic or intoxicating beverages. 
(7)  For any person under twenty-one (21) years of age to enter or remain within the premises of an establishment licensed for the on-premise consumption of alcoholic beverages. However, this prohibition does not apply when the establishment is currently licensed as a restaurant as defined in section 2.5-1 of this article, or when the only alcoholic beverage license is for on-premise beer or on-premise table wine, or any combination thereof, or when the person is employed by the licensee for the provision of entertainment and in such case, this person is limited in access to only the performance area of the premises. In no case shall this minor person be allowed to participate in the sale, serving, or dispensing of any alcoholic beverages or any other function of the licensee excepting the entertainment. 
(Ord. No. 84-2412, § 12, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 90-2963, §§ 2-4, 12-10-90; Ord. No. 98-3460, § 5, 7-6-98) 
Sec. 2.5-8. - False representation. 
    It shall be considered a false representation that a minor person is not a minor or is not under twenty-one (21) years of age, if the purchaser fails to disclose that the person making the purchase, obtaining or securing such malt or brewed beverages, or such wines or liquors, or such alcoholic or intoxicating beverages, is a minor person or has not reached the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(Ord. No. 84-2412, § 13, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 98-3460, § 6, 7-6-98) 
Sec. 2.5-9. - Authorized hours. 
    In addition to the hours of operation made unlawful by the provisions of section 28-3 A-25 of the Code of Alabama 1975, it shall be unlawful for any person, whether a liquor, wine, or beer licensee or not, to sell, offer for sale or to serve or dispense for offer or reward, or to offer to serve or dispense for reward any liquor, wine, or beer for on premises consumption or off premises consumption, or to allow the consumption of any alcoholic beverages on the licensed premises between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday or Saturday of any week, or between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. (noon) on Sunday of any week; however, it shall be lawful for a duly licensed club retail liquor licensee to conduct such above described activities without limitation as to the hours of operation. 
(Ord. No. 84-2412, § 14, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 92-3106, § 4, 11-2-92; Ord. No. 98-3460, § 7, 7-6-98; Ord. No. 10-4026, § 1, 4-20-10; Ord. No. 10-4029, § 1, 5-3-10) 
Sec. 2.5-10. - Regulation of conduct in clubs, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, club, firm or corporation or the officers, members, agents, servants or persons in charge thereof at any club or at any other place to which the public generally resorts or is admitted, which is a liquor, wine or beer licensed place, or any combination thereof, to permit, allow, conduct or condone any of the following: 
(1)  Topless or bottomless waitresses, dancers or performers, or any lewd or indecent conduct. 
(2)  Acts, or simulated acts, of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law. 
(3)  Acts, or simulated acts, of caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals. 
(4)  Acts involving the displaying of the anus, vulva or genitals. 
(5)  Permitting any patron, customer or member to touch, caress or fondle the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals, or any part of the body or clothing of a performer. 
(6)  Permitting the showing of films, still pictures, electronic reproductions or other visual reproductions depicting: 
a.  Acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law. 
b.  Any person being touched, caressed or fondled on the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals. 
c.  Scenes wherein a person displays the vulva or the anus or the genitals. 
d.  Scenes wherein artificial devices or inanimate objects are employed to depict, or drawings are employed to portray, any of the prohibited activities described above in this section. 
(7)  Any waiter, waitress, dancer, entertainer or model employed upon the licensed premises to sit at tables with the customers or members and guests while so employed and during the time that said establishment is open for business. 
(8)  Any person at the time employed or engaged on the licensed premises as an entertainer, to also serve as a waiter or waitress while so employed. 
(9)  The showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering, or the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any portion thereof below the top of the darkened area surrounding the nipple, or the depiction of covered male genitals in a lewd or indecent manner by any waiter, waitress, dancer, entertainer, employee, model or customer. 
(Ord. No. 84-2412, § 15, 2-4-85) 
Sec. 2.5-11. - Records; reports. 
    It shall be the duty of each person subject to the license tax imposed by this chapter to keep full and complete records of all purchases, sales and deliveries of alcoholic beverages, from which records there can be readily obtained information as to the correct amount of license tax due the city. As a part of such records, each wholesaler shall keep an individual ledger or card account for each of his customers, and said ledger or card account shall show the correct name and address of each person to whom any alcoholic beverages are delivered, together with the dates thereof and the number of cases sold or delivered, and each wholesaler shall also keep, as evidence of the foregoing, a receipted delivery ticket signed by each purchaser or by his authorized agent. Each retailer shall keep an individual ledger or card record showing the correct name and address of each person from whom he purchased alcoholic beverages, a delivery ticket showing each such purchase, the date thereof and the number of cases purchased. The aforesaid records shall be kept posted currently and shall be preserved for not less than three (3) years succeeding said calendar year. All of such records shall be open for inspection and audit at the licensed premises within the city during such regular business hours as the revenue department, or its duly authorized representative, may request. Failure to keep any of the records required by this section, or elsewhere in this chapter, or by any amendment thereto, or refusal to make the same available to the revenue department, or its duly authorized representative, shall constitute grounds for revocation of any license issued under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 84-2412, § 18, 2-4-85; Ord. No. 98-3460, § 8, 7-6-98) 
Sec. 2.5-12. - Packaging of beverages. 
    Retail licensees for off-premise sales of alcoholic beverages must place each container thereof in a bag, box or other similar opaque covering prior to the customer's leaving the licensee's building used for beverage sales. 
(Ord. No. 84-2412, § 20, 2-4-85) 
Sec. 2.5-13. - Overnight operation.
