(b)  In order to lessen congestion caused by emergency vehicles and to provide for the safety of pedestrians and vehicles on the public streets, to facilitate the prompt and coordinated dispatch of emergency transport vehicles when needed to protect life, safety and health, and to further preserve and promote the health, safety and welfare of its citizens, the city designates the Decatur fire and rescue department as the basic life support/advanced life support primary responder for all 911 calls within the corporate limits of the city and establishes the following procedures, rules and regulations for private ambulances and municipal emergency vehicles in the city as set out herein. 
(c)  This chapter shall be known as the emergency medical treatment and transportation service ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words, terms, phrases and their derivations shall have the meanings respectively ascribed thereto by this section: 
    Advance life support (ALS). Prehospital patient care and transport involving any procedure the Alabama Department of Public Health has, by rule and regulation, recognized as being within the scope of practice of an EMT intermediate or paramedic. 
    ALS/BLS transport vehicle. 
(1)  ALS transport vehicle. Any motor vehicle constructed, reconstructed, arranged, equipped or used for the purpose of transporting individuals with life threatening medical conditions. 
(2)  BLS transport vehicle. Any motor vehicle constructed, reconstructed, arranged, equipped or used for the purpose of transporting individuals with non-life-threatening medical conditions. 
    Ambulance. A vehicle equipped and used for the purpose of transporting the wounded, injured or sick, and shall include but is not restricted to emergency vehicles used for such purposes. 
    Ambulance call. The act of responding with a licensed ALS transport vehicle and/or ambulance for the purpose of transporting any patient for compensation. 
(1)  Emergency response. A response in which it is believed that illness, injury or disability requires immediate medical services wherein delay of such services may endanger personal health or safety. This call shall be accomplished with use of all warning devices and lights. 
(2)  Non-emergency response. A response that does not require the use of warning devices, including but not limited to; interhospital transfers, discharges to home, visits to physicians offices and the transport of deceased patients to the funeral home. 
    Ambulance EMT. Any person licensed as an EMT by the Alabama Committee of Public Health who, for compensation, has the duty of performing or assisting in the performance of an ambulance call. 
    Basic life support. The prehospital patient care and transportation of a patient by an EMS provider wherein the patient is treated by procedures recognized by the Alabama Committee of Public Health as being within the scope of practice of a basic EMT. 
    North Alabama Emergency Medical Services (NAEMS). The regional EMS organization as recognized by state law and contract with the Alabama Department of Public Health to perform regional EMS functions. 
    City. All areas within the corporate limits and the police jurisdiction of the City of Decatur, Alabama. 
    City council (council). The city council of the City of Decatur, Alabama. 
    Driver. Any person who, for compensation, drives or attempts to drive any ambulance and who is responsible for the safe transport of the patient and other attending EMT(s). This person must have met all requirements set forth by the Alabama Committee of Public Health for ambulance drivers. 
    Emergency. Any nonhospital occurrence or situation involving illness, injury or disability requiring immediate prehospital intervention, wherein delay in the provision of such services is likely to aggravate the condition and endanger personal/health or safety. 
    Emergency medical services (EMS). Those prehospital functions and services which are required to prepare for and respond to emergencies, including rescue, transportation, treatment, triage, communications, evaluation and public education. 
    Emergency medical services (EMS) committee. A committee established by the city council to provide recommendations for improving the city's prehospital EMS delivery system and to investigate, study, advise and recommend minimum standards of care for emergency victims including mass casualty incidents and other responsibilities as provided herein. 
    Emergency medical services (EMS) dispatch center. The central communications center of Decatur fire and rescue from which all EMS/E-911 dispatches originate. 
    Emergency medical technician (EMT) shall be known as any one of the following: 
(1)  Basic (EMT-B). An individual who the Alabama Board of Public Health licenses to provide prehospital care such as cardiopulmonary resuscitation, fracture splinting, and bandaging of wounds and other such procedures as the board recognizes. 
(2)  Intermediate (EMT-1). An individual who the Alabama Board of Public Health licenses to provide prehospital care which can be invasive such as the starting of IVs the monitoring of cardiac rhythms, and intubation and other such procedures as the board recognizes. 
(3)  Paramedic (EMT-P). An individual who the Alabama Board of Public Health licenses to provide invasive prehospital care such as endotracheal intubation, drug administration, and other measures and procedures as the board recognizes. 
    Enhanced basic life support services. Those services which are made available through the use of an EMT-D to deliver rapid defibrillation. 
    Fire chief. The chief of the fire and rescue department of the city or his duly authorized representative. 
    Fire and rescue service department. The fire and rescue department of the city. 
    Firemedic. An EMT-P/firefighter employed by the fire and rescue department. 
    Firemedic BLS/ALS vehicle. Any prehospital EMS transport or nontransport unit operated by the fire and rescue department that meets criteria for basic life support and/or advanced life support. 
    Interfacility emergency ALS transfer. The transfer of a patient requiring EMT paramedic or EMT intermediate level of care, where more advanced procedures are to be performed such as the monitoring of IVs or drugs, from one healthcare facility to another. 
    Medical control physician. A physician licensed to practice in the state, knowledgeable in the ADPH approved ALS protocols, standard EMS radio procedures and general operating policies of the fire and rescue department and the Alabama Department of Public Health and from whom prehospital EMS providers shall take medical direction in person, by radio, or by remote communications device subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
    Medical direction. 
(1)  On-line. Direction given prehospital EMS personnel by an ADPH approved on-line medical control physician at a regionally designated medical control facility through direct voice contact, or by ADPH approved ALS protocol. 
(2)  Off-line. A physician licensed to practice in the state who practices medicine in the city and is approved by the city's EMS committee to serve as the off-line medical control physician for a prehospital EMS provider. The off-line medical control physician will serve as medical liaison and advocate for the EMS provider and assist with retrospective review of prehospital patient care procedures. 
    Medical protocol. A series of written statements of standard procedure, promulgated by the medical control and accountability committee, a standing committee appointed by the state committee of public health which is a part of the approved NAEMS medical control accountability plan (MCAP). 
    Medical review. The periodic review of prehospital patient care reports and other data by the off-line medical control physician for quality assurance purposes. 
    Mutual aid ambulance call. Request for emergency ambulance service issued by an ambulance dispatcher in one political jurisdiction to an ambulance dispatcher or ambulance crew in a neighboring political jurisdiction. 
    Owner. A person engaged in business as the owner, manager, officer or proprietor of a company, firm or organization providing private ambulance service within the city. 
    Patient. Any individual who is sick, injured, or wounded and in need of emergency medical care and transportation. 
    Patient transport. 
(1)  Category I - Emergency. Patients whose conditions are life threatening or will likely cause serious permanent physical impairment if not treated immediately and transported by ALS transport vehicle. 
(2)  Category II - Urgent. Patients whose conditions would not cause loss of life or serious permanent and physical impairment if treatment is deferred or delayed but whose condition is such that transportation to a medical facility is warranted and transported by ALS transport vehicle. 
(3)  Category III - Non-emergency. Individuals with minor medical conditions where the time to treatment is not a critical factor and whose condition is such that transportation may be provided by BLS transport vehicle or other alternative forms of transportation. 
(4)  Category IV - Deceased on scene. Patients who have been found to be expired or rendered deceased on the scene for which attempts at resuscitation are negated. Transport of the deceased will be in accordance with the Morgan County coroner's office policy. 
    Person. Any individual, partnership, firm or corporation of any kind. 
    Physician advisor. The licensed physician appointed by the fire and rescue department to serve as its medical advisor and other members of the emergency medical services system. 
    Police chief. The chief of the police department of the city or his duly authorized representative. 
    Private ambulance. Any motor vehicle meeting the criteria designated by this chapter for ambulances or other prehospital emergency transport or nontransport vehicles owned and operated by a person or corporation doing business within the city. 
    The state medical control and accountability committee. The committee appointed by the state committee of public health for the purpose of regulating emergency medical services in the state. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-3. - Firemedic BLS/ALS service. 
    The firemedic BLS/ALS vehicles of the fire and rescue department shall be the primary responder to all E-911 calls of an emergency medical nature. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-4. - Duty of the fire chief. 
    It shall be the duty and responsibility of the fire chief to administer the provisions of this chapter pursuant to the prehospital EMS delivery system as stated in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-5. - Use of emergency warning devices. 
(a)  All private ambulances responding to emergency calls outside the city shall notify the fire dispatcher or 911 operator to travel and operate ambulances with warning devices upon city streets. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a private ambulance responding to an apparent non-emergency call to proceed to the hospital or other destination with the use of emergency warning equipment upon the city streets. 
(c)  Emergency warning equipment shall not be used without prior notification of the fire dispatcher and shall not be used except where serious medical conditions exists, such as in the case of category I or II patients. 
(d)  No notification shall be necessary for patients being transported from a point of pick-up to a physician's office, clinic, nursing home, funeral home or morgue, however, emergency warning equipment is not authorized and is illegal for such transports. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-6. - Obedience to traffic laws, ordinances or regulations. 
    When the driver of any ambulance has been authorized to utilize lights and sirens in accordance with the provisions of this chapter he/she may: 
(1)  Stop, stand or park the ambulance in any place in order to provide medical services irrespective of the otherwise applicable provisions of law, ordinance or regulations. 
(2)  Proceed with warning devices operating past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after stopping as necessary for safe operation. 
(3)  Exceed the maximum speed limits permitted by law, ordinance or regulation; provided, however, that any governing directives issued by the city's chief of police are obeyed and that life and property are not endangered thereby. 
(4)  While operating warning devices, disregard operating laws, ordinances and regulations governing directions or movements or turning in specified directions. 
(5)  The exemptions herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle shall apply only when such vehicle is making use of an audible signal meeting the requirements of section 32-5-213, Code of Alabama 1975 and visual requirements of any laws of this state requiring visual signals on emergency vehicles. 
(6)  The foregoing provisions shall not relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-7. - Disposition of the deceased. 
(a)  Transport of individuals that are obviously dead, where the death is not of a suspicious nature and not under investigation by any law enforcement agency, shall be the responsibility of the family of the deceased. Arrangements may be made with a private ambulance service or funeral home for transport. Where family of the deceased cannot be located the transport of the body shall be coordinated with the Morgan County coroner's office. 
(b)  Transport of deceased individuals where the deaths are being investigated by a local law enforcement agency shall be the responsibility of that agency. 
(c)  Under no circumstances shall a firemedic BLS/ALS vehicle be used to transport bodies of deceased individuals. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-8. - Unlawful or prohibited acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally or knowingly: 
(1)  Follow any police car or fire apparatus which is traveling in response to an emergency call on the streets of the city or to follow any ambulance to or near the scene of an emergency call on the streets of the city unless said vehicle is authorized to respond to said emergency. 
(2)  Solicit on the streets of the city the business of transporting injured or sick persons; provided that this prohibition shall not be construed to prohibit lawful advertisements. 
(3)  Intercept any communication concerning traffic accidents on the streets of the city and divulge or publish the existence, contents, substance, purpose, effect or meaning of such intercepted communication and no such solicitor, owner or person, not being entitled thereto, shall receive or assist in receiving any such message emanating through the radio medium of the police or fire and rescue department for his own benefit or for the benefit of another solicitor, owner or person in the business of furnishing ambulance service. 
(4)  Use a uniform, insignia, badge, title, identification card, or vehicle marking that so closely resembles or mimics those of the fire and rescue or police department as to confuse the public. 
(5)  Request the services of any ambulance which is not licensed or permitted or exempted therefrom in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(6)  No person shall make or cause another to make a request for ambulance service or assistance unless that person has some cause to believe that a medical need exists. It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section if a person requests or causes another to request ambulance service and then fails to seek medical examination or treatment. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-9. - Complaint procedure. 
(a)  Any person having a complaint regarding service and/or charges shall first notify the owner/manager of the ambulance service in question. The owner/manager of the ambulance service shall notify the fire chief in writing as to the complaint within twenty (20) days following the date that a written complaint was filed with the EMS provider. If a complaint is not resolved to the satisfaction of both parties, either may submit a written request to the EMS committee for further review. Upon receipt of such written request, the EMS committee or an appointed subcommittee shall hold a hearing on such complaint within thirty (30) days. The EMS committee or subcommittee shall make a written report within seven (7) days to the city council, police chief, fire chief, complainant and ambulance service, stating their findings. 
(b)  The ambulance company and fire chief shall keep a record of all complaints and how each is resolved for the preceding twenty-four-month period. 
(c)  Complaints which constitute either: (1) A potential violation of state EMS rules and regulations or (2) Patient care procedures reported to have compromised acceptable standards of care established by the state medical control and accountability committee shall be reviewed by the city's EMS committee, in concert with the provider's off-line medical control physician, and forwarded to the North Alabama EMS Regional Agency for further examination. All information, documentation and other materials determined to be pertinent to the incidents in question shall be forwarded to the North Alabama EMS Agency. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-10. - Promulgation of addition standards and regulations. 
(a)  The fire chief is hereby authorized to establish, with the concurrence of the emergency medical services committee, additional standards and regulations for the operation of ambulances by permit holders not in conflict with any provisions of this chapter. Such standards and regulation shall include and set forth the procedures to be followed in processing and handling complaints against permit holders made to the city and may clarify any provision of this chapter which is deemed ineffective and may establish any procedure necessary to the accomplishment of the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Such standards and regulations shall be established in accordance with subsection (a) of this section shall be mailed to all permit holders hereunder and such standards and regulations shall become effective thirty (30) days thereafter. 
(c)  The standards and regulations, or any part thereof, as provided herein, may be revoked at anytime by appropriate action of the council. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
ARTICLE II. - CERTIFICATES OF PUBLIC NECESSITY AND CONVENIENCE 

Sec. 3-11. - Certificate of public necessity and convenience, permits, licenses and insurance required; nontransferable; exemption. 
(a)  No ambulance service for hire, except those ambulance services for hire lawfully conducting business in the city on the effective date of this chapter, shall operate on any street of the city without the owner having first been issued a certificate (CPNC) declaring that the public convenience and necessity require such an operation. 
(b)  No ambulance for hire shall operate on any street of the city without having first been issued an annual ambulance vehicle permit from the city clerk, an annual business license from the city clerk and current and valid insurance as provided herein. The annual permit cannot be transferred from one vehicle to another. 
(c)  All CPNC'S, licenses and permits, which are issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, are nontransferable. Any change or transfer of ownership shall terminate such CPNC'S, licenses and permits and shall require a new application in conformance with all the requirements of this chapter as upon an original application. 
(d)  Decatur fire and rescue BLS/ALS vehicle operations shall be exempt from all CPNC'S, permits, business licenses and fees required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-12. - CPNC requirement exceptions. 
    No certificate of public necessity and convenience (CPNC) shall be required for any person operating an emergency ambulance or other vehicle under the following conditions: 
(1)  Rendering assistance during any catastrophe or major emergency when the ambulances authorized to operate in the city by CPNC are either insufficient in number or inadequate for any other reason as determined by the fire chief or EMS dispatch center; 
(2)  Operating an ambulance brought in to the city solely for the purpose of a drill or training exercise; 
(3)  Operating any ambulance rendering requested assistance currently authorized by the city in cases of disaster or major emergency. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-13. - Application for certificate of public necessity and convenience. 
    Applications for a certificate of public necessity and convenience for the operation of an ambulance within the city shall be in writing, signed and sworn to by the applicant, and shall be filed with the city clerk on such forms as prepared by the fire chief and shall contain at least the following information: 
(1)  The trade name under which the applicant does or proposes to do business; if the applicant is an individual, the name, age and address of the applicant and the length of the time the applicant has resided in the city; or if a partnership or association, the business name thereof and the name, age and address of each partner and the length of time each partner has resided in the city; or if a corporation, the names and addresses of all officers and the directors of such corporation, and length of existence of the corporation. 
(2)  The number of vehicles the applicant desires to operate and the class, size, design and color scheme, insignia, name, monogram or other distinguishing characteristics to be used to designate the applicant's vehicle and a list of equipment to be carried on board each said vehicle. 
(3)  Whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of any federal or state crime, or a violation of any city ordinance. The disposition of same and place of conviction. 
(4)  Whether or not the applicant, his associates or employees have any claims or judgments against them for damages resulting from the negligent operation of an ambulance, or any other vehicle, the disposition of same and place of claim or judgment. 
(5)  The financial ability of the applicant to comply with the provisions of this chapter, to include, but not limited to, a copy of the most recent audited financial statements of the corporation petitioning the city for a CPNC. 
(6)  A two-year business plan or market share analysis providing substantial evidence of the applicant's capacity to ensure appropriate service to the city. At a minimum the applicant will provide: (1) The number and location (i.e., physical address) of the transport units scheduled to be placed in service, (2) Coverage area(s) identified by political subdivision or geographically defined on a station-by-station basis, (3) Projected call volume by level of service (i.e., non-emergency transfer, 911, inter-facility transfer, etc.), (4) Existing formal agreements with volunteer rapid responder units operating outside the fire and police jurisdictions of the city, (5) Current contractual agreements with healthcare providers, major employers, payers or other entities which may affect the candidates ability to provide uninterrupted prehospital patient care. 
(7)  Documentation from the applicant's insurance carrier, stating that the insurance required hereunder is available to the applicant and that such coverage is or will be provided prior to the issuance of the CPNC to operate hereunder. 
(8)  The training, experience and credentials of the applicant and any employees of the applicant in the transportation and care of patients. 
(9)  The location and description of the place or places from which the applicant intends to operate. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-14. - Investigation of applications. 
(a)  The fire chief and chief of police shall investigate the facts set out in the application and report in writing to the council within thirty (30) days of receipt thereof the results of their investigation as follows: 
(1)  Their findings as to the truth or falsity of the facts set out in the application. 
(2)  Whether or not each such ambulance, its required equipment and the premises designed in the application meet the requirements of this chapter and other applicable laws, ordinances and regulations. 
(3)  Any facts, which may bear upon the question of whether or not the applicant is a responsible and proper person to conduct, carry on or engage in the proposed business. 
(4)  Whether or not the requirements of this chapter and all other applicable laws and ordinances relating to the application have been met. 
(b)  The city clerk shall refer a copy of the application to the emergency medical services committee. The EMS committee shall consider such application and report thereon to the council within thirty (30) days. The committee shall advise the council of any facts of which it has knowledge that are relevant to the consideration of the CPNC application. The committee shall advise the council if the area to be served is in need of additional ambulance service based upon consideration of response times, projected revenue, level of care, level of staffing, level of equipment, as well as the overall effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed service considering any existing CPNC'S. Any existing holders of CPNC's may present material to the committee concerning the advisability of the application with specific emphasis on; change in response time, level of care, level of service, level of equipment, and efficiency of the area to be served by the new provider and the city as a whole. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-15. - Public hearings upon the public convenience and necessity of issuing such certificate. 
    Upon receipt of all reports provided for herein, the council shall set a date for a public hearing on such application to be held within thirty (30) days after receipt of such reports. The city clerk shall notify the applicant of the time and place of said hearing and shall cause notice of such public hearing to be given by publishing said notice once in a newspaper of general circulation within the city at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for such hearing. The purpose of such public hearing shall be to consider, among other things, the following: 
(1)  Reports from the police department, fire and rescue service department and the emergency medical services committee. 
(2)  Whether or not the public convenience and necessity require the operation of such ambulance or ambulances; 
(3)  Whether the applicant will be able to provide ambulance service of such permanence and quality as to best serve the public interest; 
(4)  The experience that the applicant has had in rendering ambulance service; 
(5)  The past experience of the applicant in satisfying judgments, if any, to claimants as a result of injuries received by reason of negligent operation of the ambulance; 
(6)  The financial ability of the applicant to respond to damages to property resulting from the negligent operation of an ambulance; 
(7)  The character and condition of the ambulance(s) and capabilities of listed EMT personnel to be used by the proposed prehospital provider. 
    In the event the city council finds that the public convenience and necessity require the issuance of such a certificate and that the applicant meets the required qualifications and will be able to give proper and adequate service in the best interest of the inhabitants of the city, the city clerk shall issue a certificate of public necessity and convenience (CPNC) to the applicant which shall state any restrictions mandated by the city council, including, but not limited to, time of operations and number of authorized ambulances. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-16. - Form, contents, and issuance of CPNC. 
(a)  Every CPNC issued hereunder shall be signed by the city clerk and shall contain, in addition to the name and address of the applicant, the number of vehicles authorized to be operated pursuant to such CPNC along with any time limits which may be applicable. 
(b)  A copy of every CPNC issued shall be filed with and maintained by the fire and rescue department and the city clerk's office. 
(c)  Every certificate holder shall post their CPNC prominently in the central place of business as provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-17. - Causes of alteration, suspension or revocation of CPNC or ambulance permit. 
(a)  Every CPNC or ambulance permit issued hereunder shall be subject to alteration, suspension or revocation by the city for failure to comply or maintain compliance with this chapter or if any of the following conditions should occur: 
(1)  The public convenience and necessity no longer warrant such operation. 
(2)  The owner or his agent has refused to render the full service authorized by the CPNC. 
(3)  The owner or his agent has been convicted of a crime which directly relates to the duties and responsibilities of the ambulance operation. 
(4)  The CPNC was obtained by an application in which any material fact was intentionally omitted or falsely stated. 
(5)  The owner or his agent has failed to ensure the ambulance service is in constant compliance with the operating regulations set forth herein or has persisted in permitting the ambulances operating on behalf of his ambulance service to be operated in violation of federal or state law or municipal ordinance. 
(6)  The owner or his agent has willfully and knowingly violated or failed to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(7)  The owner or his agent has, without good cause, induced or sought to induce a change of designation to or from a hospital or other place specified by the person hiring the ambulance. 
(8)  The owner or his agent has allowed the ambulance service to be operated in a negligent manner. 
(9)  The insurance coverage required herein has been cancelled, reduced, withdrawn, suspended or terminated. 
(10)  The owner or his agent has allowed any of the vehicles operating on behalf of his ambulance service or any of the equipment carried thereon to become damaged, deteriorated or unclean to the extent that they are unsatisfactory for public use. 
(11)  The owner fails to maintain the financial ability to comply with the terms of this chapter. 
(12)  The owner or his agent has failed to comply with the terms and limitations imposed by the city council in the CPNC. 
(13)  The owner or his agent has failed to comply with the applicable federal, state or local laws or regulations. 
(b)  The EMS coordinator, appropriately designated by the fire chief pursuant to § 3-38(b), shall be responsible for monitoring the activities and operation of each ambulance service duly authorized and licensed by the city. Should he find that any CPNC holder has failed to comply or maintain compliance with this chapter or should he find that any of the above-listed conditions have occurred, he shall immediately take action pursuant to the procedures outlined in § 3-18, infra. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98; Ord. No. 09-3981, § 1, 6-1-09) 
Sec. 3-18. - Procedure for alteration, suspension or revocation of CPNC or ambulance permit. 
(a)  Should the EMS coordinator determine that a CPNC holder has refused, failed or has become unable to perform according to the requirements of this chapter for any reason, he shall provide written notice to the owner of record of the offending ambulance service, detailing each requirement not being satisfied. Transmission of said notice shall be effectuated by use of certified mail or other delivery service requiring a signature precedent to receipt. A copy of such notice shall be filed with the city clerk and a copy shall be transmitted to each member of the EMS committee. 
(b)  Within five (5) business days of receipt of the notice, the owner shall contact the EMS coordinator to establish a mutually agreeable time and place to discuss the notice, such meeting to occur within fifteen (15) days of the owner's receipt of said notice. If a mutually agreeable resolution is capable of being reached, the EMS coordinator and the owner shall then establish a timeline for implementing the provisions of said resolution and bringing the service back into compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Such resolution and timeline must be in writing and signed by the EMS coordinator and by the owner of the subject ambulance service. A copy of the documentation shall be retained by the EMS coordinator and the owner and the original shall be delivered to the city clerk. A copy of the same shall also be transmitted to each member of the EMS committee. 
(c)  If the owner fails to contact the EMS coordinator within the allotted time or if a mutually agreeable resolution is not reached or, if at the end of the time allotted for completion of redress, the terms of the agreed-upon resolution and timeline are not being met, the EMS coordinator is authorized to forward the matter to the EMS committee with a recommendation for alteration, suspension or revocation of the CPNC and/or ambulance permits issued for the subject ambulance service. The EMS coordinator shall file a copy of such recommendation with the city clerk and shall serve a copy of the same on the ambulance service. Transmission of said notice shall be effectuated by use of certified mail or other delivery service requiring a signature precedent to receipt. 
(d)  Within ten (10) business days of the recommendation being filed with the city clerk, the EMS committee shall conduct a hearing regarding the EMS coordinator's recommendation. The committee shall provide the ambulance service at least three (3) days' notice of the date, time and place of such hearing. During the hearing, the ambulance service and the EMS coordinator shall be afforded equal opportunities to address the committee regarding the alleged failures and any attempts at resolution. 
(e)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the EMS committee shall decide if the EMS coordinator's recommendation for alteration, suspension or revocation is due to be adopted and forwarded to the city council or if other means of redress are in order to ensure the ambulance service's compliance with the minimum standards of care established in this chapter. 
(f)  In the event the EMS committee determines that means of redress other than alteration, suspension or revocation are due to be imposed on the ambulance service, such decision and the specific terms thereof shall be reduced to writing and forwarded to the city clerk and the owner of the ambulance service within three (3) days of the conclusion of the hearing. Additionally, the item shall be automatically placed on the next regular agenda of the EMS committee for purposes of monitoring the ambulance service's compliance. 
(g)  In the event the committee determines that the CPNC and/or ambulance permits for the ambulance service are due to be altered, suspended or revoked, such decision shall be reduced to writing and forwarded to the city clerk and the owner of the ambulance service within three (3) days of the conclusion of the hearing. The clerk shall then place this recommendation on the next available council agenda for hearing and shall notify the certificate holder of the time and place of the same. 
(h)  At the conclusion of the council's hearing, the body shall decide whether or not the CPNC and/or ambulance permits held by the ambulance service are due to be altered, suspended or revoked and the city clerk shall provide written notice to the ambulance service of the same via certified mail or personal service. 
(1)  Upon issuance by the council and receipt by the owner of notice of alteration, the ambulance service shall immediately cease operations under the former CPNC and/or permits and immediately shall begin operating under the altered and amended version(s) thereof. 
(2)  Upon issuance by the council and receipt by the owner of notification of suspension, the ambulance service shall immediately suspend operation until further notification from the city council or its authorized designee. 
(3)  Upon issuance by the council and receipt by the owner of notification of revocation, the ambulance service shall immediately cease operation. 
(4)  Each day the ambulance service operates in contravention of the council's decision shall constitute a separate violation of this chapter. 
(5)  In the event the council decides that no action is due to be taken regarding the CPNC and/or ambulance permits held by the ambulance service, such decision shall be reduced to writing and provided to the owner in the manner prescribed above. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98; Ord. No. 09-3981, § 2, 6-1-09) 
Sec. 3-19. - Suspension or revocation of sole provider; committee's responsibility to council. 
    In the event the city is served by a sole provider of ambulance services and such provider has its CPNC and/or permits suspended or revoked by the council, the EMS committee shall convene within twenty-four (24) hours of the issuance of the council's decision to formulate an alternative means of providing coverage for the city. Such plan shall be reduced to writing and forthwith transmitted to the council for their immediate consideration. 
(Ord. No. 09-3981, § 3, 6-1-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-3981, § 3, adopted June 1, 2009, amended the Code by, in effect, repealing former § 3-19 and adding a new § 3-19. Former § 3-19 pertained to certificate holder's records and reports, and derived from Ord. No. 98-3471, adopted August 3, 1998. 
ARTICLE III. - PRIVATE AMBULANCE SERVICE GENERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 3-20. - Private ambulance. 
(a)  Private ambulance services within the city shall have the following ALS/emergency duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  Inter-facility transfer of medically stable patients that require an EMT intermediate or EMT paramedic to monitor fluids, EKG rhythms or administer medications. 
(2)  During routine non-emergency transport, patients who develop conditions that require an emergency transport, fire and rescue dispatch shall be notified. 
(3)  Continuation of ALS instituted outside the city limits to a facility inside the city. 
(4)  Inter-facility transport of emergency ALS patients. 
(5)  Transportation of ALS patients to facilities outside of the city. 
(6)  a.  Provide a minimum of one (1) paramedic and (1) EMT assigned to each responding ambulance that shall respond to patients determined to be category I or II in nature as defined by the fire and rescue dispatch center EMD triage guide. 
b.  Provide a minimum of two (2) EMT basics assigned to each responding ambulance that shall respond to patients determined to be category III or IV in nature as defined by the fire and rescue dispatch center ENM triage guide. 
(b)  In order to provide maximum BLS/ALS medical coverage for the citizens of the city, the fire and rescue service department shall transfer the request of individuals who require non-emergency ambulance transport to a private ambulance company which the city has authorized through a CPNC permit. 
(c)  (1) Private ambulance service shall be responsible for the billing and collection of fees from privately transported individuals. The city will not compensate private ambulance services for private ambulance transportation services rendered. 
(2)  If a firemedic BLS/ALS vehicle responds to a patient and determines the patients category to be a category II or III and, therefore, ALS transport is not necessary, the individual will be appropriately advised in accordance with fire and rescue service department policies, medical protocols and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-21. - Central place of business. 
    Each private ambulance service owner shall maintain a central place of business with at least one properly listed telephone for receiving all calls for ambulance service, where all business records and daily manifests herein required shall be maintained and available upon request of the fire chief. Each owner shall, in writing, immediately notify the fire chief of any change of the business address or of the telephone number where said owner may be contacted at all times. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-22. - Authority of fire chief to designate equipment. 
    The fire chief is hereby authorized to maintain a "list of equipment to be on board any ambulance operating in the city". This list shall reflect the minimum equipment as required by the state. This list shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and in the office of the fire chief. In the event additional equipment becomes available, the EMS committee will investigate the equipment to see if there is justification for adding the equipment to the required list of equipment to be on board each ambulance. Any equipment deemed necessary will be recommended by the EMS committee to the city council for addition to the "list of equipment to be on board any ambulance operating in the city." The city council shall have final approval for any additions, deletions or modifications. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-23. - Equipment required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any ambulance within the city when responding to a patient transport, which is not equipped with all of the equipment enumerated in the above described list which equipment shall be in satisfactory working condition. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-24. - Equipment changes, objections, adoption. 
(a)  The EMS committee, upon making a determination based on procedures and equipment approved and/or adopted by the state EMS medical control and accountability committee and NA-EMS that changes are necessary to the "list of equipment required to be on board any ambulance operating in the city", shall notify the city council by submitting a list detailing the proposed changes and the effective date of implementation of such changes, which date shall be a minimum of thirty (30) days subsequent to the date of said notice. Such notice shall also be sent to all ambulance companies operating in the city as of the date the proposed changes are submitted. 
(b)  Any person, entity, or ambulance company objecting to any proposed change shall notify the fire chief and city clerk in writing detailing such complaint at least fourteen (14) days prior to the effective date of implementation as stated in the notice. Any such items objected to shall be set for council hearing prior to the effective date of implementation. If no written objections are made fourteen (14) days prior to the scheduled implementation date such changes shall forthwith take effect upon approval of the council. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-25. - Inspection of equipment. 
(a)  All mechanical, safety and special equipment shall be subject to inspection at any time by the police department and/or fire and rescue department. 
(b)  Prior to the issuance of any CPNC and annually thereafter the holder of the CPNC shall submit a safety and soundness inspection report including affidavits from the owner and the inspecting mechanic that each vehicle is in sound mechanical condition and is safe for operation on the streets of the city as an emergency vehicle and meets the police department's criteria and all provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to transport a patient in an ambulance or to place such ambulance in service subsequent to an accident involving such vehicle or alteration of such vehicle until the vehicle has been inspected by the chief of police or his/her designee and determined to be in proper operative condition and in compliance with all the requirements of this chapter and a new safety and soundness affidavit submitted as provided herein; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit such an ambulance to continue the transportation of a patient who was being transported at the time of the accident when such can be done safely. 
(d)  The fire chief or his/her designee shall be responsible for the annual inspection of said vehicles to insure that said vehicles are equipped in accordance with this chapter prior to issuance of a permit and at periodic intervals at his/her discretion. The periodic inspection required thereunder shall be in addition to any other safety or motor vehicle inspection to be made for ambulances or other motor vehicles, or other inspections required to be made under general law or ordinance, and shall not excuse compliance with any requirement of law or ordinance to display any official certificate of motor vehicle inspection and approval, nor excuse compliance with the requirements of any other applicable general law or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-26. - Operating regulations. 
(a)  Each owner shall provide twenty-four-hour-per-day, seven-day-per-week ambulance services and shall remain in continuous operation in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Each vehicle utilized by an owner as a private ambulance, as the same is defined in this chapter, shall be of a type I, II, or III as the same is recognized and classified in the emergency care industry. Each vehicle so used shall be introduced into service in good condition and shall be thereafter maintained in good operating condition. Additionally, each vehicle so used shall meet or exceed the federal standards applicable to emergency vehicles at the time of the vehicle's original manufacture, except where such standards conflict with state standards, in which case the state standards shall prevail. At all times while each such vehicle is in service in the city, it shall also meet or exceed all other applicable current standards set forth by the state and the city, including, but not limited to, those standards and regulations relating to equipment and appearance. 
(c)  Each ambulance shall at all times while in use: 
(1)  Be suitable for the transportation of patients from the standpoint of health, sanitation, and safety and be maintained in sanitary condition; 
(2)  Contain adequate safety belts for the driver and a passenger in the front seat and all seating in the patient compartment (head of cot and squad bench), each restraint conforming with the applicable state and federal standards, requirements, and regulations for such equipment and being maintained in proper working order; 
(3)  Comply with all applicable laws, ordinances, and regulations relating to maintenance, health, sanitation, and safety; 
(4)  Be equipped with such lights, sirens, and special markings to properly designate it as an ambulance as may be prescribed by law or in reasonable regulations promulgated by the chief of police; and 
(5)  Be staffed with no less than two (2) emergency medical technicians, each of whom shall be duly and currently licensed and appropriately credentialed by the state. Each ambulance shall be staffed according to the level of response assigned at the time of dispatch: 
a.  Category I or II (as defined by the EMD Triage Guide) call for service: minimum of one (1) EMT-P and (1) EMT-B assigned to each responding ambulance. 
b.  Category III or IV (as defined by the EMD Triage Guide) call for service: minimum of two (2) EMT-B personnel assigned to each responding ambulance. 
(d)  No owner shall permit or allow a person in his employ to perform duties as an EMT without the appropriate and valid license, certification, and credentials as required under this chapter and applicable state laws and regulations. 
(e)  Each owner shall ensure that at least one (1) field supervisor with emergency medical experience is on-duty or on-call at all times to oversee and provide support to field personnel. 
(f)  At least fifty-one (51) percent of the personnel staffing the fleet of any owner's ambulances shall be full-time employees. 
(g)  Each private ambulance owner shall meet the following requirements regarding the dispatching of emergency vehicles for service: 
(1)  Ambulance services shall contract with the EMS dispatch center, as the same is designated by the city, for the dispatch and logging of all calls the service receives, whether the calls are received from the dispatch center or by private call. 
(2)  At all times, ambulance services shall provide and maintain in good operating condition communication equipment compatible with that used by the EMS dispatch center and as specified by Decatur Fire & Rescue. 
(3)  At all times, ambulance services shall provide and maintain in good operating condition an automatic vehicle location system compatible with the equipment used by the EMS dispatch center and as specified by Decatur Fire & Rescue. 
(h)  Any private ambulance service operating in the city shall ensure that every ambulance offered for service in the city meets the following response time requirements, regulations, and standards: 
(1)  Response times shall be calculated from the hour, minute, and second the call is dispatched by the EMS dispatch center to the hour, minute, and second the ambulance service's transport unit arrives on scene. A call is considered "dispatched" at the time of initial radio and/or pager toning as automatically captured via the computer aided dispatch (CAD) system. 
(2)  Response time standards shall be applicable to all category I or II calls. Transport response times will be calculated and monitored separately. Each incident shall be counted as a single response regardless of the number of first responders or ambulances actually utilized and only the first arriving ambulance's time shall be applicable. 
(3)  Based on fractile response time analysis, ninety (90) percent of all category I and category II responses within the city limits of the city shall be achieved within eight (8) minutes or less. 
(4)  Based on fractile response time analysis, ninety (90) percent of all category I and category II responses within the police jurisdiction of the city shall be achieved within twelve (12) minutes or less. 
(5)  Response time exceptions will be considered by the EMS coordinator for good cause only. The burden of establishing good cause for an exception shall rest with the ambulance service, which must have acted in good faith in the execution of its responsibilities. The alleged good cause must have been a substantial factor in producing the excessive response time. Exceptions shall be considered on a case-by-case basis, said consideration being initiated by the service filing a request for each response time exception according to the reporting requirements contained herein. Such request shall list the date, the time, and the specific circumstances causing the delayed response. In the course of evaluating the service's response time exception request, the EMS coordinator shall have the authority to require additional information of the service or any other individual deemed to possess information pertinent to the response in question. 
(i)  Any private ambulance service operating in the city shall meet the following reporting requirements by timely supplying accurate, verifiable documentation to the EMS committee or its designated agent as required below: 
(1)  The following reporting shall be done on a quarterly basis, with the appropriate documentation for the immediately preceding quarter being filed with the city clerk within ten (10) calendar days of the last day of each standard calendar year quarter: 
a.  Number of emergency responses and transports. 
b.  Fractile response time analysis of all category I and category II calls. 
c.  Identification of each emergency call dispatched which did not meet the established response time standard. 
d.  Requests for response time exceptions. 
e.  Equipment and vehicle maintenance reports. 
f.  Equipment failure reports. 
g.  Employment roster (including both full-time and part-time employees in medical and non-medical positions). 
h.  Daily logs, which shall record, at a minimum, the following information for each call received: 
1.  Date and time call received by ambulance service. 
2.  Origin of call and name of individual calling. 
3.  Time of arrival at dispatched location. 
4.  Patient's name and address. 
5.  Disposition of each call. 
i.  Patient billing and account documentation. 
j.  Continuous quality improvement program reports, which shall detail, at a minimum, the following information: 
1.  Continuity of care. 
2.  Quality of care. 
3.  Communications coordination. 
4.  Pre-hospital service coordination. 
5.  Patient care documentation. 
k.  All contracts for service. 
l.  Equipment and supply inventory records. 
m.  A statement of the total number of calls made in the previous calendar year, broken down to indicate those calls in which the points of origin and termination were within the city and those in which either the point of origin or point of termination was outside the city. 
(2)  Any private ambulance service operating in the city shall be responsible for coordinating monthly in-depth, retrospective performance reviews and reporting on the same on a quarterly basis, with the appropriate documentation for the immediately preceding quarter being filed with the city clerk within ten (10) calendar days of the last day of each standard calendar year quarter. Coordination of such reviews shall include, but not be limited to, extending timely invitations to participate to the following entities: 
a.  Decatur Fire & Rescue; 
b.  Morgan County Emergency Management Communication District; 
c.  Decatur General Hospital Emergency Department; 
d.  Parkway Medical Center Emergency Department. 
These monthly reviews and their quarterly reports shall involve a detailed, panoramic analysis of the care provided by all pre-hospital emergency care providers in selected cases and shall evaluate said care according to the elements contained in subsection (i)(1) hereinabove. 
(3)  The following reporting shall be done on an annual basis, with the appropriate documentation being filed with the city clerk on or before March 31 of each year for the calendar year immediately preceding said due date: 
a.  Financial statements, including a detailed listing of all assets and liabilities. 
b.  Conditions and requirements of employment. 
c.  Current OSHA-compliant communicable disease policy, the date of its enactment, method of distribution to personnel, dates of and percentage of employees in attendance for training offered in the prevention of exposure to communicable diseases and in the disposal of medical waste. 
d.  Current critical incident stress management program, date of implementation, method of distribution to personnel, and any other stress mitigation programs or policies being used. 
e.  Current in-house drug screening program for all employees, including, without the usage of any privileged or confidential information, a summary of its implementation and effectiveness during the year. 
f.  Current disaster preparedness plan, including a plan for immediate recall of on-duty and off-duty personnel to staff units during multi-casualty situations, times of peak overload, or declared disaster situations. 
g.  A listing of any legal claims pending at the time of reporting and a listing of any legal claims resolved during the previous calendar year, regardless of the manner of disposition. 
(j)  The city's designated primary responder for all 911 calls within the corporate limits shall meet the following quarterly reporting requirements by supplying accurate, verifiable documentation for the immediately preceding quarter to the EMS committee or its designated agent within ten (10) calendar days of the last day of each standard calendar year quarter: 
(1)  Number of emergency responses. 
(2)  Fractile response time analysis of all category I and category II calls. 
(3)  EMS equipment maintenance reports. 
(4)  EMS equipment failure reports. 
(5)  Daily logs, which shall record, at a minimum, the following information for each call received: 
a.  Date and time call received from dispatch. 
b.  Time of arrival at dispatched location. 
c.  Patient's name and address. 
d.  Disposition of each call. 
(6)  Continuous quality improvement program reports, which shall detail, at a minimum, the following information: 
a.  Continuity of care. 
b.  Quality of care. 
c.  Communications coordination. 
d.  Pre-hospital service coordination. 
e.  Patient care documentation. 
(k)  All documentation used to fulfill the reporting requirements of this section shall be retained by the entity filing the report for at least two (2) years following each filing. However, in the case of patient care reports used to support these requirements, required retention shall be extended to seven (7) years. 
(l)  In the event any due date set forth in this section shall fall on a weekend or on a legal holiday designated by the city in its merit system rules, which are governed by Act No. 324 of the Alabama Legislature (Regular Session, 1965), as amended, the required documentation shall be due the following business day. Documentation submitted in accordance with this provision shall be deemed timely filed. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98; Ord. No. 09-3982, § 1, 6-1-09) 
Sec. 3-27. - Radio dispatcher procedure. 
(a)  In the event an owner receives a private call for ambulance service which is of an emergency nature as defined by the fire and rescue dispatch center EMD triage guide, the provider shall notify, via phone, the fire and rescue service dispatch center within ninety (90) seconds of receipt of the call if the caller and location is within the corporate limits and/or jurisdiction of the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a private ambulance EMT or owner to make an emergency ambulance call on the city streets without having given prior notification, as provided above, to the fire and rescue service department or 911 operator either prior to departure or except as exempted in other sections of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
ARTICLE IV. - INSURANCE 

Sec. 3-28. - Liability insurance required. 
    No permit required by this chapter or business license shall be granted to any person to operate any ambulance upon the streets or elsewhere in the city until such person shall have first filed with the city clerk a personal injury and property damage liability insurance policy issued to such person by a public liability insurance company authorized to do business in the state, providing insurance coverage for each such ambulance or as follows: 
(1)  For each ambulance, such insurance policy shall provide insurance coverage in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for personal injury or death arising from any one accident and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage liability and uninsured motorist's liability coverage in the sum of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) per person for bodily injury liability or five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) combined single limit liability with one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) excess liability coverage whether the operation of any such vehicle is by such person, his agent, servant or employee, or by any person in possession of such vehicle. 
(2)  The insurance coverage required by this section shall at all times be maintained for the full amount. The policy of insurance required by this section to be filed with the city clerk shall contain a clause obligating the company issuing the same to give not less than thirty (30) days written notice to the city clerk before cancellation thereof. Notice of cancellation shall not relieve the company issuing such policy of liability for any injury or claim arising before the cancellation becomes effective. The cancellation of any such policy shall have the effect of suspending the permit of such person to operate the ambulances covered thereby until a new policy complying with the provision of this section is filed with the city clerk. 
(3)  Every insurance policy required hereunder shall contain a provision for a continuing liability thereunder to the full amount thereof, notwithstanding any recovery thereon, that the liability of the insurer shall not be affected by the insolvency or the bankruptcy of the insured, and that until the policy is canceled the insurance company will not be relieved from liability on account of nonpayment of premium, or any act or omission by the name assured. Such policy of insurance shall be further conditioned for the payment of any and all judgments, up to the limits of such policy, recovered against any person other than the owner, his agent or employee who may operate the same with the consent or acquiescence of the owner. 
(4)  In order to meet the policing filing requirements herein, as an alternative, the insured may file a binder of liability and property damage insurance as required here in above and a letter from the insuring agent which shall state that the coverage is bound, the name of the company, the effective date of coverage, the limits of liability and a list of all vehicles covered and proof that said agent has the ability to bind the issuing company. The policy of insurance so bound shall be filed with the city clerk within sixty (60) days of the effective date of coverage. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
ARTICLE V. - RATES AND FEES 

Sec. 3-29. - Rates and fees. 
    Within ninety (90) days upon passage of this chapter the emergency medical services committee of the city shall be formed. The committee shall recommend to the city council a prehospital EMS charge master which shall identify a fee schedule, of reasonable and customary fees, to be used by all EMS providers in possession of a CPNC. Patient charges in excess of the allowable fee schedule or additional charges levied by the provider will be treated as a violation of their CPNC. The committee will submit its recommended fee schedule to the council within one hundred twenty (120) days following the date of its first meeting. To be considered in the development of the EMS charge master will be the following units of service and other functions, which constitute billable charges. 
(1)  Transporting of emergent and non-emergent patients. 
(2)  Mileage charges. 
(3)  Use of oxygen and other ancillary services administered to the patient. 
(4)  Waiting charges. In addition to the charges above, any ambulance required to wait for patients at any hospital, clinic, medical office or nursing home may charge a determined fee set by the committee. The fee shall be broken down in time increments, with a minimum charge provided. No waiting charge can be assessed for standby at any scene of any accident or disaster. 
(5)  Family members. There shall be no charge for any family member or other person accompanying a patient or injured party being transported in an ambulance. 
(6)  Extra patients. When more than one (1) injured or ill person or patient is being transported by an ambulance at the same time, the maximum transportation charge shall be only the allowed billing amount per person. Each patient transported shall be individually liable for only his/her entire transportation charge, and in no case shall a sum in excess of the total maximum billing be collected. 
(7)  Medicare participating provider. Any prehospital EMS provider to which a CPNC has been issued must be a Medicare participating provider and shall be in compliance with all rules, regulations and standards promulgated by the health care financing administration (i.e. HCFA). 
(8)  Mandatory transportation. Any ambulance or ambulance company operating in the city shall transport any and all persons requiring ambulance transportation to any appropriate medical facility, regardless of the persons ability to pay for the service. 
(9)  Refusal to pay for service-Deferred payment plans. No person shall obtain ambulance service or assistance with intent to refuse to pay for same upon demand, and no person after obtaining such service or assistance shall willfully refuse to pay for same on demand unless there exists a bona fide dispute as to the amount owned or unless there is an agreement for credit or deferred payment, provided that, on request of the person obtaining ambulance service and upon presentation of proper identification, a written deferred payment plan shall be offered to that person for his signature, which deferred payment plan shall be on such terms as agreed, provided further that, if no agreement can be reached, then the offered plan shall require no less than four (4) monthly installment payments each approximately one-fourth (1/4) of the total amount. Reasonable proof of financial indigence shall be a defense to any prosecution for violation of this section. 
(10)  False information given to EMT. It shall be unlawful for any person who has obtained ambulance service to willfully fail to give his correct name, social security number, residence address, and date of birth to the ambulance providing service, after having been requested to do so. 
(11)  The EMS committee will review the city's EMS charge master on an as needed basis, but no less than once annually to accommodate adjustments pursuant to new procedures or new technology. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
ARTICLE VI. - PRIVATE AMBULANCE SERVICE VEHICLE PERMIT 

Sec. 3-30. - Permit required for each vehicle. 
(a)  After the owner has secured a CPNC, as provided herein, no vehicle shall be operated under authority of such certificate until the owner has made application to the city clerk for and has been issued a permit for each motor vehicle to be operated under said certificate. Every application for a permit shall be in writing, verified by the owner, and shall show the vehicle identification number, the make, type, year of manufacture, unit number, passenger capacity and exterior color(s) for each motor vehicle for which a permit is requested. No permit shall be issued for the operation of any ambulance, which is unsafe or unfit for the transportation of patients. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to operate an ambulance on any street of the city without first having obtained a permit therefor in accordance with this article or unless exempted therefrom by the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-31. - Annual permit fees. 
    No permit for an ambulance shall be issued or continued in operation unless the holder thereof has paid an annual permit fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each vehicle to be operated within the city. The number of ambulances for which permits are issued shall not exceed the number authorized in the certificate of public necessity and convenience issued pursuant to this chapter. The permits required herein shall be valid for one (1) calendar year, beginning January 1 and ending December 31 of such year, and any owner desiring to continue the operation of any ambulance shall make application for renewal of any and all permits issued hereunder prior to December 1, of any year for the privilege of operating during the following calendar year. The fee shall accompany the application and shall not be refundable. The amount of the permit fees hereunder prescribed shall not be prorated for fractional parts of a calendar year, nor shall it relieve the owner of obtaining any city, state or county occupation licenses or complying with any other requirement established by law. Each permit shall designate a specific ambulance and shall not be transferable nor assignable without the prior written consent of the fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
ARTICLE VII. - PRIVATE AMBULANCE PERSONNEL 

Sec. 3-32. - Ambulance EMT personnel. 
(a)  No ambulance EMT shall drive, manage or control any ambulance on any public street in the city, attend or render any care to any passenger, or otherwise perform duties in any such ambulance for compensation without having been approved and licensed by the state department of public health, EMS division. The fire chief shall be provided a yearly roster of such personnel employed as ambulance personnel. 
(b)  Each EMT shall have conspicuously displayed on their person in the form of a patch or badge their individual level of training. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-33. - Appearance and conduct of EMT's. 
(a)  No EMT shall operate on the streets of the city without wearing a distinctive uniform, which shall have been approved by the fire chief. Each such uniform shirt shall bear a badge or patch on the left shoulder with some identity or trade name of the company appearing thereon. In cold or cool weather, the fire chief may approve for wear by ambulance EMT's a coat or jacket, if requested by the permit holder, to be worn over such shirt. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any owner to permit or allow an EMT to work while not sanitary or not clean or neat in appearance. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any owner to permit an employee, or for any employee of an ambulance to be discourteous, to use vulgar, profane or obscene language, or to be drunk or under the influence of intoxicating beverages or drugs while on duty. 
(d)  Any owner shall notify the fire chief in writing immediately upon becoming aware that any person in his employment is suffering from a reportable communicable disease. Current applicable health standards shall apply is such cases. Such standards as allowed by law shall apply as related to said person's employment capabilities. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
ARTICLE VIII. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES COMMITTEE 

Sec. 3-34. - Created; purpose. 
    There is hereby created the emergency medical services committee (i.e., EMS committee) of the city to provide both administrative oversight of the prehospital EMS delivery system and serve as an advisory body to the city council. The committee shall: (1) Ensure compliance with minimum standards of care, (2) Recommend to the city the issuance of prehospital EMS CPNCS, (3) Hear appeals of the denial, suspension or revocation of prehospital EMS CPNCS, (4) Establish reasonable prehospital EMS fee schedules (i.e., EMS charge master) and (5) Advice the city on issues pursuant to the prehospital EMS delivery system as may be requested by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-35. - Membership. 
    The emergency medical services committee shall consist of eight (8) members to be appointed by the city council as follows: 
(1)  The chief of police or his/her designee. 
(2)  The fire chief or his/her designee. 
(3)  The medical director of the emergency department of Decatur General Hospital. 
(4)  The medical director of the emergency department of Parkway Medical Center. 
(5)  The medical director for the city fire and rescue. 
(6)  The director of the county emergency management agency or his/her designee. 
(7)  The director of the county emergency management communication district. 
(8)  A member recommended at-large by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98; Ord. No. 04-3796, § 1, 3-15-04; Ord. No. 08-3942, § 1, 3-3-08) 
Sec. 3-36. - Officers, subcommittee. 
(a)  The members of the committee shall elect a chairman, a vice-chairman and secretary annually from among their voting membership by a majority vote. 
(b)  The committee may appoint such subcommittees as needed to more efficiently carry out the functions of the committee, with members to be appointed by the chairman. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 2, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-37. - Meeting, quorum. 
(a)  The committee shall meet at least four (4) times a year and as otherwise directed by the chairman. 
(b)  Five (5) members of the committee shall constitute a quorum for any meeting or hearing. 
(c)  The chairman shall constitute part of the quorum, but shall vote only in the event of a tie among the other members present and voting. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98; Ord. No. 08-3942, § 2, 3-3-08) 
Sec. 3-38. - Services to committee. 
(a)  Investigation as needed under this chapter shall be furnished by the chief of police and/or the fire chief. 
(b)  Other assistance to the committee shall be provided by an EMS coordinator designated by the fire chief. 
(1)  The EMS coordinator shall: 
a.  Be properly certified and credentialed as a firefighter; 
b.  Be properly certified and credentialed as a paramedic; 
c.  Have at least five (5) years of experience as a paramedic, two (2) of which must have been spent as a paramedic with Decatur Fire & Rescue; and 
d.  Be an employee in good standing. 
(2)  The fire chief, through the EMS coordinator, shall provide a means of direct communication between the committee and the fire department on issues regarding the fire department's role and participation in the city's pre-hospital EMS delivery system. Additionally, the fire chief, through the EMS coordinator, shall provide oversight of all first responder activity and report to the EMS committee on at least a quarterly basis regarding training, performance, and any other matters pertaining to the emergency medical technicians in the employ of the city. 
(3)  Upon request of the committee, the fire chief, through the EMS coordinator, shall provide advice to the committee regarding the city's pre-hospital EMS delivery system as a whole and any other issues the committee and fire chief deem appropriate. 
(4)  The fire chief, through the EMS coordinator, also shall provide oversight of all ambulance service operation within the city and shall report on the same to the EMS committee on no less than a quarterly basis. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98; Ord. No. 09-3983, § 1, 6-1-09) 
Sec. 3-39. - Compensation. 
    The members of the committee shall serve without compensation unless authorized by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 3-40. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The committee shall have the power to perform all acts necessary to carry out the objectives and purposes set forth in this chapter subject to the general administrative process and procedures controlling departments of the city government. 
(b)  The committee shall adopt rules and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions and findings, which shall be public record. 
(c)  The committee shall act in an advisory capacity to the mayor and council in regard to matters set out in this chapter and such other information as is required from time to time by the city council. 
(d)  The committee shall review all applications for certificates for the public necessity and convenience for private ambulances for hire and shall report its findings and recommendations to the city council as provided by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-3471, § 1, 8-3-98) 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 14; parades, Ch. 17; solid waste, Ch. 19; traffic, Ch. 22; zoning, Ch. 25; disposal of dead animals, § 19-11. 
State Law reference- Animals, Code of Ala. 1975, Title 3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Shelter established; poundmaster's duties; procedure to release impounded animals. 
(a)  There is hereby established at its present location an animal shelter which shall be in the charge of a poundmaster, whose duty shall be to capture and place in such animal shelter any dog or puppy found running at large in violation of the provisions of sections 4-2 and 4-4 of this chapter, and any cat or kitten found running at large off the premises or property of the owner or person in charge of such cat or kitten which is strayed, abandoned, injured, rabid or otherwise considered a threat to the populace or to other animals, or is a nuisance, menace or threat to the safety and well-being of the populace or to other animals, and any such dog, puppy, cat or kitten so captured and placed in such shelter shall be kept not less than forty-eight (48) hours, unless it is redeemed by the owner, nor more than one (1) calendar week, and shall thereafter be humanely destroyed or sold or otherwise done away with. 
(b)  The owner of any impounded dog, puppy, cat or kitten may appear at the animal shelter at any time before such dog, puppy, cat or kitten is humanely destroyed, sold or otherwise done away with, and identify such dog, puppy, cat or kitten and after such identification he shall receive such dog, puppy, cat or kitten from the pound master with a written warning for the first day of boarding plus payment of a ten-dollar boarding fee for each day or fraction thereof that the dog, puppy, cat or kitten is kept. On the second offense that the dog, puppy, cat, or kitten is impounded and any time thereafter it is impounded, the owner before receiving the animal back shall pay the sum of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) redemption fee for the first day of boarding plus ten dollars ($10.00) additional boarding fee for each subsequent day or fraction thereof that the animal is kept. The director or shelter manager has the authority to work with animal owners concerning the redemption fees or boarding fees owed. 
(c)  In addition to the boarding fee there shall also be collected an unaltered animal redemption fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) from any owner redeeming a dog, puppy, kitten, or cat that cannot provide verification that said animal has been spayed or neutered. Upon redemption, the owner shall have forty-five (45) days to provide proof of the subsequent spay or neuter of said animal and upon proof being provided the twenty-five dollar ($25.00) fee shall be paid to the veterinarian who performed the surgery. If the owner declines to have the animal spayed or neutered within the forty-five-day period the unaltered animal redemption fee shall forfeited to or retained by the city. 
(Code 1956, § 5-3; Ord. No. 90-2914, § 1, 6-4-90; Ord. No. 08-3947, § 1, 4-7-08; Ord. No. 16-4252 , § 2, 3-7-16) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to restrict, impound and dispose of animals running at large, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 3-5-14; 11-47-110. 
Sec. 4-2. - Dogs to be under control when off owner's premises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or person in charge of any premises to cause, permit or allow any dog or puppy residing there, either temporarily or permanently, to be off of such premises or property unless such is under the control of a competent person, either by leash, cord, chain or other restraint sufficient to physically control said dog or puppy at all times. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or person in charge of any dog or puppy to cause, permit or allow such dog or puppy to be off the premises or property of the owner or person in charge unless under the control of a competent person either by leash, cord, chain or other restraint sufficient to physically control said dog or puppy at all times. 
(Code 1956, § 5-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 3-1-5. 
Sec. 4-3. - Animal affected with or suspected of having rabies.
