ARTICLE II. - ZONING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Airport zoning, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-16. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Airport Obstruction Zoning Ordinance of the City of Decatur, Alabama," and the map herein referred to, identified by the title "Airport Obstruction Zoning Map of the City of Decatur, Alabama," shall further be identified by the signatures of the city clerk. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-21) 
Sec. 6-17. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply to this article unless the context otherwise requires: 
    Airport means the Huntsville-Madison County Airport. 
    Airport hazard means any structure, tree or use of land which obstructs the airspace required for, or is otherwise hazardous to, the flight of aircraft in landing or taking off at the airport. 
    Airport manager means the individual responsible for operation and management of the Huntsville-Madison County Airport. 
    Airport reference point means the point established as the approximate geographic center of the airport landing area. 
    Airport zoning commission means a board consisting of three (3) members appointed by the city council of the City of Decatur, Alabama, pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-5. 
    Height limitation means the maximum elevation for the highest point that a structure may be altered, erected or a tree allowed to grow. 
    Instrument runway means a runway equipped or to be equipped with electronic or visual air navigation aids adequate to permit the landing of aircraft under restricted visibility conditions. 
    Landing strip means the area of the airport used for the landing, taking off or taxiing of aircraft. 
    Map means the airport obstruction zoning map. 
    Nonconforming use means any structure, tree or use of land which does not conform to the regulations prescribed in this article or an amendment thereto, as of the effective date of such regulation. 
    Noninstrument runway means a runway other than an instrument runway. 
    Person means any individual, firm, co-partnership, corporation, company, association, joint stock association or body politic, and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee or other representative thereof. 
    Political subdivision means any municipality, city, town village or county. 
    Runway means the paved surface of an airport landing strip. 
    Structure means any object constructed or installed by man including, but without limitation, buildings, towers, antennae, smokestacks and overhead transmission wires. 
    Tree means any object of natural growth. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-22) 
State Law reference- Definitions relating to airport zoning, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-2. 
Sec. 6-18. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the airport zoning commission to administer and enforce the regulations prescribed in this article. Applications for permits and variances shall be made to the airport manager upon a form furnished by him. Applications required by this division to be submitted to the airport manager shall be promptly referred to the airport zoning commission. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-30) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-9. 
Sec. 6-19. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined, upon conviction, not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and costs of court for each offense. Each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-31) 
Sec. 6-20. - Remedies. 
(a)  In case any structure or tree is erected, altered, planted or allowed to grow in violation of this article, the airport zoning commission, or any other appropriate authority, in addition to other remedies, may institute injunction, mandamus or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful creation of a hazard to air navigation. 
(b)  Any person creating a hazard to air navigation may be compelled, at his own expense, to lower, remove, reconstruct or equip such object, as may be necessary to conform to this article, or if the owner of such structure or tree shall neglect or refuse to comply with such order for ten (10) days after notice thereof, the City of Decatur, Alabama, may proceed to have the object so lowered, removed, reconstructed or equipped, and recover the cost and expense thereof from the owner of such structure or tree. Unless such cost and expense is paid within ninety (90) days from the service of notice thereof on the agent or owner of such structure or tree, the sum shall bear interest at the rate of six (6) percent per annum until paid, and shall be recoverable by civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-32) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-12. 
Sec. 6-21. - Establishing airport hazard area. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article in an area of land and water within a radius of fifty-five thousand (55,000) feet of the airport reference point hereinafter described and established, and including the area within the limits of the boundary of the airport approach-departure surface zones, transition surface zones, horizontal surface zones and conical surface zones, is hereby declared to be the airport hazard area, and the whole of such area is made subject thereto. 
(b)  The airport reference point is established and described as follows: Latitude 34° 38' 19?; Longitude 86° 46' 25.2?. 
(c)  The airport elevation for this article is hereby declared to be six hundred twenty-eight (628) feet mean sea level. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-23) 
Sec. 6-22. - Zones. 
    In order to carry out the provisions of this article, the airport hazard area is hereby divided into separate zones which include all of the land lying within the instrument approach-departure zone, noninstrument approach-departure zone, transitional zone, horizontal zone and conical zone. The limits of these zones are hereby established as shown on the airport zoning map of Huntsville-Madison County Airport, which is hereby made a part of this article and the same may be amended and supplemented. The various zones are hereby established and defined as follows: 
(1)  Instrument approach-departure zone. This zone is established at each end of the instrument runway for instrument landings and take-offs. The instrument approach-departure zone shall have a width of one thousand (1,000) feet at a distance of two hundred (200) feet beyond each end of the runway, widening thereafter uniformly to a width of sixteen thousand (16,000) feet at a distance of fifty thousand two hundred (50,200) feet beyond each end of the runway, its centerline being the continuation of the centerline of the runway. 
(2)  Noninstrument approach-departure zone. This zone is established at each of the noninstrument runways for noninstrument landings and take-offs. The noninstrument approach-departure zone shall have a width of five hundred (500) feet at a distance of two hundred (200) feet beyond each end of the runway, widening thereafter uniformly to a width of two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet at a distance of ten thousand two hundred (10,200) feet beyond each end of the runway, its centerline being the continuation of the centerline of the runway. 
(3)  Transitional zone. These zones extend outward from both sides of the primary surface and the approach-departure zones to an intersection with the inner horizontal, conical and outer horizontal zones or other transitional zones. 
(4)  Inner horizontal zone. This zone is established as the area within a circle with its center at the airport reference point and having a radius of thirteen thousand (13,000) feet. This zone does not include the instrument and noninstrument approach-departure zones and the transitional zones. 
(5)  Conical zone. This zone is established commencing at the periphery of the inner horizontal zone and extending to a distance of twenty thousand (20,000) feet from the airport reference point. This zone does not include the instrument and noninstrument approach-departure zones and the transitional zones. 
(6)  Outer horizontal zone. This zone is established as the area starting at twenty thousand (20,000) feet from the center of a circle and extending outward to a distance of fifty thousand (50,000) feet from the airport reference point. This zone does not include the instrument and noninstrument approach-departure zones and the transitional zones. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-24) 
Sec. 6-23. - Primary surface. 
    The primary surface is symmetrically located with respect to the centerline of the landing strip. The transverse profile of primary surface is horizontal; whereas, its longitudinal profile may vary throughout its length. The elevation of any point on the longitudinal profile of the primary surface is determined by the highest ground elevation along the width of the landing strip. The primary surfaces for this article are hereby established as follows: 
(1)  Primary surface runway 18R/36L. This surface is one thousand (1,000) feet wide and ten thousand four hundred (10,400) feet in length for runway 18R/36L and begins two hundred (200) feet outward from the north end of said runway. 
(2)  Primary surface runway 18L/36R. This surface is one thousand (1,000) feet wide and eight thousand four hundred (8,400) feet in length for runway 18L/36R and begins two hundred (200) feet outward from the north end of said runway. 
(3)  Primary surface runway 13/31. This surface is five hundred (500) feet wide and four thousand four hundred (4,400) feet in length for runway 13/31 and begins two hundred (200) feet outward from the southeast end of said runway. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-25) 
Sec. 6-24. - Criteria to govern height limitations. 
    Except as otherwise noted in this article, no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, allowed to grow or maintained in any zone created by this article to a height in excess of the height limit herein established for such zone. Such height limitations are computed from imaginary surfaces referenced to the airport elevation. The imaginary surface established for each of the zones in question is as follows: 
(1)  Approach-departure surfaces: 
a.  Runway 18R. This surface slopes one (1) foot in height for each fifty (50) feet in horizontal distance beginning at an elevation of six hundred twenty-eight (628) feet and a distance of one thousand (1,000) feet outward from the end of runway 18R. This surface slopes outward and upward from its beginning, symmetrically about the extended centerline of the landing strip, to an elevation of one thousand one hundred twenty-eight (1,128) feet; thence continues at this elevation to fifty thousand two hundred (50,200) feet beyond the end of the runway. 
b.  Runway 36L. This surface slopes one foot in height for each fifty (50) feet in horizontal distance beginning at an elevation of six hundred fourteen (614) feet and a distance of two hundred (200) feet outward from the end of runway 36L. This surface slopes outward and upward from its beginning, symmetrically about the extended centerline of the landing strip, to an elevation of one thousand one hundred twenty-eight (1,128) feet; thence continues at this elevation to fifty thousand two hundred (50,200) feet beyond the end of the runway. 
c.  Runway 18L. This surface slopes one foot in height for each fifty (50) feet in horizontal distance beginning at an elevation of six hundred six (606) feet and a distance of two hundred (200) feet outward from the end of runway 18L. This surface slopes outward and upward from its beginning, symmetrically about the extended centerline of the landing strip, to an elevation of one thousand one hundred twenty-eight (1,128) feet; thence continues at this elevation to fifty thousand two hundred (50,200) feet beyond the end of the runway. 
d.  Runway 36R. This surface slopes one foot in height for each fifty (50) feet in horizontal distance beginning at an elevation of five hundred eighty-nine (589) feet and a distance of six hundred fifty (650) feet outward from the end of runway 36R. This surface slopes outward and upward from its beginning, symmetrically about the extended centerline of the landing strip, to an elevation of one thousand one hundred twenty-eight (1,128) feet; thence continues at this elevation to fifty thousand two hundred (50,200) feet beyond the end of the runway. 
e.  Runway 13. This surface slopes one foot in height for each fifty (50) feet in horizontal distance beginning at an elevation of six hundred twenty (620) feet and a distance of two hundred (200) feet outward from the end of runway 13. This surface slopes outward and upward from its beginning, symmetrically about the extended centerline of the landing strip, to an elevation of seven hundred seventy-eight (778) feet; thence continues at this elevation to ten thousand (10,000) feet beyond the end of the runway. 
f.  Runway 31. This surface slopes one foot in height for each forty (40) feet in horizontal distance beginning at an elevation of five hundred eighty-nine (589) feet and a distance of two hundred (200) feet outward from the end of runway 31. This surface slopes outward and upward from its beginning, symmetrically about the extended centerline of the landing strip, to an elevation of seven hundred seventy-eight (778) feet; thence continues at this elevation to eight thousand five hundred (8,500) feet beyond the end of the runway. 
(2)  Transitional surface: This surface extends outward and upward at a slope of one foot in height for each seven (7) feet in horizontal distance. The maximum elevation for structures or trees located thereunder shall be the elevation of the adjacent point on the primary surface or the approach-departure surface plus one-seventh ( 1/7 ) of the distance which separates the structure or tree from the slope of the primary or approach-departure surface. The distance shall be measured in feet along the perpendicular to the landing strip or its extended centerline. 
(3)  Inner horizontal surface: This surface is at a height of one hundred fifty (150) feet above the established airport elevation. The maximum elevation of structures or trees located thereunder shall be seven hundred seventy-eight (778) feet mean sea level. 
(4)  Conical surface: This surface extends outward and upward at a slope of one foot in height for each twenty (20) feet in horizontal distance. The maximum elevation of structures or trees located thereunder shall be seven hundred seventy-eight (778) feet plus one-twentieth of the distance which separates the structure or tree from the periphery of the horizontal surface. The distance shall be measured in feet along the radial from the airport reference point. 
(5)  Outer horizontal surface: This surface is at a height of five hundred (500) feet above the established airport elevation. The maximum elevation of structures or trees located thereunder shall be one thousand one hundred twenty-eight (1,128) feet mean sea level. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the growth, construction or maintenance of any tree or structure to a height of up to fifty (50) feet above the surface of the land. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-26) 
Sec. 6-25. - Use restrictions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no use may be made of land within any zone established by this article in such a manner as to create electrical interference with a radio communication between the airport and aircraft, make it difficult for flyers to distinguish between airport lights and others, result in glare in the eyes of flyers using the airport, impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport or otherwise endanger the landing, taking-off, maneuvering of aircraft or impair approach and departure procedures. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-27) 
Sec. 6-26. - Nonconforming uses-Regulations not retroactive. 
    The regulations prescribed by this article shall not be construed to require the removal, lowering or other changes or alteration of any structure or tree not conforming to the regulations as of June 1, 1965, or otherwise interfere with the continuance of any nonconforming use. Nothing herein contained shall require any change in the structure, alteration or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of which was begun prior to June 1, 1965, and is diligently executed. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-28) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-7. 
Sec. 6-27. - Same-Marking and lighting. 
    Notwithstanding the preceding section, the owner of any nonconforming structure or tree is hereby required to permit the installation, operation and maintenance thereon of such markers and lights as shall be deemed necessary by the airport manager to indicate to the operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport, the presence of such airport hazards. Such markers and lights shall be installed, operated and maintained at the expense of Huntsville-Madison County Airport. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-28) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-8. 
Secs. 6-28-6-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 6-41. - Future uses. 
    Except as specifically provided in paragraphs (1), (2) and (3) of this section, no material change shall be made in the use of land and no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, planted or otherwise established in any zone created by this division unless a permit therefor shall have been applied for and granted. Each application for a permit shall indicate purpose for which the permit is desired, with sufficient particularity to permit it to be determined whether the resulting use, structure or tree would conform to the regulations herein prescribed. If such determination is in the affirmative, the permit shall be granted. 
(1)  In the area lying within the limits of the horizontal zone and the conical zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than seventy-five (75) feet of vertical height above the ground, except when because of the terrain, land contour or topographic features such tree or structure would extend above the height limits prescribed for such zone. 
(2)  In the areas lying within the limits of the instrument and noninstrument approach-departure zone, but at a horizontal distance of not less than four thousand two hundred (4,200) feet from each end of the runways no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than fifty (50) feet of vertical height above the ground, except when such tree or structure would extend above the height limit prescribed for such instrument or noninstrument approach-departure zone. 
(3)  In the areas lying within the limits of the transitional zones beyond the perimeter of the horizontal zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than seventy-five (75) feet of vertical height above the ground except when such tree or structure, because of terrain, land-contour or topographic features would extend above the height limit prescribed for such transitional zones. 
    Nothing contained in any of the foregoing exceptions shall be construed as permitting or intending to permit any construction, alteration or growth of any structure or tree in excess of any of the height limits established by this division. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-29) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-8. 
Sec. 6-42. - Existing uses. 
    No permit shall be granted that would allow the establishment or creation of an airport hazard or permit a nonconforming use, structure or tree to be made or become higher, or become a greater hazard to air navigation, than it was on the effective date of this division [June 1, 1965] or any amendment thereto or than it is when the application for a permit is made. Except as indicated, all applications for such a permit shall be granted. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-29) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-8. 
Sec. 6-43. - Nonconforming uses abandoned or destroyed. 
    Whenever the airport zoning commission determines that a nonconforming structure or tree has been abandoned or more than eighty (80) percent torn down, physically deteriorated, or decayed, no permit shall be granted that would allow such structure or tree to exceed the applicable height limit or otherwise deviate from these zoning regulations. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-29) 
Sec. 6-44. - Variances. 
    Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any structure, or permit the growth of any tree, or use his property, not in accordance with the regulations prescribed in this division, may apply to the airport zoning commission for a variance from such division. Such variances shall be allowed where it is duly found that a literal application or enforcement of the regulations would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship and the relief granted would not be contrary to the public interest but will do substantial justice and be in accordance with the spirit of this division. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-29) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-8. 
Sec. 6-45. - Hazard marking and lighting. 
    Any permit or variance granted may, if such action is deemed advisable to effectuate the purpose of this division and be reasonable in the circumstances, be so conditioned as to require the owner of the structure or tree in question at their expense to install, operate and maintain thereon such markers and lights as may be necessary to indicate to flyers the presence of an airport hazard. 
(Code 1956, § 3A-29) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 4-6-8. 
Chapter 6.5 - BINGO OPERATIONS 

Sec. 6.5-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Bingo. The game of bingo is a game of chance that is played by groups of people seated in a duly authorized and permitted location. Balls bearing a combination of one (1) of five (5) letters (B-I-N-G-O) and a number between one (1) and seventy-five (75) are randomly drawn, usually from a wheel, and announced by a "caller." The game is played on flat pieces of cardboard or disposable paper containing twenty-five (25) squares arranged in five (5) vertical columns and five (5) horizontal rows (i.e., a five-inch by five-inch square matrix). The letters B-I-N-G-O are printed above the five (5) vertical columns, with one (1) letter appearing above each column; the center space on the square matrix may be marked "Free," and one (1) of the seventy-five (75) numbers with which the game typically is played is pre-printed in each of the remaining twenty-four (24) squares. The distribution of the seventy-five (75) numbers commonly corresponds to the following arrangement on the pre-printed card: 1 to 15 in the "B" column; 16 to 30 in the "I" column; 31 to 45 in the "N" column; 46 to 60 in the "G" column; and, 61 to 75 in the "O" column. As balls are randomly drawn and the marked letter/number combination announced by the caller, each player covers (with a poker chip, "daub" of paint, or some other marking device) any square on his or her Bingo card that corresponds to the announced letter/number combination. Players compete against each other to be the first to achieve a specified winning pattern (typically, five (5) contiguous squares covered vertically, horizontally, or diagonally) announced by the caller before the beginning of each game, and a winner is required to call out the word "Bingo!" to alert other players and the caller to a possible win. Bingo cards are not cleared and a new game begun until it has been confirmed that each space covered on the putative winner's card was, in fact, randomly drawn and announced by the caller during the course of that game. This definition may not be construed to include the operation of the game of bingo by the use of any electronic or electrical equipment or device, computer, or related equipment, telecommunication or data transmission, storage, or receiving equipment. 
    Bingo session. A series of consecutive games held during a period of time not to exceed five (5) hours in a given day, not to extend beyond the hour of 11:30 o'clock p.m., nor to exceed one (1) day in a calendar week, with the exclusion of Sunday. Games will be considered to be consecutive when they are continuous except for a break of no more than fifteen (15) minutes between games. 
    Committee. The bingo review committee. 
    Equivalent value. The fair market value of the gift on the date the gift is given as the prize in a bingo game. 
    Location. A single building, hall, enclosure, or outdoor area used for the purpose of playing bingo pursuant to a permit or license issued under this chapter. Multiple permits may not be issued for the same location. 
    Net proceeds. The gross proceeds of each bingo session less the cost of prizes and the cost of purchase and/or repair of bingo machines and monitors. In addition to the cost of prizes and the purchase and/or repair of bingo machines and monitors, the actual specific expenses incurred as a reasonable expense of each bingo session for bingo game sheets, janitorial services, security, bookkeeping or accounting services, trash pick-up (dumpster) services, insurance, utilities, return check fees and license fees which are directly related to the operation of the bingo session may be deducted from gross proceeds to determine net proceeds. Said additional expenses must be directly related to the operation of bingo sessions and the deduction for such additional expenses may not during a calendar year exceed, in aggregate, seven (7) percent of the gross proceeds of all bingo sessions during that particular calendar year. 
    Permit. A permit issued by the city clerk pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. Said permit is in addition to, and not in lieu of any business or privilege license which may be required by the city's licensing code. 
    Permit holder. A qualified organization or qualified club which holds a current permit or license pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
    Person. Any human being, corporation, association or other legal entity. 
    Reasonable expenses. Includes customary and usual business overhead expenses. 
    Qualified organization. A bona fide religious, educational, service, senior citizens, fraternal or veteran's organization which, by its charter, certificate of incorporation or constitution, operates without profit to its members and which qualifies as an exempt organization under Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code, provided that the principal location of each such organization (defined as being where a majority of the organization's assets are located) shall have been in existence continuously as that organization within that area of the corporate limits of the city which lie within Morgan County for a period of three (3) years and which has owned or leased real property within the city limits which lie within Morgan County for at least three (3) years immediately prior to making application for a bingo permit. " 
(Ord. No. 96-3340, § 1, 12-2-96; Ord. No. 01-3687, § 1, 12-17-01; Ord. No. 10-4054, § 1, 2-7-11; Ord. No. 11-4071, § 1, 8-1-11) 
Sec. 6.5-2. - Authority. 
    It shall be lawful for any qualified organization, upon obtaining a permit from the city clerk as hereinafter provided, to conduct the game of bingo within that area of the corporate limits of the city which lie within Morgan County, subject to the provisions of this chapter and subject to Act No. 96-378 and Act No. 96-648, both adopted during the 1996 Regular Session of the Alabama Legislature. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, association, corporation or organization, including any non-profit organization, its officers, employees or agents, whether for charitable or educational purposes or otherwise, to operate any bingo game or games for prizes or money within the area of the corporate limits of the city lying within Morgan County, Alabama, without first having obtained a permit therefore as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 96-3340, § 1, 12-2-96) 
Sec. 6.5-3. - General restrictions. 
    Any game or games of bingo licensed hereunder shall be subject to the following restrictions in addition to such other restrictions as may be provided herein or contained in the Laws of the State of Alabama. 
(1)  No person, firm, association, corporation, organization or club shall conduct any game of bingo except under a permit issued by the city clerk pursuant to this chapter. No bingo game shall be operated until a permit has been issued. A permit holder may hold only one (1) permit and the permit shall be valid for only the one (1) location for which it has been issued. A permit shall not be assignable or transferable. A permit holder shall not lend its name or allow its identity to be used by any other person in operating or promoting a bingo game in which that permit holder is not directly and solely operating said bingo game, regardless of whether that person or organization is an auxiliary to the qualified organization or whether the permit holder is an auxiliary of that person or organization. 
(2)  No person, firm, association, corporation, organization or club shall conduct any game of bingo unless the location is within the confines of that area of the corporate limits of the city which lies within the boundaries of Morgan County. No permit shall be issued for any bingo game or games to be held in any location within the corporate limits of the city which lie outside the boundaries of Morgan County. 
(3)  No person, firm, association, corporation, organization or club shall conduct any game of bingo except at the specific time and single location approved by the city bingo review committee. 
(4)  No bingo permit shall be issued to any non-profit organization, unless such organization has been in existence continuously for at least three (3) years within that area of the corporate limits of the city which lies within Morgan County; has, for at least the three (3) years immediately prior to making application for a permit, owned or leased real property within that area of the corporate limits of the city which lies within the boundaries of Morgan County. 
(5)  The permit holder shall display its bingo permit conspicuously at the location where the bingo game is approved and conducted. 
(6)  No person, firm, association, corporation, organization or club shall hold, operate or conduct any game or games of bingo under any permit except an active member of the qualified organization to which the permit is issued, and no person except an active member of the qualified organization or of its auxiliary shall assist in the holding, operating or conducting of any game. 
(7)  No person under the age of nineteen (19) shall be permitted to play any game or games of bingo, nor to conduct or assist in conducting any game of bingo pursuant to this chapter. 
(8)  No person under the age of nineteen (19), with the exception of members of the qualified organization, shall be allowed in the room where a bingo game is being played during any bingo session. 
(9)  No alcoholic beverages shall be served on the permitted premises during any bingo session. 
(10)  No person who has been convicted of any gambling offense, any crime involving moral turpitude or any other criminal offense, other than minor traffic offenses, under the laws of Alabama, the laws of the United States, the laws of any other state or the ordinances of any municipality, shall be involved in the operation of any bingo games for which a permit is issued by the city for a period of one (1) year from the date of said conviction. No permit holder shall conduct bingo games at a building, hall or facility which is owned or under the control of any person who has been convicted of the above offenses within a period of one (1) year of the date of the application. 
(11)  No permit holder shall pay consulting fees to any person for any services performed in relation to the operation or conduct of a bingo game. No permit holder shall enter into any contract with any person to have said person operate bingo games or concessions on behalf of the permit holder. 
(12)  No games of bingo shall be conducted with any equipment which is not owned, being purchased or being rented at a reasonable rate by the permit holder, with the exception that, with the consent of the permit holder, any individual participant in a bingo game may use his or her personal bingo card, but is not exempt from any fees or charges by the permit holder that are normally charged to any other participant in the game. 
(13)  The total value of prizes given by any permit holder for the playing of bingo games shall not exceed the cash amount or gifts of equivalent value of three thousand five hundred dollars ($3,500.00) during any bingo session. 
(14)  It shall be unlawful for two (2) or more permit holders to pyramid the valuation of prizes in a manner so as to exceed the limits in cash, or gifts of equivalent value, as provided in subsection (10) of this section. 
(15)  A permit holder may not advertise bingo games or sessions without approval of the governing body of the city. 
(16)  No permit holder shall conduct more than one bingo session during any one (1) calendar week, nor shall any bingo session exceed five (5) hours in duration, nor shall any bingo session extend beyond the hour of 11:30 p.m. No bingo sessions shall be permitted to be held on Sundays. 
(Ord. No. 96-3340, § 1, 12-2-96; Ord. No. 10-4054, § 2, 2-7-11 
Sec. 6.5-4. - Operating requirements. 
    Any game or games of bingo permitted under this chapter shall be subject to the following requirements, in addition to such other requirements as may be provided herein or contained in the Laws of the State of Alabama. 
(1)  Bingo games comprising a bingo session shall not have an intermission of more than fifteen (15) minutes between games, and at the beginning of the session, bingo cards good for all the games listed on the program of play for the session may be purchased by the players. Additional cards for games listed on the program of play can be sold at a reduced price during the intermission. 
(2)  Bingo games shall be operated only on the premises owned or leased by the permit holder. If the premises are leased, the rate of rental shall not be based, in whole or in part, on a percentage of receipts or profits resulting from the operation of bingo games. Up to ten (10) percent of the monthly gross receipts from bingo operations, but in no event more than four hundred dollars ($400), may be used to pay rent for the location to which the permit is issued. 
(3)  No permit holder shall take any salary, expense money or fees (unless specifically authorized by this chapter) as remuneration for services rendered in the operation of any bingo game. 
(4)  The entire net proceeds of any game of bingo, as defined by this chapter, shall be devoted to charitable and/or educational purposes as follows: fifty-one (51) percent of the net proceeds shall be donated to charities external to the permit holder; forty-nine (49) percent shall be used to pay reasonable expenses related to bingo, other than those specifically allowed in section 6.5-1 and for charities internal to the organization of the permit holder. 
(5)  Each qualified organization, as a condition precedent to receiving a bingo permit under this chapter, shall have at least thirty (30) active members who reside within the corporate limits of the city; shall have at least four (4) general membership meetings annually where minutes are kept of the meeting; and shall elect officers at least annually where all classes of members shall be eligible for election to all offices by popular ballot of the entire membership. In addition, each applicant for a permit shall provide such evidence as may be required by the city clerk as evidence that it has met the requirements of this chapter. 
(6)  Prior to each bingo session, there shall be maintained by the bingo chairman of the qualified organization and posted in view of the general public at each entrance, a list of all members working at that bingo session, showing at least their name and position of responsibility, and the bingo chairman or the person in charge in his stead shall wear a name tag showing his/her name. 
(7)  At the beginning of each bingo session, a program of play shall be provided to each player and anyone else who requests a copy of same, showing the number, order and type of bingo games to be played, along with the amount of the winning prize for each bingo game. All the rules for the game of bingo shall be listed on the program of play. No game shall be played by whatever title or name that is not listed on the program of play. 
(8)  At the beginning of each bingo game, the person calling the game shall announce the amount of the prize for that bingo game. At the end of each bingo game, the person calling the game shall announce the number of winners for that game and how much each winner received. 
(9)  The permit holder must designate a bingo committee and name one (1) of its members to serve as the bingo chairman. No person may serve as bingo chairman for more than one (1) permit holder. The city clerk of the city shall be notified in writing within thirty (30) calendar days of any change in the permit holder's designated bingo chairman. 
(10)  No game of instant bingo, more commonly referred to as "pull tabs" (where a single or banded ticket or card, with its face covered to conceal one (1) or more numbers or symbols where one (1) or more cards or tickets in each set has been designated in advance as a winner, and where participants at a designated time of play remove the front cover of the card to determine if that card has the required designated numbers or symbols to be declared a winner) shall be played by any permit holder. 
(11)  No member of any qualified organization which has been granted a permit under this chapter who manages, calls or helps conduct any bingo game during a session shall be allowed to play bingo at any game during such bingo session. 
(12)  No permit holder shall allow any other person to sell concessions or to undertake any other type of fundraising activity of any kind whatsoever at the permitted location on the day of any bingo session. 
(Ord. No. 96-3340, § 1, 12-2-96; Ord. No. 01-3687, § 2, 12-17-01; Ord. No. 10-4054, § 3, 2-7-11 
Sec. 6.5-5. - Reporting requirements. 
    Each permit holder shall maintain the following records pertaining to each bingo session for a period of at least one (1) year from the date of the annual report to the city clerk: 
(1)  Each permit holder shall be required to maintain a separate checking account for bingo operations, into which all bingo funds except cash prizes awarded during the bingo session are deposited and from which all bingo disbursement checks are written. The bingo checking account is to be separate from and in addition to any other checking or savings accounts maintained by the permit holder. 
(2)  An accurate, itemized list shall be maintained for each bingo session showing the gross amount of money taken in from fees, sale of game packs and sale of game sheets during each bingo session; the total number of winners for each bingo game and the amount received by each winner of a game; the total amount that was given away during each bingo session and the net amount of each bingo session to be deposited in the permit holder's bingo checking account. The net amount shall be deposited in the bingo checking account within four (4) days after the bingo session. All payments of any kind made from the proceeds of any bingo game, except for cash prizes awarding during the bingo game, must be made by check from the permit holder's bingo checking account and a receipt or invoice must be on file for all expenditures other than cash prizes. The above accounting records, copies of all canceled checks (both sides of check), copies of all deposit slips and copies of monthly bingo checking account bank statements shall be attached to the annual reports that are required under subsection (4) of this section to be submitted to the city clerk of the city. 
(3)  No item of expense shall be incurred or paid in connection with the holding, operating or conducting of any game of bingo under any permit, except those reasonable expenses that are directly related to the operation of bingo, including, but not limited to, bingo supplies and equipment, bingo prizes and bingo permit application fees; for bookkeeping or accounting services, janitorial services, security services, trash pick up (dumpster) services, insurance, if any, and utilities. 
(4)  On January 2, and in no case later than January 31, of each calendar year, each permit holder shall file with the city clerk a copy of the records required in subsections (1) and (2) of this section, relating to the operating of bingo sessions in the previous calendar year. Said annual report shall accompany any application for permit renewal and shall be subscribed by the bingo chairman and affirmed by the same as true, under the penalties of perjury. 
(5)  The records required to be kept pursuant to subsections (1), (2) and (3) of this section and the location at which bingo is conducted shall be open to inspection by the sheriff, municipal officials, any law enforcement agency or the duly authorized representatives of either during reasonable business hours. The city clerk or any officer designated by her shall have the right and the authority to examine or cause to be examined any manager, officer, director, agent, member or employee thereof under oath in relation to the conduct of any such game or the use of its premises for bingo under any permit issued by her. 
(Ord. No. 96-3340, § 1, 12-2-96) 
Sec. 6.5-6. - Application for permit. 
    The process by which each qualified organization may apply for a permit and for a renewal of the annual permit is as follows: 
(1)  Each qualified organization desiring to obtain a permit to operate bingo games shall file with the city clerk a duly executed and verified application on forms provided by the city clerk and shall pay a non-refundable annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). The city clerk shall refuse to grant or renew a bingo permit to any applicant who fails to fully provide the information required on the application forms provided by the city clerk. Each applicant for a permit shall prove its length of existence and the ownership for at least the three (3) preceding years of real property within area of the corporate limits of the city lying within the boundaries of Morgan County. The application shall include, but is not limited to, the following information 
a.  Legal name of the qualified organization. 
b.  Actual or trade name of the qualified organization. 
c.  Current mailing address and telephone number of the qualified organization and the address for the previous three (3) years, if different. 
d.  Address of location where bingo games are to be played. Premises must be wholly owned by the qualified organization or a lease and/or sublease must be provided. 
e.  Day of the week (with the exception of Sunday) on which bingo session is to be held. 
f.  Time of day during which bingo session is to be held (not to exceed five (5) hours or to extend beyond 11:30 p.m.) 
g.  Date the qualified organization was established in Decatur and/or date of incorporation. 
h.  Name, current address, telephone number and place and date of birth of each current officer or director of the qualified organization. 
i.  Name, current addresses and telephone numbers of persons or entities that shall be the surety for the applicant. If individuals, include place and date of birth. 
j.  Name, current address, telephone number and place and date of birth of the qualified organization's bingo committee members, with one (1) of the members designated as the bingo chairman. There shall be attached to the application a statement executed by the members of the Bingo Committee that they will be responsible for the conduct of bingo games in accordance with the terms and requirements of the permit issued to the permit holder and the provisions of this chapter and the Laws of the State of Alabama. 
k.  Copy of certificate of incorporation, if the qualified organization is a corporation. 
l.  Copy of charter. If the qualified organization is affiliated with any state, national or international organization, the qualified organization must submit a copy of the authorization or evidence of affiliation issued by the state, national, or international organization. 
m.  Copy of the qualified organization's by-laws. 
n.  Copy of the qualified organization's 501(c) exemption status as approved under the United States Internal Revenue Code. 
o.  Copy of current active membership roster including, but not limited to the names, addresses and telephone numbers of at least thirty (30) members who reside within the corporate limits of the city. 
p.  Copy of deed to the property where bingo games will be conducted or copy of any lease and/or sub-lease pertaining to the property where bingo games will be conducted. Name, address and telephone number of property owner. 
q.  Copies of the qualified organization's financial statements for the immediately preceding three (3) years. 
r.  A list of all charitable or educational donations, including the dollar amount or value thereof, made during the immediately preceding three (3) years. 
s.  A list of persons who will operate any concessions during bingo sessions. If no concessions will be sold, attach a statement to that effect. 
t.  A copy of the Morgan County health department permit and most current health department inspection report, if concessions are to be sold or served during bingo games. 
u.  A statement as to the specific purpose to which the entire net proceeds of bingo games are to be donated. 
v.  A statement that all persons signing the application have received and read a copy of the current city bingo ordinance. 
w.  $100.00 application fee. 
(2)  Any original permit granted under this chapter shall be effective January 1 of the following year, with the exception of the permits issued for calendar year 1997, which shall be effective upon their approval. 
(3)  Permits shall be in such form as shall be prescribed by the city clerk and shall contain a statement of the name and address of the bingo committee of the qualified organization, the place, day of the week and times that bingo sessions are to be conducted and the specific purposes to which the entire net proceeds of such bingo games are to be devoted. 
(4)  The city clerk shall exercise close supervision over all games of bingo conducted by permit holders and shall have the responsibility and authority to suspend or revoke any such permit for violation of any provision of this chapter. The city clerk shall provide written notice of revocation to the permit holder by certified mail and said revocation shall become effective ten (10) days after the date of said notice unless the permit holder files with the city clerk within the said ten-day period a written request for a hearing by the bingo review committee. Following a full hearing of the committee, a written decision shall be rendered by the committee. The decision of the committee may be appealed to the Decatur city council and the city council shall hold a public hearing concerning the revocation at the earliest scheduled meeting of the city council and shall render a written decision on the revocation. The rendering of a decision by the city council to uphold a permit revocation shall result in the immediate revocation of the permit. Either party may appeal the decision of the city council within fourteen (14) days to the circuit court of Morgan County and request a trial by jury. 
(5)  As a prerequisite for the renewal of any permit issued pursuant to this chapter, the permit holder must submit to the city clerk all information required in subsection (1) of this section, as well as the prior year's annual bingo financial statement, in a format specified by the city clerk, to be used by the bingo review committee to determine the properness of the renewal of said permit. Any information required for permit renewal that has not changed and does not differ from the original permit application on file with the city clerk shall not be required to be submitted in connection with the renewal application, providing a statement to that effect is attached to the renewal application. 
(6)  Permits may be amended upon resubmission of the application, surrender of the current permit and payment of a non-refundable twenty-five-dollar ($25.00) additional fee. 
(Ord. No. 96-3340, § 1, 12-2-96) 
Sec. 6.5-7. - Bingo review committee. 
    There is hereby created for the purpose of assisting the city clerk in the review of application for bingo permits a committee to be known and designated as the bingo review committee to be composed as follows: The city clerk or her designated representative; one (1) member of the police department to be designated by the chief of police; one (1) member of the public at large who may be affiliated with a qualified organization to be appointed by the city council for a term of two (2) years; one (1) member of the public at large who shall not be affiliated with a qualified organization to be appointed by the city council for a term of two (2) years. The committee shall annually elect a chairman and a secretary and may adopt such procedural rules for its own operation as are consistent with the provisions of this chapter. The committee shall hold such regular meetings as may be determined by the committee and the chairman shall call special meetings at any time at the request of the city clerk or of any two (2) committee members, provided that notice of the time and place of all special meetings shall be given to all committee members. 
(1)  The committee shall assist the city clerk in the consideration and special investigation of the applications for bingo permits. In addition to considering all relevant findings compiled by the city clerk, the committee may require any applicant to submit additional evidence and may conduct a financial analysis and investigation of the application. The committee shall make a recommendation to the city clerk as to whether or not a permit should be issued to the applicant. In addition, the committee shall review all annual reports submitted to the city clerk and report any violations to the city clerk. 
(2)  The city clerk shall cause to be investigated the qualifications of each applicant and the merits of each application with due expedition following the filing of the application. The city clerk shall deliver to the committee the application together with the supporting documents and a detailed report of the results of her investigation to determine that the applicant is duly qualified to be issued a permit to conduct bingo under this chapter; that the member or members of the qualified organization designated in the application to conduct bingo are bona fide active members of same and are persons of good moral character and have not violated any provisions of this chapter or been convicted of any criminal offense within the immediately preceding year; that such games are to be conducted in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and that the proceeds thereof are to be disposed of in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. If the committee is satisfied that the application is in order and that the qualified organization has complied with all requirements of this chapter, the committee shall authorize the issuance of a permit and a privilege license upon payment of an annual license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) plus the sum of one-tenth of one (0.1) percent on all annual gross receipts above one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) received solely from the operation of bingo. This annual license fee shall be due on January 1 of each year and subject to the provisions of Chapter 14 of the Code of Decatur, Alabama. 
(3)  If any information required in the current year's application changes during the year, the permit holder must submit to the city clerk a written, notarized statement of any such changes within thirty (30) calendar days of such changes. Failure to submit such notice within the required thirty-day period shall constitute grounds for revocation of the permit. The permit must be amended as provided in subsection (6) of section 6.5-6 of this chapter. 
(4)  No application for a permit shall be recommended for denial by the committee until after a hearing, with due notice to the applicant, at which the applicant shall be entitled to be heard upon the qualifications of the applicant and the merits of the application. In the event recommendation is made that the application for a permit be denied, the applicant may appeal said denial to the city council by filing a notice of appeal with the city clerk within ten (10) days of said hearing. The city council shall set a hearing date on the appeal within a reasonable time. Upon the decision of the city council being made final, either party may appeal the decision of the city council within fourteen (14) days to the Morgan County circuit court and request a jury trial. 
(Ord. No. 96-3340, § 1, 12-2-96) 
Sec. 6.5-8. - Permit revocation. 
    The unauthorized conduct of a bingo game or any willful violation of any provisions of this chapter shall constitute and be punishable as a misdemeanor as provided in section 1-8 of the Code of Decatur, Alabama and this chapter and may result in the revocation of the permit upon conviction of same. In addition to any person directly responsible for any violation of this chapter, the elected or appointed officials, officers or directors of the permit holder shall also be responsible for violations of this chapter. The permit of any permit holder may be revoked for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Failure to submit to the city clerk the annual report as required for the renewal of a bingo permit; 
(2)  Making any false statement in any application for a permit or renewal of a permit to be issued under this chapter: 
(3)  Failure to keep a separate bingo checking account and such books and records as shall fully and accurately record all transactions connected with the permit holders conduct of bingo games; 
(4)  Making any false entry in any books and records so far as they relate in any manner to the conduct of bingo or to the disposition of the proceeds thereof; 
(5)  Failure to list a member working at a bingo session as required by subsection (6) of section 6.5-4 of this chapter; 
(6)  Diverting or paying any portion of the net proceeds of any game of bingo to any person, except in the furtherance of one (1) or more of the lawful purposes enumerated in this chapter; 
(7)  Allowing any person under the age of nineteen (19) to play a game or games of bingo or allowing a person under the age of nineteen (19) to conduct or assist in the conduct of any game or games of bingo; 
(8)  Violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or of the Laws of the State of Alabama relating to the conduct of bingo in the city or of any term of any permit issued under this chapter. 
    The circuit court of Morgan County shall have jurisdiction to restrain or enjoin violations of this chapter and/or violations of Act No. 96-378 and Act No. 96-648, both adopted during the 1996 Regular Session of the Legislature of the State of Alabama and shall afford trial by jury for all appeals directed to it for alleged violations of the same leading to revocations of existing permits. 
    Any person who shall be convicted of any of said offenses shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor upon first conviction and shall be guilty of a Class A misdemeanor upon any subsequent convictions. Any person so convicted shall forfeit any permit issued under this chapter and shall be ineligible to re-apply for a permit or to serve as an officer of a permit holder or to participate in conducting of bingo for a period of one (1) year from the date of such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 96-3340, § 1, 12-2-96) 
Sec. 6.5-9. - Contraband. 
    Any device, equipment, record, money or stakes used in any bingo game or operation in violation of this chapter may be contraband and may be seized and be forfeited. Property forfeited may be sold, destroyed or retained for official use by the municipal, county, state or law enforcement agencies, as the circuit court of Morgan County may direct following a full due process hearing. 
(Ord. No. 96-3340, § 1, 12-2-96) 
Sec. 6.5-10. - Other laws not applicable. 
    Any other law providing a penalty or disability on a person who conducts or participates in bingo games, who possesses equipment used in conducting bingo, who permits bingo to be conducted on his or her premises, or who performs other acts in connection with bingo, shall not apply to the conduct of bingo when done pursuant to this chapter and the Laws of the State of Alabama or rules promulgated under the same. 
(Ord. No. 96-3340, § 1, 12-2-96) 
Chapter 7 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
