All amounts determined to be due under the provisions of this section shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the date such amounts were required to be reported and paid to the city until such time as said amount is paid to the city, and additionally, a penalty of fifteen (15) percent shall be added thereto any amount determined to be due. If any part of the deficiency for which a determination of an additional amount is made is due to negligence or disregard of this division or authorized rules and regulations, or fraud or an intent to evade this division, a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of such amount shall be added thereto. The revenue department shall give to the retailer or person storing, using or consuming tangible personal property written notice of the determination and the total amount of deficiency, interest and penalty shall be paid to the city within ten (10) days of such notice. 
(b)  Any such determination as described above which is levied against a licensed contractor doing business in the city and not paid in full to the city upon expiration of the time provided in this section shall result in that contractor being ineligible for the issuance of any further building permits for projects within the city until such time as the full payment of such determination is made to the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-3324, § 1, 8-16-96; Ord. No. 98-3473, § 12, 7-6-98) 
Sec. 14-78. - Records to be kept; city authorized to make regulations, etc. 
    Every seller and every person storing, using or otherwise consuming in this city tangible personal property purchased from a retailer shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as to be reasonably examined by the city. The city, or any person authorized in writing by it, is hereby authorized to examine the books, papers, records and equipment of any person selling tangible personal property and any person liable for the tax imposed by the division and to investigate the character of the business of any such person, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return was made by such person, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid hereunder. The revenue department is hereby charged with the enforcement of this division and is authorized and empowered to prescribe, adopt and enforce rules and regulations relating to the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 96-3324, § 1, 8-16-96; Ord. No. 98-3473, § 13, 7-6-98) 
Sec. 14-78.1. - In police jurisdiction. 
    In addition to all other taxes now imposed by law there is levied an excise tax or use tax at one-half (1/2) the rates specified in section 14-70 on the storage, use or other consumption of such tangible personal property outside the corporate limits of the city, but within the police jurisdiction. Provided further, that except for the amount of the excise or use tax herein levied within the police jurisdiction of the city but without the corporate limits thereof, all the provisions of this division extend and apply to all the area within the police jurisdiction of the city, subject to the provisions of Act 2015-361 enacted by the Alabama Legislature during the 2015 Regular Session. 
( Ord. No. 15-4246, § 3 , 1-19-16) 
DIVISION 4. - LEASING OR RENTAL TAX 

Sec. 14-79. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this division, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed by this section: 
    Business. All activities engaged in, or caused to be engaged in, by any person with the object of gain, profit, benefit or advantage, either direct or indirect to such person. 
    Gross proceeds. The value proceeding or accruing from the leasing or rental of tangible personal property, without any deduction on account of the cost of the property so leased or rented, the cost of materials used, labor or service cost, interest paid or any other expense whatsoever, and without any deductions on account of loss. 
    Leasing or rental. A transaction whereunder the person who owns or controls the possession of tangible personal property permits another person to have the possession or use thereof for a consideration and for the duration of a definite or indefinite period of time without transfer of the title to such property. 
    Person. Any natural person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, receiver, trust, estate or other entity, or any other group or combination of any thereof acting as a unit. 
(Ord. No. 99-3562, § 7, 10-18-99) 
Sec. 14-80. - Lease or rental of tangible personal property-Tax levied. 
(a)  In addition to all other taxes now imposed by law there is hereby levied and shall be collected as herein provided a privilege or license tax upon each person engaging or continuing within the city in the business of leasing or renting tangible personal property in an amount equal to four (4) percent of the gross proceeds derived by the lessor from the lease or rental of tangible personal property, provided, that the said privilege or license tax on each person engaging or continuing within this city in the business of leasing or renting any automotive vehicle, truck trailer, semitrailer, house trailer or manufactured housing shall be at the rate of one (1) percent of the gross proceeds derived by the lessor from the lease or rental of such automotive vehicle, truck trailer, semi-trailer, house trailer or manufactured housing and, provided, that the said privilege or license tax on each person engaging or continuing within this city in the business of leasing or rental of machines or equipment used in mining, quarrying, compounding, processing, or manufacturing of tangible personal property shall be an amount equal to one and one-half (11/2) percent of the gross proceeds derived by the lessor from the leasing or rental of said machines or equipment. The term "machines," as herein used, shall include machinery which is used for mining, quarrying, compounding, processing, or manufacturing tangible personal property, and the parts of the machines, attachments, and replacements therefor, which are made or manufactured for use on or in the operation of the machines and which are necessary to the operation of the machines and are customarily so used. Provided further, that the tax levied in this section shall not apply to any leasing or rental, as lessor, by the state, or any municipality or county in the state, or any public corporation organized under the laws of the state, including without limiting the generality of the foregoing, any corporation organized under the provisions of Code of Ala. 1975, sections 11-54-80 through 11-54-101, as amended. 
(b)  In addition to all other licenses or taxes now imposed by law or ordinance, there is hereby levied and shall be collected a privilege or license tax on each person engaging or continuing in the police jurisdiction of the city in any of the businesses set out in subsection (a) above, at a rate equal to one-half (1/2) of the rate hereinabove established for engaging in such business within the corporate limits of the city, subject to the provisions of Act 2015-361 enacted by the Alabama Legislature during the 2015 Regular Session. 
(Ord. No. 96-3324, § 1, 8-16-96; Ord. No. 96-3333, § 6, 9-16-96; Ord. No. 99-3562, § 8, 10-18-99; Ord. No. 01-3674, § 5, 9-12-01; Ord. No. 01-3674A, §§ 1, 5, 10-1-01; Ord. No. 15-4246, § 4, 1-19-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 99-3562, § 8, adopted October 18, 1999, amended the Code by renumbering former § 14-79 as a new § 14-80. 
Sec. 14-81. - Same-Application for license. 
    If any person shall engage in or continue in any business for which a privilege or license tax is imposed by section 14-80 of this division as a condition precedent to engaging or continuing in such business, he shall apply for and obtain from the city a license to engage in and conduct such business for the current licensing year upon the condition that he shall pay the taxes accruing to the city under the provisions of this division; provided that no license shall be issued under the provisions of this Code to any person who has not complied with the provisions of this division, and no provision of this section shall be construed as relieving any person from the payment of any privilege or license tax now and hereafter imposed by law. 
(Ord. No. 96-3324, § 1, 8-16-96; Ord. No. 99-3562, § 9, 10-18-99) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 99-3562, § 9, adopted October 18, 1999, amended the Code by renumbering former § 14-80 as a new § 14-81. 
Sec. 14-82. - Same-Exemptions. 
    There are exempted from the provisions of section 14-80 and from the computation of the amount of privilege or license tax levied, assessed or payable under that section, the gross proceeds of such rental or leasing as is exempt under the provisions of section 40-12-223 of the Code of Alabama, 1975, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 96-3324, § 1, 8-16-96; Ord. No. 99-3562, § 10, 10-18-99) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 99-3562, § 10, adopted October 18, 1999, amended the Code by renumbering former § 14-81 as a new § 14-82. 
Sec. 14-83. - Tax due; monthly report. 
(a)  The tax levied under the provisions of this division except as otherwise provided shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding the month in which the tax accrued. On or before the twentieth day of each month, every person on whom the tax levied by the division is imposed shall render to the city, on a form prescribed by the city, a true and correct statement showing the gross proceeds of his business from rental or leasing activities within the city for the next preceding month, the amount of gross proceeds which are not subject to the tax or are not to be used as a measurement of the tax due by such person, together with such other information as the city may require, and at the time of making such monthly report such person shall compute the tax due and pay to the city the amount of tax shown to be due. 
(b)  If any person subject to this division should submit a false return or make a false statement of material facts in the statements or reports required herein, or shall fail to file a report as required, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and may be prosecuted as such. 
(Ord. No. 99-3562, § 11, 10-18-99) 
Sec. 14-84. - Discount for timely payment. 
    Every person subject to this division shall provide the reports and pay the tax before the same become delinquent as described in the provisions of this division. If the reports are not filed within the time herein provided and the taxes not paid on the dates herein provided for, such person shall pay to the city the full amount of the tax due together with interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the date the payment of such became delinquent; a penalty of fifteen (15) percent of the tax; and a citation fee of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50); which interest, penalty and citation fee must be paid by such person. 
(Ord. No. 99-3562, § 12, 10-18-99; Ord. No. 10-4034, § 2, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 14-85. - Construction. 
    This division shall not be held or construed to cancel or repeal any provision of any other ordinance of the city under which a privilege or license tax is levied, but shall be cumulative thereto. 
(Ord. No. 96-3324, § 1, 8-16-96; Ord. No. 99-3562, § 13, 10-18-99) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 99-3562, § 13, adopted October 18, 1999, amended the Code by renumbering former § 14-82 as a new § 14-85. 
Secs. 14-86-14-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRANSIENT OCCUPANCY TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Transient occupancy tax, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-26-1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-101. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning, the words, terms and phrases used in this article shall have the following respective meanings: 
    Person shall mean any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association, administrator, trustee or other fiduciary. 
    Police jurisdiction shall mean the territory outside the corporate limits of the city but within its police jurisdiction. 
    Transient shall mean a person to whom rooms or lodgings are rented for a period of less than one hundred eighty (180) continuous days. 
(Code 1956, § 15-58; Ord. No. 02-3690, § 1, 1-28-02) 
Sec. 14-102. - Construction of article. 
    This article shall not be held or construed to cancel or repeal any other provision of this chapter, or any other ordinances of the city under which a privilege or license tax is levied, but shall be cumulative thereto. 
(Code 1956, § 15-65) 
Sec. 14-103. - Tax levied within city limits; amount. 
    There is hereby levied and imposed in addition to all other taxes of every kind now imposed by law, a privilege or license tax upon every person engaging within the corporate limits of the city in: 
(1)  The business of renting or furnishing any room or rooms or lodgings to transients in any hotel, motel, inn, tourist camp, tourist cabin or any other place in which rooms or lodgings are regularly furnished to transients for a consideration, said tax to be in an amount equal to seven (7) percent of the charge for such room, rooms or lodgings, including the charge for use or rental of personal property and services furnished in such rooms; provided, that charges for property sold or services furnished which are required to be included in the computation of the tax levied in article 1, chapter 23, of title 40 of the Code of Alabama, 1975, said article being commonly referred to as the State Sales Tax Statutes, shall not be included in computing the tax levied in this article. 
(2)  The tax referred to in the foregoing subparagraph (1) shall be subject to all exemptions as provided for in chapter 26 of title 40 of the Code of Alabama, 1975, as may be amended from time to time. 
(3)  As part of the tax levy of this section and subject to the provisions of subparagraph (2) above, there is hereby levied the additional sum of two dollars ($2.00) per rented room for each day of its occupancy, beginning September 1, 2007. 
(Code 1956, § 15-59; Ord. No. 91-3008, § 1, 9-16-91; Ord. No. 98-3397, § 1, 10-6-97; Ord. No. 01-3665, § 1, 7-16-01; Ord. No. 01-3665A, §§ 1, 2, 8-6-01; Ord. No. 02-3690, §§ 2, 3, 1-28-02; Ord. No. 07-3907, § 1, 7-2-07; Ord. No. 10-4048, § 1, 10-18-10) 
Sec. 14-104. - Tax levied in police jurisdiction; amount. 
    There is hereby levied and imposed, in addition to all other taxes of every kind now imposed by law, a privilege or license tax upon every person engaging outside the corporate limits but within the police jurisdiction in: 
(1)  The business of renting or furnishing any room or rooms or lodgings to transients in any hotel, motel, inn, tourist camp, tourist cabin or any other place in which rooms or lodgings are regularly furnished to transients for a consideration, said tax to be in an amount equal to three and one half (3.5) percent of the charge for such room, rooms or lodgings, including the charge for use or rental of personal property and services furnished in such rooms provided, that charges for property sold or services furnished which are required to be included in the computation of the tax levied in article 1, chapter 23, of title 40 of the Code of Alabama, 1975, said article being commonly referred to as the state sales tax statutes, shall not be included in computing the tax levied in this article. 
(2)  The tax referred to in the foregoing subparagraph (1) shall be subject to all exemptions as provided for in chapter 26, of tide 40 of the Code of Alabama, 1975, as may be amended from time to time. 
(3)  As part of the tax levy of this section and subject to the provisions of subparagraph (2) above, there is hereby levied the additional sum of one dollar ($1.00) per rented room for each day of its occupancy, beginning September 1, 2007. 
(Code 1956, § 15-60; Ord. No. 91-3008, § 2, 9-16-91; Ord. No. 98-3397, § 2, 10-6-97; Ord. No. 01-3665, § 2, 7-16-01; Ord. No. 01-3665A, §§ 1, 3, 8-6-01; Ord. No. 02-3690, §§ 4, 5, 1-28-02; Ord. No. 07-3907, § 2, 7-2-07; Ord. No. 10-4048, § 2, 10-18-10) 
Sec. 14-105. - Tax payment date; reports; filing. 
    The taxes levied under the provisions of this article, except as otherwise provided, shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding the month in which the tax accrues. On or before the twentieth day of each month every person on whom the taxes levied herein are imposed, shall render to the city on a form prescribed by the city a true and correct statement showing the gross proceeds of the business subject to said tax for the preceding month, together with such other information as the city may demand and require, and at the time of making such monthly report the taxpayer shall compute the taxes due and shall pay to the city the amount of taxes shown to be due. A failure to render the report and pay the tax as described in this section shall be unlawful and punishable as such. 
(Code 1956, § 15-61; Ord. No. 98-3473, § 14, 7-6-98) 
Sec. 14-106. - Discount; interest; penalty; citation fee. 
    Every person subject to this article may take a discount in an amount equal to one (1) percent of all taxes paid to the city under the provisions of this article, provided the reports are made and the taxes paid before the same shall become delinquent hereunder. Notwithstanding this provision, no discount shall be allowed for the tax levied by subsection 14-103(3), or subsection 14-104(3) of this article. If reports are not filed within the time herein provided and the taxes not paid on the dates herein provided for, such person shall pay to the city the full amount of tax together with interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the date the payment of such tax became delinquent; a penalty of fifteen (15) percent of the amount of the tax; and a citation fee of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50); which interest, penalty, and citation fee must be paid by such person. 
(Code 1956, § 15-63; Ord. No. 98-3473, § 15, 7-6-98; Ord. No. 99-3562, § 15, 10-18-99; Ord. No. 01-3667, § 1, 7-16-01) 
Sec. 14-107. - Businesses conducted on credit basis; method of reporting. 
    Any person subject to the taxes herein levied who conducts business on a credit basis may defer reporting credit rentals and charges until after their collection, and in the event he so refers reporting them, he shall thereafter include in each monthly report all credit collections made during the then preceding month and shall pay the amount of taxes measured thereby at the time of filing such report. 
(Code 1956, § 15-62) 
Sec. 14-108. - Preservation of records; inspection. 
    It shall be the duty of every person engaging in continuing in any business subject to the taxes herein levied to keep and preserve suitable records of the gross proceeds of such business and such other books or accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of tax for which he is liable under the provisions of this article. Such records shall be open for examination by the revenue department, or any duly authorized representative of the city, at any reasonable time during regular business hours. A failure to maintain or produce the described records, or a refusal to allow the examination of such records by the city shall be unlawful and punishable as such. 
(Code 1956, § 15-64; Ord. No. 98-3473, § 16, 7-6-98) 
Secs. 14-109-14-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AMUSEMENTS 

Sec. 14-121. - Article declared cumulative. 
    This article shall not be held or construed to cancel or repeal any provision of any other ordinance of the city under which a privilege or license tax is levied, but shall be cumulative thereto. 
(Code 1956, § 15-53) 
Sec. 14-122. - Tax levied-In city. 
    There is hereby levied, in addition to all other taxes of every kind and nature now imposed by law, and shall be collected as provided in this article, a privilege or license tax upon every person engaged or continuing within the city in the business of conducting or operating, places of amusement or entertainment, billiard and pool rooms, bowling alleys, amusement devices, musical devices, theaters, opera houses, moving picture shows, vaudevilles, amusement parks, athletic contests, including wrestling matches, prize fights, boxing and wrestling exhibitions, football and baseball games (including athletic contests conducted by or under the auspices of any educational institution within this state, any athletic association thereof, or any other association whether the institution or association be a denominational, state, county, or municipal institution or association; a state, county or city school; or other institution, association or school), skating rinks, race tracks, golf courses or any other place at which any exhibition, display, amusement or entertainment is offered to the public or place or places where an admission fee is charged, including public bathing places, public dance halls of every kind and description within the city, in an amount equal to four (4) percent of the gross receipts of any such business. Provided, however, notwithstanding any language to the contrary in the prior portion of this section, the tax provisions so specified shall not apply to any athletic event conducted by a public primary or secondary school or any football playoff conducted by or under the auspices of the Alabama High School Athletic Association. The tax amount which would have been collected pursuant to this section shall continue to be collected by the public primary or secondary school but shall be retained by the school which collected it and shall be used by the school for school purposes. 
(Code 1956, § 15-47; Ord. No. 2230, § 1, 5-5-80; Ord. No. 01-3674, § 6, 9-12-01; Ord. No. 01-3674A, §§ 1, 6, 10-1-01) 
Sec. 14-123. - Same-In police jurisdiction. 
    There is hereby levied, in addition to all other taxes of every kind and nature now imposed by law, and shall be collected as provided in this article, a privilege or license tax upon every person engaged or continuing outside the corporate limits but within the police jurisdiction of the city in the business of conducting or operating places of amusement or entertainment, billiard and pool rooms, bowling alleys, amusement devices, musical devices, theaters, opera houses, moving picture shows, vaudevilles, amusement parks, athletic contests, including wrestling matches, prize fights, boxing and wrestling exhibitions, football and baseball games (including athletic contests conducted by or under the auspices of any educational institution within this state, any athletic association thereof, or any other association whether the institution or association be a denominational, state, county, or municipal institution or association; a state, county or city school; or other institution, association or school), skating rinks, race tracks, golf courses or any other place at which any exhibition, display, amusement or entertainment to the public or place or places where an admission fee is charged, including public bathing places, public dance halls of every kind and description outside the corporate limits but within the police jurisdiction of the city, in an amount equal to two (2) percent of the gross receipts of any such business. Provided, however, notwithstanding any language to the contrary in the prior portion of this section, the tax provisions so specified shall not apply to any athletic event conducted by a public primary or secondary school or any football playoff conducted by or under the auspices of the Alabama High School Athletic Association. The tax amount which would have been collected pursuant to this section shall continue to be collected by the public primary or secondary school but shall be retained by the school which collected it and shall be used by the school for school purposes. 
(Code 1956, § 15-48; Ord. No. 01-3674, § 7, 9-12-01; Ord. No. 01-3674A, §§ 1, 7, 10-1-01) 
Sec. 14-124. - When due, payable; reports required. 
    The tax levied under the provisions of this article, except as otherwise provided, shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding the month in which the tax accrued. On or before the twentieth day of each month, every person on whom the tax is levied or imposed by this article shall render to the city, on a form prescribed by the city, a true and correct statement showing the gross receipts of such business for the next preceding month; provided however, should such business be itinerant in nature, so that such business shall not be in operation to the twentieth of the following month, the tax levied hereunder shall be due and payable upon the last day of such business operation, or the twentieth day of the next succeeding month, whichever occurs first. 
(Code 1956, § 15-49) 
Sec. 14-125. - Discounts for prompt payment; delinquency. 
    Every person subject to this article may take a discount in an amount equal to one (1) percent of all taxes paid to the city under the provisions of this article, provided the reports are made and the taxes paid before the same become delinquent hereunder. If reports are not filed within the time herein provided and the taxes not paid on the dates herein provided for, such person shall pay to the city the full amount of tax together with interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the date the payment of such tax became delinquent; a penalty of fifteen (15) percent of the amount of the tax; and a citation fee of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50); which interest, penalty, and citation fee must be paid by such person. 
(Code 1956, § 15-52; Ord. No. 99-3562, § 15, 10-18-99) 
Sec. 14-126. - Records. 
    It shall be the duty of every person engaging or continuing within the city and within the police jurisdiction of the city in any business on which a tax is imposed by this article to keep and preserve suitable records of the gross receipts of such business as may be necessary to determine the amount of tax for which such business is liable under the provisions of this article for a period of two (2) years and to maintain the same open for inspection at all reasonable times by the city clerk or any person designated by him. 
(Code 1956, § 15-50) 
Secs. 14-127-14-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TOBACCO TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 94-3198, § 1, adopted April 4, 1994, amended former Art. VI to read as herein set out. Former Art. VI, §§ 14-141-14-149, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1956 and the following ordinances: Ord. No. 84-2417, § 1, 12-3-84; Ord. No. 90-2949, §§ 1-12, 10-1-90; Ord. No. 91-2968, § 1, 1-7-91. 

Sec. 14-141. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning, the following words and phrases, wherever used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section: 
    Cigarette means a roll of finely cut tobacco or any substitutes therefor enclosed in paper prepared for smoking by individuals. 
    Dealer means any wholesale or retail dealer as defined in this section. 
    Monthly statement means the report made to the city clerk by means of which the taxes levied under this Article on all tobacco products, except cigarettes, are paid. 
    Package means the individual box or other container from which or in which retail sales of tobacco products mentioned herein are normally made or intended to be made. 
    Retail dealer means any person, other than a wholesale dealer, who sells or delivers tobacco products within the city or its police jurisdiction, and any person operating under a retail dealer's license. 
    Retail price means the retail selling price of the tobacco products before adding the amount of the tax assessed herein or any tobacco tax assessed by the state. 
    Sold and sale means any transfer of title or possession, or both, exchange or barter, conditional or otherwise, in any manner or by any means whatsoever for a consideration or any agreement therefor, including rewards, prizes or premiums of tobacco products given as a result of operations on punch boards, shooting galleries or other activities. 
    Stamps means the stamp or stamps by the use of which the taxes levied on the sale of cigarettes under this article are paid. 
    Store and stored means the storage or warehousing of tobacco products in any manner, or the withdrawal or use of the same for any purpose, other than for resale or reshipment outside the city or its police jurisdiction. 
    Tobacco products means cigarettes, cigars, chewing tobacco, smoking tobacco, snuff or any substitute therefor. 
    Wholesale dealer means a person who sells or delivers within the city or its police jurisdiction, at wholesale only, tobacco products to retail dealers for the purpose of resale only. 
(Ord. No. 94-3198, § 1, 4-4-94) 
Sec. 14-142. - Construction. 
(a)  This article shall not be construed to tax interstate commerce or any business of the United States government or any branch or agency thereof. 
(b)  This article shall not be construed to apply to tobacco products stored for the purpose of resale or reshipment outside the city and its police jurisdiction and which are actually so resold or reshipped. 
(c)  This article shall not be construed to repeal any of the provisions of the general license provisions of the city, but shall be held to be cumulative. 
(d)  Whenever the requisite amount of stamps has been affixed to cigarette packages or the required amount of taxes paid on the monthly statement for other tobacco products as required in this article, this article shall not be construed to require additional stamps to be affixed thereto in case of subsequent sales, deliveries or storage; provided, that where such cigarettes or other tobacco products have been properly stamped or the taxes paid on the monthly statement for sale, delivery or storage within the police jurisdiction, then before the same can be sold, delivered or stored in the corporate limits of the city there must be properly affixed to such cigarettes and properly canceled an equal amount of stamps to those already affixed and sales reported and taxes paid on all other tobacco products on the required monthly statement. 
(Ord. No. 94-3198, § 1, 4-4-94) 
Sec. 14-143. - Tax levied-In city. 
    In addition to all other taxes of every kind now imposed by law, every person who sells, stores or delivers tobacco products in the corporate limits of the city shall pay a license tax to the city, and a license tax is hereby fixed and levied, for the sale, storage or delivery of tobacco products in the corporate limits of the city in the following amounts: 
(1)  Cigarettes. A license tax in the sum of eight cents ($0.08) for each package of cigarettes so sold, stored or delivered. 
(2)  Cigars, including cheroots, stogies. A license tax in the sum of four cents ($0.04) for each cigar, or substitute therefor, so sold, stored or delivered. 
(3)  Chewing tobacco. A license tax in the sum of eight cents ($0.08) for each package of chewing tobacco prepared in such a manner as to be suitable for chewing only and not suitable for smoking so sold, stored or delivered. 
(4)  Smoking tobacco. A license tax in the sum of eight cents ($0.08) for each package of smoking tobacco including granulated, plug cut, crimp cut, ready rubbed and other kinds and forms of tobacco prepared in such a manner as to be suitable for smoking in a pipe or cigarette so sold, stored, or delivered. 
(5)  Snuff and other tobacco products used in a similar manner. A license tax in the sum of eight cents ($0.08) for each package of all snuff and other tobacco products used in a similar manner, not smoked or chewed, so sold, stored, or delivered. 
(Ord. No. 94-3198, § 1, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 03-3766, § 1, 8-18-03) 
Sec. 14-144. - Same-In police jurisdiction. 
    In addition to all taxes now imposed by law, every person who sells, stores or delivers tobacco products in the police jurisdiction of the city shall pay a license tax to the city, and a license tax is hereby fixed and levied, for the sale, storage or delivery of tobacco products in the police jurisdiction of the city, which license tax shall be in an amount equal to one-half (1/2) of the license tax fixed and levied in section 14-143 for each package of respective tobacco products so sold, stored or delivered. 
(Ord. No. 94-3198, § 1, 4-4-94) 
Sec. 14-145. - Stamps-Sold by city clerk; inscription; sale to wholesalers and others; monthly statements. 
(a)  The city clerk shall keep on hand for sale an adequate quantity of stamps to be affixed to each package of cigarettes in denominations as required under this article. Each such stamp shall have inscribed thereon the words "City of Decatur-Tobacco Tax" but such words need not be arranged in the foregoing order and may be abbreviated. Such stamps may be sold by the city clerk to licensed wholesale dealers only at a price equal to ninety (90) percent of the full amount thereof, the remaining ten (10) percent of such full amount representing compensation to the wholesale dealer for the labor of affixing such stamps to the packages in which the cigarettes are contained. All other persons, except such wholesale dealers, must pay the full face amount of the stamps, but no person shall be entitled to purchase any such number of stamps as shall cause the purchase price to include a fraction of a cent. 
(b)  On or before the twentieth day of each month, every wholesaler dealer and/or retail dealer of tobacco products upon which a tax is levied by this article shall file with the city clerk a true and correct monthly statement of all tobacco products, other than cigarettes, sold, delivered or stored within the city or its police jurisdiction during the preceding month, for which he is or shall be liable for the payment of the tax. 
Every person subject to this article may take a discount in an amount equal to one (1) percent of all taxes paid to the city under the provisions of this article, provided the reports are made and the taxes paid before the same become delinquent hereunder. If reports are not filed within the time herein provided and the taxes not paid on the dates herein provided for, such person shall pay to the city the full amount of tax together with interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the date the payment of such tax became delinquent; a penalty of fifteen (15) percent of the amount of the tax; and a citation fee on one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50); which interest, penalty, and citation fee must be paid by such person. 
(Ord. No. 94-3198, § 1, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 99-3562, § 16, 10-18-99) 
Sec. 14-146. - Affixing; canceling cigarette stamps. 
    Before any cigarettes shall be sold, stored or delivered within the corporate limits of the city or its police jurisdiction by any dealer, such dealer shall affix to each package of cigarettes a stamp or stamps obtain from the city clerk in the amounts set out in this article in payment of the license taxes imposed by this article. Every dealer shall, within one (1) hour alter receipt of any cigarettes within the city or its police jurisdiction, unless sooner offered for sale, cause stamps to the requisite amount of the tax to be affixed as herein provided and shall cause the same to be canceled by writing or stamping with waterproof ink across the face of each stamp such registered number as shall be furnished to such dealer by the city clerk. Alter such stamping has been begun, it shall be continued with reasonable diligence by such dealer until all unstamped cigarettes shall have been stamped and the stamps canceled as herein provided, but no stamp required to be affixed to any package of cigarettes shall, after the same has been affixed as herein provided, be again used in payment of any part of the tax levied under this article. Such stamps shall be affixed in such manner that their removal will require continued application of water or steam. In the case of cigarettes sold by retail in packages, the stamps shall be affixed to each individual package in such a way that such stamps shall be torn in two (2) or mutilated when such package is opened. 
(Ord. No. 94-3198, § 1, 4-4-94) 
Sec. 14-147. - Disposition of proceeds. 
(a)  One-half (1/2) of all proceeds derived from the tax levied in this article within the corporate limits of the city shall be paid by the city treasurer, as collected, to the custodian of the public school funds of the city and shall be used solely for the operation and maintenance of the public schools of the city. The remaining one-half (1/2) of the proceeds derived from the taxes herein levied within the corporate limits of the city shall be placed in the general fund account of the city subject to appropriation by the city council for any lawful purpose of the city. 
(b)  All proceeds from the taxes levied in this article in the police jurisdiction of the city, and all revenues derived in the police jurisdiction of the city, and all revenues derived in the police jurisdiction from the license taxes herein levied in the police jurisdiction of the city, shall be placed in the general fund account of the city and shall be used for police regulatory purposes and for none other. 
(Ord. No. 94-3198, § 1, 4-4-94) 
Sec. 14-148. - Records; report of sale of unstamped cigarettes. 
    Every wholesale dealer shall, at the time of selling or delivering tobacco products into the city or its police jurisdiction, make a true duplicate invoice of the same, which shall show full and complete details of the sale or delivery of such tobacco products and the prices thereof. Every wholesale dealer and every retail dealer shall keep a record of the purchase, sale, exchange or receipt of tobacco products. All such invoices and records and all canceled checks and other memoranda pertaining to any such purchase, sale, exchange or receipt shall be retained for a period of three (3) years and shall be subject to inspection of the city clerk or his duly authorized deputy, who shall have the power and authority to enter upon the premises of any dealer at all reasonable times for the purpose of examining such invoices, records, canceled checks and other memoranda. Any person who purchases or receives in any manner whatsoever cigarettes which do not have stamps affixed or other tobacco products on which sales have not been reported and taxes paid in the manner required by this article shall, within three (3) days after receipt of such cigarettes or other tobacco products, report the receipt and purchase thereof to the city clerk, giving the date of purchase or receipt, the name of the person from whom purchased or received and a list describing the cigarettes and/or other tobacco products so purchased or received and the purchase price thereof. Such report must be made by registered mail or in person. 
(Ord. No. 94-3198, § 1, 4-4-94) 
Sec. 14-149. - Illegal acts. 
    Among others, the following acts and omissions shall be unlawful: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is required by this article to affix stamps to cigarettes to fail to affix such stamps or to cancel such stamps in the manner or within the time required by this article. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, store or deliver within the city or its police jurisdiction any cigarettes where stamps have not been affixed and cancelled or other tobacco products on which sales have not been reported and taxes paid as provided in this article. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession or under his control, any cigarettes where stamps have not been affixed or other tobacco products on which sales have not been reported and taxes paid in the manner required by this article for more than six (6) hours after receipt of such cigarettes or other tobacco products on the premises of such person. The possession of each package of cigarettes not having proper stamps affixed or other tobacco products on which sales have not been reported and taxes paid as required by this article shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, buy, sell, offer for sale or possess, or attempt so to do, any reproduction or counterfeit of the stamps provided for in this article or to possess tools, implements, instruments or materials of any kind necessary or appropriate to reproduce or counterfeit such stamps, or to alter or cause to be altered any stamps herein provided for. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove from a package or otherwise prepare any stamp with intent to use or cause the same to be used, after it has already been used, or to buy, sell, offer for sale or give away any washed, removed, altered or restored stamp to any person, or to have in possession any such washed or removed or restored or altered stamp, or, for the purpose of indicating payment of any tax under this article, to reuse any stamp which has theretofore been used for the payment of any tax provided in this article or to sell any stamp provided for herein except as to sales made by the city clerk. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for any person to reuse or refill with cigarettes any package from which cigarettes have been removed and with respect to which the tax has theretofore been paid. 
(7)  It shall be unlawful for any person, who is in this article required to keep records, to fail or omit to keep the same in the manner herein provided, or to refuse to permit the city clerk or his duly authorized deputy to inspect the same at any reasonable hour, or to interfere with or obstruct the city clerk or his duly authorized deputy in the making of any such inspection. 
(8)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is in this article required to file statements with the city clerk to fail or omit to make or file any statement herein provided within the time herein specified, or to make any false statement therein, and such offense shall be a continuing offense against the city and each day during which such person shall sell, store or deliver cigarettes or other tobacco products in the city or its police jurisdiction during such default shall constitute a separate offense. 
(9)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is required to pay the license tax provided for in this article to fail or omit to pay the same within the time herein specified, and such offense shall be a continuing offense against the city and each day during which such person shall sell, store or deliver tobacco products in the city or, its police jurisdiction during such default shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 94-3198, § 1, 4-4-94) 
Secs. 14-150-14-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - GASOLINE AND GASOLINE PRODUCTS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Licensing of distributors of motor fuels, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-190 et seq.; gasoline tax, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-17-30 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-166. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article: 
    Distributor shall include any person who engages in the business of selling or delivering gasoline, as defined in this section, within the city or its police jurisdiction in wholesale quantities, or who ships, hauls, transports or delivers gasoline in wholesale quantities from this storage plant, point or place of business within the city or its police jurisdiction to any other place or point within or without the city. 
    Gasoline shall include gasoline, wocopep, naphtha and all other liquid motor fuels or substitutes ordinarily used in internal combustion engines; provided, that nothing contained in this chapter shall be held to apply to those products ordinarily known as "kerosene oil," "fuel oil" or "crude oil" used for lighting and heating purposes. 
    Seller shall include every person who engages in the business of selling gasoline within the city or its police jurisdiction at retail or in broken quantities. 
(Code 1956, § 11-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-190. 
Sec. 14-167. - Delivery of gasoline into city by truck; permit. 
(a)  Every person delivering gasoline by truck from a point outside the city or its police jurisdiction to a point within the city or its police jurisdiction shall first obtain from the city clerk a permit to deliver such gasoline. Before the city clerk shall issue any permit for the delivery of gasoline by truck from a point outside the city or its police jurisdiction to a point within the city or its police jurisdiction, he shall cause each separate delivery of such gasoline to be carefully measured and shall keep a record in his office showing the name of the person delivering such gasoline, the person to whom delivered, the amount of gasoline so delivered and the date of delivery. A separate permit shall be obtained for each separate delivery of gasoline made by truck. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and each separate delivery of gasoline without a permit as required herein shall be a separate offense. 
(Code 1956, § 11-9) 
Secs. 14-168-14-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE TAX 

Sec. 14-181. - Sale of gasoline. 
    Every distributor or seller of gasoline within the city shall pay to the city a license tax of two cents ($0.02) on and for each and every gallon of gasoline sold within the city, and every distributor or seller of gasoline within the police jurisdiction of the city shall pay to the city a license tax of one cent ($0.01) on each and every gallon of gasoline sold within the police jurisdiction of the city; provided that, where a distributor pays a license tax on any gasoline sold to a seller, no other further or additional license tax shall be required of the seller for the sale or delivery thereof at retail or in broken quantities, the intention being that the license tax shall not be paid but once. 
(Code 1956, § 11-2) 
Sec. 14-182. - Distribution of gasoline and oils. 
    Every distributor or seller of gasoline within the city shall pay to the city a license tax of two cents ($0.02) for each and every gallon of gasoline shipped, hauled, transported or delivered by him at or from his storage plant, point or place of business in the city to any other place or point within the city, and every distributor or seller of gasoline doing business within the police jurisdiction of the city shall pay to the city a license tax of one cent ($0.01) for each and every gallon of gasoline shipped, hauled, transported or delivered by him within the police jurisdiction of the city; at or from his storage plant, point or place of business within the police jurisdiction of the city to any other place or point within the police jurisdiction of the city; provided, that the license tax under this section shall not be required on any gasoline sold within the city and thereafter shipped, hauled, transported or delivered within the police jurisdiction of the city where the license tax for the sale thereof shall be paid. 
(Code 1956, § 11-3) 
Sec. 14-183. - Paid once. 
    The intention of the preceding two (2) sections is that the license tax therein provided for shall only be paid once. Such license tax shall not be collected on gasoline or other motor fuel sold to a distributor, as defined by this chapter, for sale to a seller, as defined by this chapter. 
(Code 1956, § 11-4) 
Sec. 14-184. - When due; monthly statement; payment. 
    The tax levied under the provisions of this article shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding the month in which the tax accrued. On or before the twentieth day of each month, every distributor or seller of gasoline shall file with the city clerk a true and correct monthly statement in writing of all gasoline sold, shipped, hauled, transported or delivered during the preceding month, for which he is or shall be liable for the payment of the license tax and shall, in each and every instance, upon the filing of the statement, furnish to the clerk such additional information, either oral or in writing, as the clerk may require as to the sale, payment, hauling, transportation or delivery of any gasoline covered by such statement and shall, at the time of making such statement, pay to the city clerk, for the city, the amount of the license tax for the preceding month covered by such statement. 
(Code 1956, § 11-6) 
Sec. 14-185. - Failure to file statement or pay tax. 
    If the reports required by this division are not filed within the time herein provided and the taxes not paid on the dates herein provided for, such person shall pay to the city the full amount of the tax together with interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the date the payment of such tax became delinquent to the date of payment; a penalty of fifteen (15) percent of the amount of the tax; and, a citation fee of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50); which interest, penalty, and citation fee must be paid by such person. 
(Code 1956, § 11-8; Ord. No. 99-3562, § 17, 10-18-99) 
Sec. 14-186. - Carriers to furnish tax officer with information. 
    Every common carrier of freight in the city, either railroad, truck or any other common carrier, delivering gasoline or any other petroleum product by whatever name known to any person in the city, or any agent or employee of any common carrier who has charge of the books and records containing such information, shall, on demand, furnish to the officer of the city charged with the duty of collecting the gasoline tax and enforcing the gasoline laws and ordinances, all information available from the books and records of such common carrier as to all shipments of gasoline to any person in the city or its police jurisdiction. 
(Code 1956, § 11-7) 
Sec. 14-187. - Interstate commerce. 
    The license tax fixed and created by this article shall not apply to the sale, shipment, hauling, transportation or delivery of gasoline in interstate commerce. 
(Code 1956, § 11-5) 
Secs. 14-188-14-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - METERS ON PUMPS 

Sec. 14-201. - Required. 
    Every person selling gasoline at retail within the city or its police jurisdiction shall have the gasoline measured through meters, and every gasoline pump or other container, by whatever name called, through which gasoline is delivered, shall be equipped with a meter. 
(Code 1956, § 11-10) 
Sec. 14-202. - Refusal to permit installation or reading. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person retailing gasoline or other liquid motor fuel or consuming gasoline by use of a pump, tank or other container to refuse to permit any authorized representative of the city either to install a meter on any pump, tank or other container belonging to such person, or to read at any time any gasoline meter installed on any gasoline pump, tank or other container, within the city or its police jurisdiction, whether installed by the city or not. 
(b)  Each day any person fails or refuses to allow the meter to be installed on the tank, pump or container, or who fails and refuses to allow any authorized representative of the city to read the meter so installed shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1956, § 11-12) 
Sec. 14-203. - Type; mode of attachment; reading. 
    The gasoline or other liquid motor fuel meters required in this article shall be of a standard type to meet specifications laid down by the officials of the city. The same shall be subject to inspection at all times by the officials or their agents, and the meters shall be read at prescribed intervals by the city officials or their agents. The meters shall be properly attached to the pumps or containers so as to show the true reading and measurements of the gasoline discharged therefrom and shall be so attached as to be conveniently read. 
(Code 1956, § 11-11) 
Sec. 14-204. - Filling station license. 
    The city clerk shall issue no license for the operation of any gasoline filling station unless and until the pumps and containers used and to be used in such station shall be equipped with meters. 
(Code 1956, § 11-15) 
Sec. 14-205. - Pumps of nondealers. 
(a)  Each pump, tank or other container owned and used by any consumer of gasoline who is not a dealer shall be equipped with a meter to indicate the true measurement of gasoline discharged therefrom; provided, however, that the city may elect to require that such person within the city or its police jurisdiction, owning and possessing such pump, tank or other container for private consumption of gasoline or other liquid motor fuel, and who is not a retail dealer, file with the city clerk on or before the tenth day of each month a sworn written statement showing the amount and quantity of gasoline or other liquid motor fuel discharged by the pump, tank or other container, or otherwise withdrawn therefrom during the calendar month next preceding, in lieu of the requirement that such meter be attached. 
(b)  In the event the city should so elect in any case, any person failing or omitting to make such statement or who shall make any false statement shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(c)  Private consumers must include in such monthly report on a form furnished by the city the name of each person from whom gasoline is purchased and the amount purchased from each such person. 
(Code 1956, § 11-14) 
Sec. 14-206. - Changing; tampering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person retailing gasoline or other liquid motor fuel or consuming gasoline by use of a pump, tank or other container to change, set back, alter or tamper with any meter on any pump, tank or other container or turn back the reading on same, except under orders of officials of the city, in which case a correct record shall be made and kept of the reading of the meters and any turning back of the indicators on the same. 
(Code 1956, § 11-13) 
Secs. 14-207-14-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - GARAGE SALES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 89-2804, adopted Jan. 16, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-8 as Art. VIII, §§ 14-221-14-228, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 14-221. - Defined. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "garage sale" shall mean and include all sales entitled "garage sale," "lawn sale," "attic sale," "rummage sale," "flea market sale," or any other similar casual sale of tangible personal property whereby there is a display and offer for sale of any goods, wares or merchandise, on the premises of any residential lot within the city limits of the city, which goods, wares or merchandise are household furnishings or personal possessions of the persons conducting the sale and residing at the premises. 
(Ord. No. 89-2804, § 1, 1-16-89; Ord. No. 92-3068, § 1, 5-18-92) 
Sec. 14-222. - Property acquired for resale not to be offered for sale at garage sales. 
    The offer for sale by means of a "garage sale" of property which has been specifically acquired for resale, or the consignment of which has been accepted for display and offer for sale at a "garage sale" is specifically prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 89-2804, § 2, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 14-223. - Duration. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hold a garage sale of longer duration than three (3) consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. 89-2804, § 3, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 14-224. - Limited number per calendar year. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hold or conduct more than two (2) garage sales within the same calendar year. Provided; however, that under no circumstances shall the same residential lot be used for more than a total of two (2) garage sales within the same calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 89-2804, § 4, 1-16-89; Ord. No. 90-2953, § 1, 10-15-90) 
Sec. 14-225. - Permit-Generally. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a garage sale in the city without first filing with the city clerk the information hereinafter specified and obtaining from such clerk a permit to do so, to be known as a "garage sale permit." There shall be no fee charged for the permit to a person for conducting the garage sale. 
(b)  Display. Each permit issued under this article must be prominently displayed on the premises upon which the garage sale is conducted throughout the entire period of the permitted sale. 
(Ord. No. 89-2804, § 5, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 14-226. - Same-Information required. 
    The information to be filed with the city clerk, pursuant to the article shall be as follows: 
(1)  Name of each person conducting the sale. 
(2)  Name of owner of the property on which the sale is to be conducted, and consent of owner, if applicant is other than the owner. 
(3)  Location at which sale is to be conducted. 
(4)  Number of days of sale and the hours that sale will be conducted. 
(5)  Date, nature of any past sale. 
(6)  Relationship or connection applicant may have had with any other person conducting the sale and the date or dates of such sale. 
(7)  Whether or not applicant has been issued any other vendor's license by any local, state or federal agency. 
(8)  Sworn statement or affirmation by the person signing that the information therein is full and true and known to that person to be so. 
(Ord. No. 89-2804, § 6, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 14-227. - Exception to provisions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following persons or sales: 
(1)  Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
(3)  Any person selling or advertising for sale an item or items of personal property which are specifically named or described in the advertisement and which separate items do not exceed five (5) in number. 
(Ord. No. 89-2804, § 7, 1-16-89) 
Sec. 14-228. - Violation; penalties. 
    Any person conducting any garage sale without obtaining the proper permit or who shall violate any of the other terms and regulations of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 89-2804, § 8, 1-16-89) 
Chapter 15 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; costs and fees, § 1-9. 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-1 et seq.; magistrates, Rule 18, Ala. Rules of Judicial Administration, Code of Ala. 1975, Vol. 23. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Definition. 
    Unless the context otherwise clearly appears, a reference in this chapter to the "municipal judge" shall mean each municipal judge serving as such. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-4) 
Sec. 15-2. - Established. 
    There is hereby established, effective December 27, 1977, a municipal court for the city, pursuant to the provisions of Act 1205, 1975 Regular Session of the Legislature of Alabama, codified as Code of Ala. 1975, sections 12-14-1 to 12-14-71, inclusive. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-1) 
State Law reference- Establishment of municipal courts, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-1. 
Sec. 15-3. - Jurisdiction. 
    The municipal court of the city shall have jurisdiction of all prosecutions for the breach of ordinances and Code provisions of the city within its corporate limits and police jurisdiction. This jurisdiction shall also extend to all prosecutions for violations of state misdemeanors committed within the corporate limits and police jurisdiction of the city where such offenses have been made offenses against the city. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-1. 
Sec. 15-4. - Powers. 
    The municipal court and each municipal judge thereof shall have all of the powers, prerogatives and authority as are now or may hereafter be conferred upon or granted to municipal courts and municipal judges by Act No. 1205, 1975 Regular Session of the Legislature of Alabama, codified as Code of Ala. 1975, sections 12-14-1 to 12-14-71, inclusive, and other applicable legislation or rule. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-6) 
State Law reference- Powers of municipal judges generally, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 12-14-31, 12-14-32. 
Sec. 15-5. - Time and place of holding court. 
    The municipal court of the city shall hold court at the City Hall, 402 Lee Street, N. E., Decatur, Alabama, in the municipal courtroom provided therefor, unless otherwise ordered by the municipal judge, each Monday, Wednesday and Friday morning at 7:00 a.m., except when such days are legal holidays, in which event court shall not be held on such day. Court may be held at such other times and from time to time as shall be directed by the municipal judge. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-3) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-3. 
Sec. 15-6. - Cash bail bonds. 
(a)  The municipal judges and any other municipal officer designated by the presiding judge shall be authorized to approve appearance and appeal bonds on criminal charges for violation of any section of this Code or other ordinance of the city within the city or its police jurisdiction. 
(b)  The municipal judge may forfeit such cash bonds placed with the chief of police by persons arrested for violation of any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city for their appearance in municipal court upon the failure of the person arrested to appear in accordance with the terms of such bail. 
(c)  All cash bonds heretofore accepted by the chief of police and heretofore forfeited by the persons charged with violation of any provision of this Code or other city ordinance by their failure to appear in the municipal court and upon which the municipal judge has entered a forfeiture shall be and are hereby forfeited to the city. 
(d)  All such cash bonds forfeited to the city shall be immediately paid by the chief of police to the city clerk. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-7) 
State Law reference- Admission to bail of persons charged with violations of municipal ordinances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-5; cash deposit generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 15-13-40 et seq.; discretionary bond schedule, Rule 2, Ala. Rules of Judicial Administration, Code of Ala. 1975, Vol. 23; approval of bonds, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-31. 
Sec. 15-7. - Code section violations. 
(a)  Any law enforcement officer of the city or any law enforcement officer of the state, in lieu of placing persons under custodial arrest, is hereby authorized to issue a summons and complaint to any person charged with violating any city municipal littering code section; city municipal code section which prohibits animals from running at large, which shall include leash laws and rabies control laws; city sound control code section; city license and business regulation code section; city buildings and building regulations code section; or any city municipal ordinance or code section not involving violence, threat of violence or alcohol or drugs. 
(b)  Such summons and complaint shall be on a form approved by the governing body of the city and shall contain the name of the defendant; a description of the offense, including the municipal ordinance number or code section; the date and time of the offense; the place of the offense; signature of the officer issuing the citation; the scheduled court date and time; an explanation to the person cited of ways in which he or she may settle his or her case; and a signature block for the magistrate to sign upon the officer's oath and affirmation given prior to trial. 
(c)  When a person is charged with one of the enumerated ordinance or code section violations, he or she may elect to appear before the municipal court magistrate, within the time specified in the summons and complaint, and upon entering a plea of guilty, pay the fine and court costs. A plea of guilty shall only be accepted by the magistrate after the defendant has executed a notice and waiver of rights form. In the alternative, the defendant shall have the option of depositing the required bail, and upon a plea of not guilty, shall be entitled to a trial as authorized by law. 
(d)  If the defendant fails to appear as specified in the summons and complaint, the judge or magistrate may issue a warrant for his or her arrest commanding that he or she be brought before the court to answer the charge contained on the summons and complaint. In addition, any person who willfully violates his or her written promise or bond to appear, given in accordance with this section, shall be guilty of the separate offense of failing to appear, a misdemeanor, regardless of the disposition of the charge upon which he or she was originally arrested. 
(Ord. No. 92-3033, § 1, 3-16-92) 
Sec. 15-8. - Court costs. 
    In addition to municipal court costs assessed and collected by the municipal court of the city pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, section 12-14-14, and section 1-9 of the Code of Decatur, Alabama the city hereby levies and assesses and directs its municipal court to collect the following costs: 
(1)  For any traffic offense, including driving under the influence, there is hereby assessed an additional seventy dollars and fifty cents ($70.50) in court costs, but such additional court costs assessed shall not be in excess of the court costs and fees in the applicable county district court for a similar case on each case filed, as authorized by Code of Ala., 1975, section 11-47-7.1. Such additional court costs shall be collected by the municipal court of the city and remitted as provided by this section. 
(2)  For any misdemeanor offense, there is hereby assessed an additional one hundred eleven dollars ($111.00) in court costs, but such additional court costs assessed shall not be in excess of the court costs and fees in the applicable county district court for a similar case on each case filed, as authorized by Code of Ala. 1975, section 11-47-7.1. Such additional court costs and fees shall be collected by the municipal court of the city and remitted as provided by this section. 
(3)  For violation of any municipal ordinance, the municipal court shall also collect as cost all additional costs and fees imposed by statute of the state for such cases and all such costs and fees shall be remitted as required by said statutes. 
(4)  All costs and fees collected under subsections (1) and (2) of this section shall be remitted to a special fund designated as the city's corrections fund, which the city clerk-treasurer is hereby authorized and directed to establish. Funds deposited into the corrections fund shall be used only for the purposes permitted by Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-7.1. 
(Ord. No. 97-3394, § 1, 9-15-97; Ord. No. 15-4238, § 1 , 9-21-15) 
Sec. 15-9. - Schedule of fines. 
    Pursuant to Section (c) of Rule 20 of the Rules of Judicial Administration, the supreme court's extended schedule of fines appearing as Appendix B of said Rule 20, as amended, is hereby adopted in whole, whereby a defendant may elect to plead guilty before a municipal court magistrate to a misdemeanor or violation listed in said schedule. 
    The adoption and use of the above described schedule is subject to the provisions, requirements, limitations and procedures contained in said Rule 20, as last amended. 
(Ord. No. 04-3805, § 1, 5-17-04) 
Secs. 15-10-15-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - JUDGES 

Sec. 15-21. - Appointment; terms. 
(a)  The municipal court shall consist of one (1) full-time municipal judge to be appointed by a vote of the majority of the members elected or appointed to the governing body. The term of office of each full-time judge shall be four (4) years. The governing body may appoint as many part-time municipal judges as it deems necessary in the same manner as the full-time judge is appointed. The term of any part-time judge shall be two (2) years. Each municipal judge shall be eligible for reappointment upon the expiration of his term. He shall hold office until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(b)  In the event of the absence from the city, death, disability or disqualification of a municipal judge for any reason, the mayor shall have the authority to designate a person, licensed to practice law in the state and a qualified elector of the state, not otherwise employed in any capacity by the city, to serve as acting municipal judge with all power and authority of a duly appointed municipal judge. No such acting judge may serve for more than thirty (30) successive days or a total of sixty (60) days in any calendar year; provided, that when the duly appointed municipal judge is disqualified pursuant to the Constitution, the time of service limitations for acting judges shall not apply during such disqualification. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-4; Ord. No. 92-3095, § 1, 9-21-92) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-30. 
Sec. 15-22. - Qualifications. 
(a)  Each municipal judge must be licensed to practice law in this state and must be a qualified elector of the state. No municipal judge shall be otherwise employed in any capacity by the city during his term of office. No municipal judge shall receive any remuneration for his judicial service except the salary and allowances authorized by the governing body of the city. No full-time municipal judge shall, during his continuance in office, engage in the practice of law. 
(b)  Each full-time municipal judge shall have the right to participate in such plans and programs as are generally available to other city employees, and shall earn and have vacation and sick leave on the same basis as classified employees. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-4; Ord. No. 92-3095, § 2, 9-21-92) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-30. 
Sec. 15-23. - Oath. 
    Each municipal judge shall, before assuming office, take and sign the oath provided by the Constitution, and a copy thereof shall be filed in the office of the secretary of state, the administrative director of the courts and the city clerk. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-30; oath of office, Ala. Const. Art. XVI, § 279. 
Sec. 15-24. - Compensation. 
(a)  The salary of the municipal judges shall be fixed from time to time by the governing body, but no judge's salary shall be diminished during his term of office. 
(b)  A general increase in the compensation of all or substantially all city employees shall be applied proportionately to the salaries of such judges. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-33. 
Sec. 15-25. - Presiding judge. 
    The presiding municipal judge, to be designated by the mayor, shall report on the proceedings and operation of the municipal court as may be required by law or rule. He shall take steps to have a magistrate, or magistrates, appointed for the city, pursuant to Rule 18 of the Alabama Rules of Judicial Administration. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-30, Ala. Rules of Judicial Administration, Code of Ala. 1975, Vol. 23. 
Sec. 15-26. - Disqualification from hearing of cases. 
    Municipal judges shall be subject to all grounds of disqualification from hearing specific cases as are applicable to circuit court judges. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-30. 
Sec. 15-27. - Vacancies. 
    If the office of a municipal judge shall be vacant, or if he dies, resigns or is removed, such vacancy shall be filled by the governing body in the same manner as original appointments are made. 
(Code 1956, § 18A-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-30. 
Chapter 16 - OFFENSES-MISCELLANEOUS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Municipal court, Ch. 15; power of mayor to close certain places in case of riot, § 2-60; loitering in cemetery, § 8-25. 
State Law reference- Criminal code, Code of Ala. 1975, Title 13A. 

Sec. 16-1. - State offenses adopted. 
(a)  Any person committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city or within the police jurisdiction thereof, which is declared by a law or laws of the state now existing or hereafter enacted to be a misdemeanor shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(b)  Any person committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city or within the police jurisdiction thereof, which is declared by a law or laws of the state now existing or hereafter enacted to be a violation, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(c)  Any person committing within the corporate limits of the city or within the police jurisdiction thereof, an offense as defined by section 13A-1-2 of the Alabama Criminal Code (Code of Ala. 1975, Title 13A, as amended), which offense is not declared by a law or laws of the state now existing or hereafter enacted to be a felony, misdemeanor or violation, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(d)  Any person found to be in violation of subsections (a), (b) or (c) of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or may be imprisoned or sentenced to hard labor for the city for a period not exceeding six (6) months, at the discretion of the court trying the case, unless otherwise provided by subsection (e) of this section. Any corporation found to be in violation of subsections (a), (b) or (c) of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), unless otherwise provided in subsection (e) of this section at the discretion of the court trying the case. 
(e)  Any person found to be in violation of Code of Ala. 1975, section 32-5A-191, as amended, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and/or may be imprisoned or sentenced to hard labor for no more than one (1) year. In addition, notwithstanding any other provision of law, the maximum fine and maximum imprisonment or maximum sentence to hard labor established for every person convicted of violating any of the state misdemeanor offenses adopted by reference as a city municipal code violation or offense shall be as provided in Code of Ala. 1975, section 11-45-9, as last amended. 
(Code 1956, § 19-68; Ord. No. 2207, § 1, 12-17-79; Ord. No. 83-2356, § 1, 8-15-83; Ord. No. 15-4247, § 1 , 12-21-15) 
State Law reference- Penalties for violations, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9. 
Sec. 16-2. - Marking on or affixing bills, etc., to buildings, etc., without consent of owner. 
    No person shall paint, print, tack, paste, stencil or otherwise mark upon, or in any manner place upon or affix to any buildings, fence, wall, tree or telephone, telegraph or electric light or power pole, without the consent of the owner thereof, any word, letter, character, figure, sentence or device, or any sign, banner, or notice. 
(Code 1956, §§ 3-5, 19-58) 
Sec. 16-3. - Camping on public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to do any camping or to erect or maintain any tent, shelter, trailer, wagon or other type of camping shelter and related equipment on the following: 
(1)  The city hall property, known also as the municipal building, located at 402 Lee Street, NE, Decatur, Alabama, and being on that property bounded on the southerly side by Lee Street, on the westerly side by Ferry Street, on the northerly side by Cain Street and on the easterly side by Well Street. 
(2)  All public rights-of-way within the corporate limits of the city. 
(3)  All city library properties. 
(4)  All parks and playgrounds except that such shall be allowed in established or designated camping areas set aside by the director of parks and recreation for such purpose, and subject to all rules and regulations promulgated in connection therewith. 
(5)  County courthouse, public office buildings, and grounds of such, within the city, except where such is authorized thereon by constituted authority. 
(b)  Any personal property referred to in subsection (a) of this section not removed by the owner or custodian of such from the premises mentioned therein shall be deemed abandoned personal property, and shall be handled in accordance with the provisions of section 22-6 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2147, § 19-57.1, 8-15-78; Ord. No. 2151, § 1, 8-21-78) 
Sec. 16-4. - Fortunetelling. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to carry on within the corporate limits or police jurisdiction of the city the business of telling fortunes or carrying on the trade, business or profession of phrenology, clairvoyance, palmistry or other business or like kind or nature in which the future of any person is foretold or attempted to be foretold. 
(Code 1956, § 19-31) 
Sec. 16-5. - Prevention of unlawful assembly. 
    Whenever the chief of police, or in his absence from police headquarters, the police officer there in charge, has good reason to believe that an unlawful assembly on a street or in any public park, public building or other public place in the city is in progress or is planned to be held, the chief of police, if he has good reason to believe that it is necessary to prevent a breach of the peace, a disorder or a riot, may prohibit for the time being persons from occupying or passing on any street or public place where such breach of the peace, disorder or riot is threatened or is believed by such officer likely to occur and otherwise regulate passage or occupancy upon such street and place. 
(Ord. No. 2149, § 1, 8-21-78) 
Sec. 16-6. - Visiting schools. 
(a)  No person shall enter or remain in any public, private or parochial school building between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on days such school is in session (or until 10:00 p.m. at those schools which have extended sessions), who is not a regularly enrolled student, teacher or employee at such school, unless said person shall have first and immediately proceeded to the administrative offices and identified himself to the principal or said principal's agent and receives written permission to remain on said premises. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter and remain in any public, private or parochial school, or on surrounding school grounds, after being directed to leave by the principal of said school or his designated agent. 
(Ord. No. 2148, § 1, 8-21-78) 
Sec. 16-7. - Firearms; discharging. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to shoot or discharge within the city limits of the city or its police jurisdiction any firearm, pistol, rifle, shotgun, air gun, air rifle, B-B gun or other like instrument of any nature; provided however, this section shall not apply to the following:
