Sec. 22-42. - Vehicles in public parks. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle, motorcycle, or motor-driven cycle as defined in section 32-1-1.1 of the Code of Alabama, 1975, in a city park except on public streets, designated parking areas, or designated motor traffic roads and paths. 
(b)  This section does not apply to a person authorized by the city to operate such a vehicle or cycle for park maintenance, public safety purposes, or other governmental purposes. 
(Ord. No. 01-3661, § 1, 7-2-01) 
Sec. 22-43. - Driving without a valid driver's license; impoundment of vehicle. 
(a)  In any instance when a driver of a motor vehicle fails to produce a valid driver's license in response to the lawful request of a duly sworn law enforcement officer, said officer may immediately cause the impoundment of such vehicle, regardless of the ownership or possessory interest therein of the driver, subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  The officer shall make a reasonable attempt to verify the license status of a driver who claims to be properly licensed, but who is unable to produce the license upon the demand of the officer. A notation of the officer's attempt to verify that the driver is properly licensed shall be noted on the officer's incident/offense report. If, after a reasonable attempt, the officer is unable to verify that the driver is a properly licensed driver, the officer may then cause the impoundment of the vehicle, subject to the exceptions outlined herein below. 
(2)  In the event of impoundment, the officer shall assist the driver and any occupants in securing transportation to a place of safety. 
(3)  The officer shall not impound a motor vehicle pursuant to this section if the license of the driver expired within the preceding sixty (60) days and the driver would have otherwise been properly licensed. 
(4)  The officer shall not impound a motor vehicle pursuant to this section if either the owner of the motor vehicle or another family member of the owner is present in the vehicle and presents a valid driver's license. 
(5)  In the event of an emergency or medical necessity jeopardizing life or limb, the officer may elect not to impound the motor vehicle. 
(b)  A motor vehicle impounded pursuant to this section shall be released by the city police department, subject to the requirements set forth in subsection (c) below, upon the satisfaction of any one of the following sets of conditions: 
(1)  The registered owner appears at the city police department and presents: 
a.  His/her valid driver's license; and 
b.  Evidence of insurance legible and sufficient to demonstrate that the impounded motor vehicle currently is covered by a liability insurance policy as required by state law; and 
c.  One of the following documents evidencing ownership: 
1.  The original vehicle title; or 
2.  A copy of both the front and back of the original title; or 
3.  The current vehicle tag receipt in the registered owner's name; or 
4.  A copy of the current vehicle tag receipt in the registered owner's name; and 
d.  Payment of a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) processing/administration fee to the city. 
(2)  A registered owner not in possession of a valid driver's license appears at the city police department and presents: 
a.  Photo identification clearly establishing his/her identity as the registered owner of the impounded vehicle; and 
b.  Evidence of insurance legible and sufficient to demonstrate that the impounded motor vehicle currently is covered by a liability insurance policy as required by state law; and 
c.  One (1) of the following documents evidencing ownership: 
1.  The original vehicle title; or 
2.  A copy of both the front and back of the original title; or 
3.  The current vehicle tag receipt in the registered owner's name; or 
4.  A copy of the current vehicle tag receipt in the registered owner's name; and 
d.  Payment of a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) processing/administration fee to the city. 
Additionally, when appearing in the police department to request the release of a vehicle impounded pursuant to this section, a registered owner not in possession of a valid driver's license must be accompanied by at least one (1) validly licensed driver and must execute appropriate documentation certifying the vehicle will be driven from the storage lot by a validly licensed driver or properly removed by other lawful means. 
(3)  A representative of the registered owner appears at the city police department and presents: 
a.  His/her valid driver's license; and 
b.  Written notarized authorization from the registered owner allowing for the release of the impounded vehicle to the named representative; and 
c.  Evidence of insurance legible and sufficient to demonstrate that the impounded motor vehicle currently is covered by a liability insurance policy as required by state law; and 
d.  One of the following documents evidencing ownership: 
1.  The original vehicle title; or 
2.  A copy of both the front and back of the original title; or 
3.  The current vehicle tag receipt in the registered owner's name; or 
4.  A copy of the current vehicle tag receipt in the registered owner's name; and 
e.  Payment of a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) processing/administration fee to the city. 
(4)  An order is entered by a court of competent jurisdiction requiring the release of the impounded vehicle. 
(c)  After obtaining a lawful release from the city police department, the person redeeming the motor vehicle shall then make payment in full to the wrecker service responsible for the towing and storage of the vehicle for the costs attributable to the towing and storage of said vehicle. 
(d)  Upon receipt of said release and making said payment, the motor vehicle shall be considered redeemed and possession given to the registered owner or, if applicable, the authorized representative thereof. 
(e)  If a motor vehicle impounded pursuant to this section is not properly redeemed as set out herein within sixty (60) days of the date it is impounded, then the wrecker service onto whose property the motor vehicle was lawfully towed at the written request of a law enforcement officer may advertise and sell said vehicle in accordance with applicable state law, currently Ala. Code sections 32-13-1 et seq., (1975), or as may be hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 07-3922, § 1, 12-3-07) 
Sec. 22-44. - Reserved. 
Sec. 22-45. - Prohibition of electronic messaging while driving. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Except as may be otherwise provided in this section, all words and phrases used in this section which are defined in section 32-1-1.1 of the Code of Alabama 1975 shall have the meanings ascribed to them in that section. 
(1)  Electronic message means a self-contained piece of digital communication that is designed or intended to be transmitted between physical devices. An electronic message includes, but is not limited to, a text-based communication, a command or request to access an internet site, or other data that uses a commonly recognized electronic communications protocol. 
(2)  Wireless communication device shall include a cellular, analog, wireless or digital device, computer or telephone, capable of accessing the internet or sending, receiving or downloading any electronic or digital data, including, but not limited to, a wireless telephone service, a wireless internet service, or a wireless text messaging service, videos, pictures, or communications, such as electronic mail, instant messages and text messages. Such device may or may not also include telecommunication capabilities and such capabilities will not in and of themselves determine whether the device meets this definition. Covered devices include, but are not limited to, cell phones with text or internet capabilities, devices commonly known as smartphones, electronic readers, electronic tablets, laptops, netbooks, GPS devices and other similarly equipped wireless devices. Covered devices shall not include voice radios, mobile radios, land mobile radios, commercial mobile radios or two-way radios with the capability to transmit and receive voice transmission utilizing a "push to talk" or "press to transmit" function, or any voice radios used by a law enforcement officer, an emergency services provider, an employee or agent of public safety organizations, first responders, school bus operators, taxi cab drivers or mobile commercial enterprises. Further, it does not include any device being used by law enforcement officers, emergency services providers, public safety officers or first responders in furtherance of their official duties. 
(b)  Violation-Electronic messaging while driving. 
(1)  A driver of a motor vehicle on a public roadway may not use a wireless communication device to view, send or compose an electronic message while operating a motor vehicle. 
(2)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution for a violation of this section that the wireless communications device is used: 
a.  While the motor vehicle was parked on the shoulder of a roadway or the vehicle was stopped due to normal traffic being obstructed for any reason including traffic control devices; 
b.  For making a telephone call; 
c.  As a global positioning or navigation system that was affixed to the vehicle provided that visual or audio directions were being received but no route or input information was being entered by the driver while the vehicle was in motion; 
d.  For obtaining emergency assistance to report a traffic accident, medical emergency, or serious traffic hazard, or to prevent a crime about to be committed; 
e.  In the reasonable belief that a person's life or safety was in immediate jeopardy or danger and the use of the device was related to that jeopardy or danger; or 
f.  If the device was permanently and/or factory installed inside the vehicle provided that visual or audio directions were being received but no route or input information was being manually entered by the driver. 
(3)  This section does not apply to an operator of an authorized emergency vehicle using a wireless communication device while acting in an official capacity. 
(c)  Violations as misdemeanors, penalties. 
(1)  It is a misdemeanor for any person to violate any provision of the above section (b). 
(2)  Every person convicted of a misdemeanor for a violation of section (b) above shall for a first conviction thereof be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by imprisonment for not more than ten (10) days or by both such fine and imprisonment; for a second conviction thereof committed within one (1) year of the date of conviction of the first offense, such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or by imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days or by both such fine and imprisonment; for conviction of a third or subsequent offense committed within one (1) year of the date of the date of conviction of the first offense such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(d)  Notice. The city shall erect a sign on every major thoroughfare entering the city to notify persons traveling to or through the city that the use of wireless communication devices, other than to make a phone call, while operating a vehicle is prohibited within the city. Such signs shall be erected no later than thirty (30) days following the adoption of this section. Neither the presence of the signs nor the driver's actual knowledge of the sign is an element of the offense and need not be proven to obtain a conviction. 
(Ord. No. 10-4041, § 1, 10-4-10) 
Sec. 22-46. - Truck routes. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Local delivery truck. Any truck, as defined herein, having its origin, destination, pickup or delivery point within the city. 
    Most direct route (Also referred to as most direct path ). The path or route from the point on the nearest truck route which is closest to the delivery or pick up location to the delivery or pick up location which is safe and suitable for use by the particular truck making the pick up or delivery. This definition applies in section 22-46(c)(3)e. except the path need not begin or end on the nearest truck route. 
    Through truck. Any truck, as defined herein, not having its origin, destination, pick up or delivery point within the city. 
    Truck. Any vehicle, machine, tractor, trailer or semi-trailer propelled or drawn by mechanical power and used upon the highways or streets in the transportation of passengers, property or any combination thereof determined by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration, but does not include any vehicle, locomotive or car operated exclusively on a rail or rails. As used in this section, it means any self-propelled or towed motor vehicle used on a highway or street in interstate commerce to transport passengers or property when the vehicle: 
(1)  Has tandem axles, tri-axles or a larger axle configuration; or 
(2)  Has a gross vehicle weight rating or gross combination weight rating or gross vehicle weight or gross combination weight, whichever is greater of twenty-six thousand one (26,001) pounds (eleven thousand seven hundred ninety-four (11,794) kilograms) or more; or 
(3)  Is designed or used to transport more than eight (8) passengers, including the driver, for compensation; or 
(4)  Is designed or used to transport more than fifteen (15) passengers, including the driver, and is not used to transport passengers for compensation. 
(b)  Truck routes designated. The following are designated as truck routes within the City of Decatur: 
    U.S. Highway 72A, State Highway 20, from the westernmost point of the city limits near Trinity to the easternmost point of the city limits at or beyond I-65; 
    Alabama Highway 67, Beltline Road from U.S. Highway 72A, State Highway 20 to the easternmost point of the city limits at or near I-65 near Priceville; 
    U.S. Highway 31, Sixth Avenue from the southernmost point of the city limits near Hartselle to the northernmost point of the city limits at or beyond Calhoun Community College, main campus; 
    Interstate 65 at any point within the city limits. 
    Interstate 565 at any point within the city limits; 
    State Road 24 from the city limits to Alabama Highway 67, Beltline Road; 
    Old Moulton Road from the outermost point of the city limits to Alabama Highway 67, Beltline Road; 
    Danville Road from the outermost point of the city limits to Alabama Highway 67, Beltline Road; 
    Wilson Street, NE from U.S. Highway 31, 6 th Avenue to 10 th Avenue NE; 
    Church Street, NE from U.S. Highway 31, 6 th Avenue to 19 th Avenue, SE; 
    10 th Avenue NE from Church Street to Market Street; 
    Market Street from 10 th Avenue NE to 19 th Avenue SE; 
    19 th Avenue SE from Church Street to Point Mallard Drive; 
    Point Mallard Drive, SE from 19 th Avenue SE to Monogram Drive, SE. 
(c)  Presumptions and exemptions. 
(1)  Any person operating any truck on any street or highway within the City of Decatur which is not designated as a truck route shall have in his possession for the inspection of police officers his log book or evidence of his destination and point of origin to justify the presence of said vehicle on such street. Failure to have such log book or evidence in his possession shall not be a separate offense, but shall create a presumption that such person is unlawfully operating that vehicle. 
(2)  It is presumed that the person operating any truck on any street or highway within the City of Decatur has familiarized himself with the truck routes and has taken the time to ascertain the most direct point from those routes to his pick up or delivery location prior to entering the city. Ignorance of the most direct route will not be a defense under this section. 
(3)  The driving of a truck upon a street or highway not designated as a truck route and not on the most direct path from a designated truck route to the point of pick up or delivery will not be a violation of this section in any of the following situations: 
a.  The pick up or delivery of merchandise at a location not situated on the designated truck route, provided the truck leaves and returns to the designated truck route by the most direct route available and at no point does the truck deviate from the most direct route; 
b.  Traveling to or from a service or repair shop for repairs or service to be performed on the truck, provided the truck leaves and returns to the designated truck route by the most direct route available and at no point does the truck deviate from the most direct route; 
c.  A truck shall not be required to enter or exit directly onto the designated truck route if such entry or exit would be unsafe from a traffic safety standpoint as determined by the chief of police or his designee; 
d.  Authorized emergency vehicles, school buses, church buses and municipal and utility service trucks. 
(d)  Local deliveries. There are no local delivery routes designated within the city. Drivers of trucks within the city who are or who purport to be operating as a local delivery truck, shall travel on the designated truck route and may only deviate from that route to proceed to and from the origination, delivery or pick up point using the most direct route possible and available. 
(e)  Violations. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any truck upon any street or highway within the city limits of Decatur that has not been designated as a truck route unless it is a local delivery truck engaged in a local delivery as defined herein. 
(2)  Violation of this section shall be punished by up to a five-hundred-dollar fine, up to one hundred eighty (180) days in the city jail or both. 
(f)  Signage. The truck routes within the city shall be clearly designated by signs authorized by the Alabama Department of Transportation. 
    Signage on state right-of-way shall be erected by the Alabama Department of Transportation and signage on city right-of-way shall be erected by the city as soon as practical after passage of the ordinance from which this section derives by the city council and the routes will be enforced thirty (30) days after the signs are erected. 
( Ord. No. 14-4196, § 1 , 10-6-14; Ord. No. 15-4235, § 1 , 9-8-15) 
Sec. 22-47. - Engine compression brake regulations. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Engine compression brake shall mean any device that utilizes compression and/or rapid release of compressed air in the cylinders of diesel engines to slow or retard vehicle speed. 
    Noise baffling device shall mean a properly functioning muffler or engine exhaust silencer that eliminates the offensive and disturbing noise caused by use of engine compression brakes. The muffler or engine exhaust silencer must reduce the noise to levels meeting vehicle noise emission standards set or authorized by the Noise Control Act (42 U.S.C. §4901 et seq.) and the United States Environmental Agency, and must also comply with all other federal, state, or local laws and regulations relating to vehicle noise levels. 
    Public safety vehicle shall mean any vehicle operated by the Decatur Fire Department or the Decatur Police Department, or any other vehicle included in the definition of "authorized emergency vehicles" as provided in Code of Ala. 1975, section 32-1-1.1. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of a motor vehicle to engage or allow to be engaged, operate, or use an engine compression brake while the vehicle is operated on any public roadway within the corporate limits of Decatur. 
    This section shall not apply to operators of any of the following: 
(1)  A public safety vehicle. 
(2)  A vehicle involved in an emergency not caused by the operator of the vehicle utilizing the engine compression brake, wherein the operator reasonably believes that use of the engine compression brake is necessary to avoid or mitigate an accident or collision. 
(3)  A vehicle equipped with a noise baffling device. A law enforcement officer or other competent witness may give opinion evidence based on personal observation as to whether a vehicle had a properly functioning noise baffling device. 
    The city is authorized, but is not required, to place traffic control devices in appropriate locations to supplement enforcement of this section. 
(c)  Any person convicted of violating this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-8 of this Code. 
(d)  The provisions of this ordinance are severable, and if any provision of this section shall be found to be invalid, the remaining provisions shall not be affected, but shall remain in full force and effect. 
( Ord. No. 14-4201, § 1 , 10-20-14) 
Secs. 22-48-22-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[4] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-152 et seq. 

Sec. 22-55. - Parking fines. 
(a)  Schedule. A parking fine schedule for the city is established as follows: 
Offense Fine Parking in excess of posted parking limits $ 25.00 Parking in prohibited zone or area (indicated by city curbing, signage, and markings)   25.00 Blocking fire hydrant  100.00 Parking in reserved handicapped zone-first offense  100.00 Second offense of handicapped zone  200.00 Third and any subsequent offenses of handicapped zone  500.00 Parking in fire lane  100.00 Parking in/blocking the alley   25.00 Reverse parking   25.00 Double parking   25.00 Blocking driveway   25.00 Parking on sidewalk   25.00 Abandoned vehicle   25.00 Parking in crosswalk   25.00 Parking of oversized vehicles or oversized trailers in residential areas   25.00  
(b)  Payment; parking offense disputes. The magistrates are authorized to accept such fines and adjudicate all such offenses in cases where the party receiving the ticket wishes to pay the fine without a court appearance. Otherwise, the municipal judge shall adjudicate, determine and decide parking offense disputes. There are no court costs. Notwithstanding the schedule in subsection (a), the municipal judge may impose a fine of one dollar ($1.00) to one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) for any parking violation. 
(c)  Late charge. If a person cited with a parking violation fails to pay the same or request a trial within fourteen (14) days from the date of the citation, then the fine for such offense shall be increased by fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(Ord. No. 89-2818, §§ 1, 2, 2-20-89; Ord. No. 95-3283, § 1, 11-6-95; Ord. No. 01-3650, § 4, 5-7-01; Ord. No. 14-4168, § 1 , 2-3-14) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 89-2818, adopted Feb. 20, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1 and 2 as § 22-55 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 22-56. - Compliance with "No Parking" signs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any automobile, truck or other motor vehicle, or any muscular drawn or propelled vehicle, on any public street, public alley, public right of way, municipal lot or any designated portion thereof within the city where the police department shall have caused signs or markers to be placed prohibiting parking and marked "No Parking." 
(Code 1956, § 25-56; Ord. No. 01-3650, § 2, 5-7-01) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-152. 
Sec. 22-57. - Restricted parking. 
(a)  Yellow paint or markings on any street or curbing shall mean parking is prohibited in that area so marked; provided, however, areas marked with yellow paint and designated as a loading zone shall be permitted to be used for that purpose or for whatever purpose so designated. 
(b)  The existence of such signs, signals, markers or markings at any place within the corporate limits of the city shall be prima facie evidence that such signs or markers were erected or placed by and at the direction of the chief of police and in accordance with the provisions of sections 22-3 and 22-4. 
(c)  Any person failing or refusing to comply with the directions indicated or any sign or marker erected or placed in accordance with the provisions of this section when so placed or erected shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1956, § 25-2) 
Sec. 22-57.1. - Parking on Grant Street. 
    Parking along the south side of Grant Street, S.E. from Second Avenue, S.E. to First Avenue, S.E. is hereby established and permitted to be diagonal provided that the parking at such place is between the painted parking space limit lines and so long as such parking is not in violation of any other traffic law. 
(Ord. No. 93-3151, § 1, 6-21-93) 
Sec. 22-57.2. - Parking on Lee St. NE and North Side of Holly Street. 
(a)  There will be no on-street parking on Lee St. NE between Sixth Ave. NE and Oak St. NE. 
(b)  There shall be no on street parking on the North Side of Holly Street NE from Fourth Avenue NE to Second Avenue NE. 
( Ord. No. 14-4168, § 2 , 2-3-14) 
Sec. 22-58. - Parking on Memorial Drive. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any automobile, truck or other motor vehicle, or any muscular drawn or propelled vehicle, on Memorial Drive S. W., also known as Danville Road S. W., within the area beginning where the southerly margin of Third Street S. W., intersects the westerly margin of Memorial Drive S. W., and extending southerly five hundred sixteen (516) feet therefrom. 
(Code 1956, § 25-56.3) 
Sec. 22-58.1. - Parking on Brookline Avenue. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any automobile, truck, or other motor vehicle on the entire length of Brookline Avenue, S.W., from its intersection with Old Moulton Road, S.W., to its intersection with McNair Street, S.W., between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 95-3273, § 1, 9-12-95) 
Sec. 22-59. - Parking on Moulton Street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any automobile, truck or other motor vehicle or any muscular drawn or propelled vehicle on Moulton Street (Alabama Highway 24) from the intersection of Moulton Street with the easterly right-of-way line of Gordon Drive, said point being established by drawing a line across Moulton Street at right angles to the southerly boundary of said Moulton Street (Alabama Highway 24) and the Old Moulton-Decatur Road, said point being ascertained by drawing a line at right angles to the southerly right-of-way of said Moulton Street from the point of its intersection with the easterlymost right-of-way line of the Old Moulton-Decatur Road. 
(Code 1956, § 25-56.4) 
Sec. 22-60. - Parking on Wilson Street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any automobile, truck or other motor vehicle or any muscular drawn or propelled vehicle on Wilson Street N. E. between Sixth Avenue N. E. and a line one hundred fifty (150) feet westerly from and parallel to Sixth Avenue N. E. 
(Code 1956, § 25-56.2) 
Sec. 22-60.1. - Parking on Fourth Avenue NE. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any automobile, truck or other motor vehicle or any muscular drawn or propelled vehicle on Fourth Avenue NE between Cain Street NE and Lee Street NE. 
(Ord. No. 16-4254 , § 1, 3-21-16) 
Sec. 22-61. - Unlawful purposes. 
    No person shall park a vehicle on any street or roadway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale. 
(2)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(Code 1956, § 25-54) 
Sec. 22-62. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-3650, § 1, adopted May 7, 2001, amended the Code by repealing former § 22-62 in its entirety. Former § 22-62 pertained to parking between certain hours; and derived from the Code of 1956, § 25-57. 
Sec. 22-63. - Manner of parking. 
(a)  No vehicle shall be allowed to park on any street other than with the right hand wheels of such vehicle parallel to and within eighteen (18) inches of the curb; provided that at any place where lines are painted on the street at approximately a forty-five (45) degree angle with the curb, the parking at such place shall be at such forty-five (45) degree angle and between the painted parking space limit lines. 
(b)  A vehicle shall not stand backed up at any angle to a curb unless driven up as near as possible, and if horse-drawn, and with four wheels, the horses shall stand parallel to the curb and facing in the direction of the traffic. 
(c)  For a third conviction for violation of this section the municipal judge shall revoke the driver's license of the person so convicted. 
(Code 1956, §§ 25-55, 25-57) 
Sec. 22-64. - Time limits for parking-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or operated by such person to be parked upon a public street in the city for a period of time greater than that posted by municipal authorities upon such street or streets. Except as may be otherwise provided or required, the chief of police is authorized and empowered to post time limits for parking on the public streets in the city. 
(Code 1956, § 25-56.01) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-152. 
Sec. 22-65. - Same-On certain streets. 
(a)  Two-hour limit. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or operated by such person to be parked more than two (2) hours at any time during the hours between 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday upon any one (1) of the following streets, or parts of streets unless a vehicle has displayed a distinctive handicapped decal or placard identification and is in a marked handicapped space, in the city, to wit: 
(1)  Grant Street SE, from Fourth Avenue SE to First Avenue SE. 
(2)  East Moulton Street, from Fourth Avenue SE and NE to railroad tracks. 
(3)  First Avenue SE and NE, from Lee Street NE to Grant Street SE. 
(4)  Second Avenue SE from Lee Street NE to Gordon Drive SE. 
(5)  Holly Street NE on south side from Fourth Avenue NE to Second Avenue NE. 
(6)  Johnston Street SE, from Fourth Avenue SE to First Avenue SE. 
(7)  Bank Street NE, from Lafayette Street NE to Cherry Street NE and on the east side only from Lafayette Street NE to Church Street NE. 
(8)  Cain Street NE from Line Street NE to Ferry Street NE and on the South side between Well Street NE and Ferry Street NE. 
(9)  Ferry Street NE from Cherry Street NE to Lee Street NE. 
(10)  Line Street NE on the east side from Cain Street NE to Lee Street NE. 
(b)  Violations. The fine for violation of this section is hereby established at twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 89-2803, § 1, 2-6-89; Ord. No. 04-3821, § 1, 12-6-04; Ord. No. 06-3879, § 1, 10-16-06; Ord. No. 14-4168, § 3 , 2-3-14; Ord. No. 16-4254 , § 2, 3-21-16) 
Sec. 22-66. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 89-2803, adopted Feb. 6, 1989, repealed former § 22-66, which pertained to one-hour limited parking on certain streets. Such repealed section bore no history note. 
Sec. 22-67. - Chalk marking of vehicles to determine overtime parking. 
    In areas where parking is limited to a specific period of time, officers of the police department are authorized to make an appropriate chalk mark or other easily removable indication on the tread of one of the tires of such vehicles parking in such areas so as to provide a means to check the length of time each such vehicle is so parked, and it shall be unlawful for any person to remove or rub off any such mark or indication while such vehicle remains parked at the space where the mark or indication was first placed thereon. 
(Code 1956, § 25-56.1) 
Sec. 22-68. - Abandoning vehicles on public streets-Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city, and shall constitute a public nuisance, for any person to park or leave standing on any public street or sidewalk in the city any car, bicycle, automobile, truck, cart, wagon or other vehicle of like kind or nature for a period in excess of three (3) days; and it shall be unlawful and an offense against the city and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to park or leave standing or abandon on any street, sidewalk, municipally owned parking lot, alley, or other public place in the city, any vehicle that is damaged, wrecked, unlicensed, inoperable, or that is incapable of being used for its intended purpose, for a period in excess of twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Code 1956, § 25-62.1; Ord. No. 04-3795, § 1, 4-5-04) 
State Law reference- Abandoned motor vehicles, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-13-1 et seq. 
Sec. 22-69. - Same-Exception. 
    Nothing contained in section 22-68 shall be construed as prohibiting a person from parking his vehicle in the street adjacent to the curb in front of his premises, when such parking is not otherwise prohibited, provided the vehicle is moved from time to time as convenience directs, the purpose of section 22-68 being to prohibit the abandoning of a vehicle on a public right of way, alley, municipally owned parking lot, sidewalk, or other public place within the city. 
(Code 1956, § 25-62.2; Ord. No. 04-3795, § 2, 4-5-04) 
Sec. 22-70. - Same-Impounding. 
    When it is made known to the police department that any vehicle has been parked or left standing on the public streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public place or in one of the prohibited areas as defined by law or ordinance, the police department is authorized to immediately remove the vehicle to some storage place and to hold it there until the owner properly establishes his ownership and pays the cost of removing the vehicle from the street, alley, sidewalk or other public place and pays the cost of storage and handling. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as binding the city to hold the vehicle in storage for an indefinite and unreasonable time or to prevent the city from selling the vehicle as provided for by this Code. 
(Code 1956, § 25-62.3) 
Sec. 22-71. - Trailers, trucks, etc., in residential districts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park, or leave standing on any public street or alley in a residence district of the city, as defined in the traffic law, except when in the process of loading and unloading, any truck, trailer or other structure whatever, or combination thereof, or any other type motor vehicle, trailer, tractor or structure whatever which is in excess of twenty-two (22) feet in length, or which is in excess of seven (7) feet in height. 
(Code 1956, § 25-65.1) 
Sec. 22-72. - Buses, picking up or discharging passengers. 
    Any bus, stopping to pick up or discharge passengers at any intersections where bus stops are provided, shall stop in the spaces provided. Any bus stopping at any street intersections, for such purpose, where stops are not designated, shall pull to the right side of the vehicular traveled portion of the street as far as possible and shall stop just before entering the intersection or just after clearing the intersection. It shall be unlawful for any driver or operator of a bus to stop the same, to pick up or discharge passengers, at any place other than at an intersection as provided in this section. 
(Code 1956, § 25-59) 
Sec. 22-73. - Bus stops-Use by vehicles other than buses. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stop or park any vehicle or to place any obstruction in any bus stops, except a bus operator to whom a permit has been granted by the council, and his employees, and except that a taxicab may stop in such stops for the purpose of receiving and discharging passengers, provided that the driver thereof does not get out of his taxicab except to open the door thereof, and provided further that such taxicab shall immediately move out of such stop upon the approach of a bus. 
(Code 1956, § 25-60) 
Sec. 22-74. - Same-Markers. 
    Any licensed bus operator to whom a permit has been granted by the council may equip bus stops with suitable markers indicating to the traveling public where the buses stop; provided, however, that any such markers are subject to the approval of the council. 
(Code 1956, § 25-61) 
Sec. 22-75. - Inter-city or interstate buses, use of streets as terminal. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any interstate or inter-city passenger bus to stop on any street, avenue or alley in the city or in the police jurisdiction thereof, for the purpose of taking on or discharging passengers at any point in the city except at the regular designated and authorized bus station of the bus company owning such bus. 
(Code 1956, § 25-58) 
Sec. 22-76. - Trains standing at crossings; time limitation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit or suffer the standing of any railroad train or engine, or part thereof, except when located upon a track constituting a mainline track, on or across any street or highway within the corporate boundaries of the city for more than five (5) minutes within any consecutive fifteen (15) minute span of time. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, or cause to be operated, moved or propelled, any railroad train or engine, or part thereof, on any sidetrack, spur track or other railroad track other than such constituting mainline tracks, in such manner so as to thereby prohibit crossing at any street or highway within the corporate boundaries of the city, other than Market Street, N. E., easterly of its intersection with Somerville Road, N. E., for more than five (5) minutes within any consecutive fifteen (15) minutes span of time. 
(Code 1956, § 25-57.1) 
Sec. 22-77. - Handicapped parking spaces. 
(a)  Designation; signs. The lieutenant in charge of traffic for the police department is hereby authorized to designate marked parking spaces for the exclusive parking of motor vehicles operated by handicapped individuals on public property. With the consent of the property owner, it is also authorized, in addition to the above, for the lieutenant in charge of traffic for the police department of the city, to designate certain parking spaces in privately owned parking areas as parking for handicapped individuals. The parking spaces so designated shall be properly marked along with a posted sign stating it is designated for parking by handicapped individuals. 
(b)  Definition of "handicapped individual." For the purposes of this section, the term `handicapped individual' means any person having a permanent mental or physical handicap, which limits mobility to the extent that the individual would have difficulty safely walking alone a distance of fifty (50) feet or more. 
(c)  Parking without decal or placard. It shall be unlawful for any person who does not have a distinctive handicapped decal or placard as provided for by state law to park a motor vehicle in a parking space designated for handicapped individuals and, upon conviction, shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense, and five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the third or any subsequent offense. In addition, for the second or any subsequent offense under this section, the person shall be ordered by the court to perform a minimum of forty (40) hours of either of the following forms of community service: 
(1)  Community service for a nonprofit organization that serves the disabled community or serves persons who have a disabling disease; 
(2)  Any other community service that may sensitize the person to the needs and obstacles faced daily by persons who have disabilities. 
(d)  Enforcement. Any authorized municipal, county, or state law enforcement officer may go onto private property to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1956, § 5-21-79; Ord. No. 88-2749, § 1, 6-6-88; Ord. No. 01-3650, § 3, 5-7-01) 
Sec. 22-78. - Obstructing sidewalks. 
    It is hereby made unlawful for any person to leave any automobile or other vehicle of any type standing on any sidewalk in the city or to obstruct the free passage along any sidewalk or street while loading or unloading any automobile, truck or other vehicle of any type. 
(Code 1956, § 23-3) 
Sec. 22-79. - Time limits for parking in parking lots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or operated by such person to be parked in a public parking lot owned or controlled by the city for a period of time greater than that posed by municipal authorities in such parking lot. Except as may be otherwise provided or required, the chief of police is authorized and empowered to post time limits for parking in such public lots in the city. 
(Ord. No. 91-2995, § 1, 7-1-91) 
Sec. 22-80. - Parking in city hall parking lots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or operated by such person to be parked in the city hall parking lots for more than a two-hour span without the distinctive city hall decal or permit issued by municipal authorities. Except as may be otherwise provided or required, the chief of police or his designee is authorized and empowered to post the appropriate signs stating the time limits for such lots. 
(Ord. No. 94-3230, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-81. - Illegal to park, etc. commercial vehicle on public street or alley in residential district. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park, stand or allow the parking or standing of more than one motor vehicle used for their commercial or business related use, on any public street or alley in a residential district of the city, as defined in the Zoning Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 96-3294, § 1, 2-5-96) 
Sec. 22-82. - Illegal to park in no-parking areas. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any automobile, truck or other motor vehicle, or any muscular drawn or propelled vehicle, in any area of a city parking lot where the police department shall have caused yellow paint, signs or markings to be placed prohibiting parking. 
(b)  Yellow paint, signs or markings in any city parking lot shall mean parking is prohibited in that area so marked; provided, however, areas marked with yellow paint and designated as a loading zone shall be permitted to be used for that purpose or for whatever purpose so designated. 
(c)  The existence of such yellow paint, signs or markings at any place within a city parking lot shall be prima facie evidence that such signs, paint or markings were erected or placed by and at the direction of the chief of police and in accordance with the provisions of section 22-3 and 22-4. 
(d)  Any person failing or refusing to comply with the directions indicated or any signs, paint or markings erected or placed in accordance with the provisions of this section when so placed or erected shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 97-3355, § 1, 3-3-97) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 97-3355, § 1, adopted March 3, 1997, amended the Code by adding a new § 22-81. In order to prevent the duplication of section numbers, the editor has redesignated the section as § 22-82. 
Sec. 22-83. - Parking used vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to display or offer for sale at any given time more than one vehicle on a lot or parcel of real property, or permit the same to be done, within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, tenant, or person in charge of a lot or parcel of real property to display or offer for sale at any given time more than one vehicle on said lot or parcel or real property, or permit the same to be done, within the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to display or offer for sale, or any owner, tenant or person in charge of a lot or parcel of real property to display or offer for sale, or permit the same to be done, any vehicle upon the public right-of-way or other public property within the city, provided, however, this section shall not prohibit a person from operating a vehicle, bearing a "for sale" sign, upon a public right-of-way or from parking said vehicle in a permissible parking space located upon and within such public right-of-way for a period of time reasonably necessary for said person to accomplish a purpose unrelated to the display or offering for sale of the vehicle. In addition to applicable penalties, any vehicle found to be in violation of this section may be towed away, impounded, and stored, until redeemed, at the owner's expense. 
(d)  Subsections (a) and (b) above shall not apply to any person properly licensed by the city to engage in the business of selling vehicles at the location designated upon such license. 
(e)  Any person properly licensed by the city to engage in business at a particular location at the time of this section's adoption who may otherwise be affected by this section shall be allowed to continue its business pursuant to the terms of such license until such time as the business ceases to operate for a period of six (6) months or the person fails to renew his business license for that location. 
(f)  Any ordinance or portion thereof which is inconsistent or conflicts with this section is hereby repealed to the extent of said inconsistency or conflict. 
(g)  Should any section or provision of this section be held void or invalid, such determination shall not affect the validity of any other section or provision hereof which is not itself void or invalid, it being the purpose and intention of the city council to enact each separate section or subsection separately. 
(Ord. No. 00-3596, § 1, 5-1-00) 
Sec. 22-84-22-99. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-3720, § 1, adopted June 3, 2002, amended the Code by adding reserved sections 22-84-22-99. 
ARTICLE V. - SCHOOL TRAFFIC 

Sec. 22-100. - School zones-Traffic study. 
    The chief of police or his designee shall make or cause to be made within the city and the police jurisdiction thereof a study of traffic problems therein as the same pertain to both vehicular and pedestrian traffic within the vicinity of public and private schools. Such study shall include areas within the immediate vicinity of public and private schools and, additionally, shall include other areas over and along the public streets of the city and the police jurisdiction thereof where children customarily cross said public streets on the way to and from school. 
(Ord. No. 02-3719, § 1, 6-3-02) 
Sec. 22-101. - Same-Signs; speed limit. 
    The chief of police or his designee, after having conducted the study of traffic conditions as required in section 22-100, shall cause to be designated and marked off with signs and appropriate markings on the surface of the street certain areas along and upon the public streets of the city which shall be designated and known as "school zones." 
    From and after such time as signs and/or flashing signal lights as provided in section 22-103 shall be erected to warn the traveling public, it shall be unlawful to drive a motor vehicle over, along or through any properly designated school zones at a rate of speed greater than fifteen (15) miles per hour during the times designated by said signs and/or flashing signal lights, unless specifically excepted from this provision by section 22-102 below. The chief of police shall designate, by appropriate markings upon said signs and/or by flashing signal lights, the hours of the day during which said speed limit shall be in effect and the maximum speed allowable. 
    Should the traffic study provided for in section 22-100 determine that the maximum rate of speed allowable for a particular school zone should vary from said limit of fifteen (15) miles per hour, the same shall be approved by the council before implementation. The chief of police shall then designate, by appropriate markings upon signs and/or by flashing signal lights erected under the authority of this section, the hours of the day during which said special regulations shall be in effect and the maximum speed limit allowable. 
(Ord. No. 02-3719, § 1, 6-3-02) 
Sec. 22-102. - Same-Speed limit; exceptions. 
    The chief of police or his designee shall cause to be excepted from the speed limit established in section 22-101 the following school zones and shall also cause the speed limit in said zones to be set as follows during the times designated by signs and/or flashing signal lights erected under the authority of this article: 
(1)  Austin High School - Danville Road: 25 miles per hour; 
(2)  Cedar Ridge Middle School-Danville Road and Modaus Road: 25 miles per hour; 
(3)  Horizon School-Church Street: 25 miles per hour; 
(4)  Leon Sheffield Elementary School-Wilson Street: 35 miles per hour; 
(5)  Gordon Bibb Elementary School-Gordon Drive: 25 miles per hour. 
    From and after such time as signs and/or flashing signal lights as provided in section 22-103 shall be erected to warn the traveling public, it shall be unlawful to drive a motor vehicle over, along or through any of the above-designated school zones at a rate of speed greater than that established hereinabove during the times designated by said signs and/or flashing signal lights. The chief of police shall designate, by appropriate markings upon said signs and/or by flashing signal lights, the hours of the day during which the special regulations contained in this section shall be in effect and the maximum speed limit allowable. 
(Ord. No. 02-3719, § 1, 6-3-02) 
Sec. 22-103. - Same-Signs. 
    In carrying out the authority of this article, the chief of police or other person designated to erect the signs and signals required under these such sections shall designate school zones with traditional signs and markings in common ordinary use for such purpose or by use of any other sign or device approved by the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices as published by the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA). 
(Ord. No. 02-3719, § 1, 6-3-02) 
Chapter 23 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 7; fire prevention and protection, ch. 11; licenses and business regulations, ch. 14; solid waste, ch. 19; streets and sidewalks, ch. 20; floodplain management, § 25-29 et seq. 
State Law reference- Public utilities, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Use of utility service without registering in meter. 
    No person shall connect a tub, pipe, wire or other instrument or contrivance with a pipe or wire used for the conducting or supplying of natural gas, water or electricity in such a manner as to supply such natural gas, water or electricity to any burner, orifice, lamp, faucet, fixture, motor or pipe where the same is or can be burned or used, without passing it through the meter or instrument provided for registering the quantity consumed. 
(Code 1956, § 19-35) 
Sec. 23-2. - Destroying or disconnecting meter. 
    No person shall destroy, alter or prevent the action of a meter or other instrument used to measure or register the quantity of natural gas, water or electricity consumed by a user or such utility service, or detach or disconnect such meter or other instrument. 
(Code 1956, § 19-35) 
Sec. 23-3. - Changing or altering pipe, wire or attachment. 
    No person shall, in any manner whatever, change, extend or alter any service or other pipe, wire or attachment of any kind, connecting or through which natural gas, water or electricity is furnished from the gas or water mains, pipes, wires or source of supply of any person. 
(Code 1956, § 19-35) 
Sec. 23-4. - Connecting with, turning on or off gas, etc., of another. 
    No person shall make any connections or reconnections with the gas or water mains, service pipes or wires of any person furnishing to consumers natural gas, water or electricity, or turn on or off in any manner, or in any manner interfere with any valve or stopcock or other appliance belonging to such person and connected with its gas or water mains, service or other pipes or wires. 
(Code 1956, § 19-35) 
Sec. 23-5. - Reserved. 
Sec. 23-6. - Setting gas on fire or interfering with mains, conduits, etc. 
    No person shall set on fire any gas escaping from broken or leaking mains, pipes, valves or other appliances used by any person in conveying gas to consumers or shall interfere in any manner with the pipes, mains, gate boxes, valves, stopcocks, wires, cables, conduits or any other appliances, machinery or property of any person engaged in furnishing gas, water or electricity. 
(Code 1956, § 19-35) 
Secs. 23-7, 23-8. - Reserved. 
Sec. 23-9. - Acts done on premises; proof of guilt of defendant. 
    Proof that any of the acts specified in this article were done on the premises in the possession of the accused or that the accused received the benefit of any such act shall be prima facie evidence that the accused committed such act, or aided or abetted in the commission thereof, maliciously or with intent to injure or defraud. 
(Code 1956, § 19-35) 
Secs. 23-10-23-25. - Reserved.

(b)  The Municipal Utilities Board of Decatur, Morgan County, Alabama, and the water department are hereby vested with the authority to install the necessary facilities for the introduction of fluorides into the city's water supply, and to introduce such fluorides into the water supply, in accordance with the regulations of the Alabama Department of Health. 
(Code 1956, § 22-7.2)

The certification by DU shall include restated access fees and/or usage charge rates, calculated to include the inflation increase herein. 
c.  In any year, commencing in 2017 and thereafter, if the certification as provided in (3)b. above is not made by DU to the City Council of Decatur, Alabama, the rates in existence on October 1 of that year shall remain in effect until such certification is made in a subsequent year or until other rate action is approved by the city council.
